name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, Siegfried Mureşan and Dragoș Pîslaru, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on establishing a Recovery and Resilience Facility (COM(2020)0408 – C9-0150/2020 – 2020/0104(COD)) (A9—0214/2020). I should like to remind Members that for all the debates there will be no catch—the—eye procedure and no blue cards will be accepted. Furthermore, as during the last part—sessions, remote interventions from Parliament’s liaison offices in the Member States are foreseen.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, good morning on what I believe will be a very good day for the European Parliament today. Today, we are giving our final vote, our approval, to the EUR 672.5 billion European Recovery and Resilience Facility. This means that money will be coming, support will be coming, for people, for enterprises, for regions all over Europe affected by the coronavirus and by the consequences of this pandemic. Our message is clear: help is coming, support from the European Union is coming to those affected.  This support, this money, is money to overcome this crisis, but it is also money to make us stronger in the face of the next crisis. It is money for recovery and for resilience, to make us more resilient to better face the next challenges in the future. Never, ever, again in the future, people and enterprises should be affected by crisis as they have been until now. It’s money to modernise our economies, to make them cleaner and greener, to make them more digital, more innovative, more modern. This is why how we are going to use this money is very important.  Parliament proposes that the money goes in six directions. Firstly, greening. Second, digital. Thirdly, economic cohesion: money for the private sector, for small and medium-sized enterprises, for industry, money for infrastructure projects. This is the third pillar. The fourth pillar is social cohesion: money for the people affected, different social categories affected by this pandemic, including children, including elderly people.  Fifth, institutional resilience: we are going to strengthen the institutions in Member States about which we learnt during this crisis that they have to modernise, increase their capacities. And here I would like to be very clear – countries can use this support to build or modernise existing hospitals, to build new hospitals or modernise and enlarge existing hospitals. And the sixth pillar is money for youth.  We, as the European Parliament, have negotiated intensely in the last months and we believe that through Parliament, the European Recovery and Resilience Facility has been made better. What have we achieved? Firstly, we have managed to offer and agree on an increase in pre-financing. That means that once a national plan of one country is approved at European level, the pre-financing, the support that it will receive, will be bigger – 13%, thanks to the involvement of Parliament, compared to the 10% initially proposed. This means that the recovery will be quicker and more decisive. We will be able to create more jobs more quickly due to the increase in this pre-financing.  Then the structure with the six pillars, which I just described, is also a proposal and an achievement of the European Parliament. We are setting up clear rules for spending the money, but within these rules we are also leaving flexibility for Member States to decide where they use the money. We say 37% of the amount at European level should go into greening and 20% into digital. But we do not impose other specific proportions for different directions because the needs of different Member States are different. Malta is different from Finland, Portugal is different from Ireland, Luxembourg or Romania, and countries should be able to decide, within the European rules, to use the money where they need it.  We, as the European Parliament, have also imposed that Member States make a self-assessment with regard to safeguarding the cybersecurity of the European Union while accessing money from this Recovery and Resilience Facility. In clear words, the money should be used in a way in which the cybersecurity of the Union as a whole and of individual Member States should not be affected. For example, money should not be used for investment in 5G networks by hostile companies from countries outside of the European Union against our will. The money is not for ordinary budgetary expenditure to finance deficits. The money is for investment and reforms, and reforms are a key concept to make our economy stronger for the future, and this is something which Parliament will insist on very much. We, as the European Parliament, have also achieved that there will be democratic control for all of the money spent, democratic control and legitimacy through the involvement of the European Parliament. Parliament will be involved in all of the future phases. We will supervise, we will scrutinise to make sure that money is being spent according to the rules. And we have also achieved, together with the Commission and with our colleagues in the Council, that the European Recovery and Resilience Facility will be revised after two years. We are going to look at it. We are going to have a review, evaluating how things go and see if something needs to be further improved or adjusted. Today we are going to vote in favour of this Facility, I believe, by a very large majority. I would like to thank my co-rapporteurs, Eider Gardiazabal Rubial from the Socialist Group and Dragoș Pîslaru from the Renew Group, for the excellent cooperation which we had throughout this process, and I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs of all of the other political groups. This Facility was adopted by a large majority in the joint meeting of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and the Committee on Budgets (BUDG), and I believe a large majority of Members will also support it today. This is thanks to the excellent cooperation which we had throughout the groups.  To conclude, the experience of the last year shows us that none of us, no country alone, can overcome this pandemic; only the joint response of all of us, based on solidarity, will help us. This is a day of success for the European Parliament. It’s a good day for Europe. Thank you very much for your support.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Mr Dombrovskis, Secretary of State Zacarias, with this debate and the subsequent vote we are facing the last step in the entry into force of the long-awaited and much-needed recovery and resilience plan. And the first thing I would like to highlight is the Success of the European Union in tackling the pandemic-derived economic crisis with an investment plan of almost EUR 700 billion, an absolutely different response to that of the 2008 crisis, where austerity and cuts were the big headlines. This plan is the right answer, this is what the citizens of the European Union expect: protection, support, aid... because the impact on their lives is being very hard. And this Parliament was very clear from the outset and, as early as May, we adopted a resolution calling for a strong economic response. The long and historic July Council laid the groundwork for this recovery plan to come to light, and during the second half we have been working to define, together with the German Presidency and the Commission, the axes of this investment plan. This plan is a double response: on the one hand, the short-term recovery, with an injection of money that will slow the fall in GDP in our countries and that will revive investments, and whose effect will be felt in the productive sector and in households, and, on the other hand, transformation, resilience, because it is not only about stopping the economic impact , but to take advantage of these investments and reforms to make unprecedented transformations. We have been talking for years about sustainability, digitization, modernizing education, efficient public administrations, but the lack of funding has so far turned these ideas into utopias. So far, because this plan is going to allow progress in these areas in a few years what in other circumstances would have taken decades. The basis on which the July European Council discussed was good: a large plan, EUR 670 billion; a rapid mobilization plan, so that its impact is immediate, and a plan focused on the ecological and digital transition; but for Parliament this was not enough, and we believed that the plan had a good chance of improvement. That is why we proposed and agreed with the German Presidency on a number of points.  First, expand the targets to six. This is how we aligned the plan with the European Union's strategies and priorities: the Paris Agreement, the Sustainable Development Goals, the European Pillar of Social Rights... The objectives of the plan are: combating climate change; digitization; social and territorial cohesion; economic pillar to support industry and SMEs; health and institutional resilience to increase response capacity and preparedness in the face of crises, and the last pillar focused on youth and children, with objectives such as education, training or insertion into the labour market.  In the fight against climate change we wanted to be more ambitious and for this we have changed three aspects. On the one hand, we have increased spending to 37%. We have also included the principle of 'not causing significant harm', so that no investment or reform financed by this plan can harm the environment. And finally, we've established a new methodology for accounting for that green expenditure, to make sure that spending is real and not an empty amount of content. In the digital field we have specified that at least 20% has to be spent. And in the social sphere, in addition to adding it as one of the fund's priorities, we wanted it to be a cross-cutting aspect and that is why we have committed to making reforms and investments contribute to the fight against poverty, to the creation of stable and quality jobs, and to the integration of disadvantaged groups or to the improvement of social protection systems. The 2008 crisis showed that making decisions based on debt and deficit, regardless of social impact, was a very bad strategy and we do not want this to be repeated. In this regard, the agreed macro-conditionality will have to take account of those economic and social circumstances of the Member State concerned, in particular the level of unemployment and the level of poverty or social exclusion in that Member State, as well as the effect that a possible suspension would have on the economy.  Coronavirus has caused an unprecedented crisis, an unprecedented health crisis, and tested our health systems. The lack of material and human resources has been alleviated by the unlimited commitment of our health and health care, but this is neither fair nor sustainable, so this plan, as it could not be otherwise, will also serve to improve accessibility and capacity of our health systems and to prepare them for future crises. This crisis, like all of them, has also particularly struck women, and we could not accept a plan that did not take this situation into account. In gender budgets and methodology to measure the impact of gender-based investments and reforms, we are still in the 19th century, and this is a to-do task that we cannot delay any longer. This is good financial management, measuring the impact of measures, not only from an economic or social point of view, but also with a gender perspective, so we will follow very closely how to address it in the different national plans. We have worked hard: we have also included the importance of national plans being designed with agents, we have managed to increase pre-financing, we have achieved retroactivity until 1 February 2020; there has been no phrase that we have not negotiated until exhaustion. For my part, I would also like to thank my co-workers, Mr Siegfried Mureaan and Mr Drago-Pslaru, for their work. It hasn't been easy to agree on some issues, but we never quit until we get an agreement. To the shadow rapporteurs too, because they have been a fundamental part of the team, and of course to the Commission and the Council. We have spent many hours negotiating, days and nights; it's been impossible at times, frustrating, but we've managed to come to terms, so now it's up to countries to work to make this plan a success.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, dear Executive Vice-President Dombrovskis, ‘Europe’s destiny is in our hands’ are words that were spoken in this assembly 40 years ago by Simone Veil. One year ago, when the pandemic hit our continent, these words couldn’t be more accurate. We, as representatives elected by European citizens, have all a duty to deliver a proper recovery and consolidated resilience to our citizens, to our entrepreneurs, to the young people and children of tomorrow. This was indeed the European Parliament’s ambition. Together with my colleagues, Siegfried Mureşan and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial, we understood that the recovery will not work if we are not comprehensive. We understood that resilience couldn’t be achieved without ambition. We spent hundreds of hours, days and nights, thinking, listening, writing, discussing, negotiating, in order to find the best solution to win this battle and leave from it stronger. The RRF, the Recovery and Resilience Facility, is a symbol. It’s a symbol for the story we are going to tell our children and grandchildren years from now. It’s a symbol of the vision that we have for Europe and it’s a symbol of how we can unite behind a good purpose. And this is why we have actually found a proper solution, and we will implement this successfully. We owe this to the next generation. We have a story that our children will be proud of. A story that for me started in May 2020, when I was attending a conference about the early impact of COVID-19 outbreak on children, when I heard children’s representatives telling us that they are scared, that they are uncertain about their future and about the way in which they can continue their education. And many young people that were present there, you know, basically uttered their emotions about the fact that they might get unemployed or they might have an uncertain future. And I made a promise that day that children and youth would be at the centre, at the core of our recovery. How can we talk otherwise about the Next Generation EU if we are not going to deliver to the children and youth of tomorrow? And shortly after, when the Commission announced the recovery package, the one that repairs and prepares Europe for the next generation, we knew together that we should actually avoid that our youth and children would become what is called a ‘lockdown’ generation. And the European Parliament delivered on this promise, with the cooperation of the Council and of the European Commission. We have right now a pillar dedicated to children and youth that is beyond the pillars, the other five pillars that have been actually mentioned already, especially the social pillar that is also contributing to the fact that no one will be left behind. And the story continues and brings us to the present. And this is actually really important to see how things developed, because in August 2020 I conducted consultations in 13 Member States and I was actually talking to stakeholders and citizens and social partners, and this was a big effort to hear the citizens, to listen to them. And that’s why we actually put this in the mandate of the European Parliament in the negotiation. As part of our ambition right now, you will find in the Regulation the fact that we need to consult stakeholders and citizens in the elaboration of the national plans. And this is important and this is the message that the Parliament is sending, and the hope that we eventually put forward should allow the citizens to express their view. Last but not least, this facility – the RRF – is about unity. And European unity comes when we let our values guide us. In the European Parliament team we had different political views, but we stood united and we have been united in a team, and then at the beginning of the negotiation with the Council and the Commission, I specifically said: this is not Parliament on one side, Council on the other side, Commission on another side. We are all together, Team Europe, and we’ve been doing the negotiation in the interest of citizens. And this is actually shown in the regulation. And I am so proud that we acted as Team Europe, and I’m sure that we will act as Team Europe for the implementation. And obviously for having the trust of the citizens, we need to have transparency and we need to have the scrutiny, and we need to have legitimacy and democracy and accountability linked to that. Because we are strong together, and if we are going to work together with the 27 Member States, then indeed we should remember that this is not a cash machine but an instrument that requires full transparency and access to information. 2020 will remain a sad memory about losses, about uncertainty, about fear and insecurity. But the Recovery and Resilience Facility: it’s a symbol, it’s an ambition, it’s something about listening to citizens, and it’s a story about promise and vision and about European unity. And this is right now becoming reality. This is what we want our generations to come to remember. This is our role: to ensure that it’s going to be well implemented. I would like to thank again Siegfried, Eider, all the shadow rapporteurs, the chairs that have been guiding us, all the other colleagues and teams and our assistants and policy advisors that work together. We have the chance to be remembered as the ones that set the example for the next generation. I’m quite proud to present the mandate of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee. If there is one lesson we ought to have learned by now, it is that we are indeed stronger together, and there are threats that we can only take as a Union. This is something that the pandemic has not only reminded us, but actually made us apply in practice. Our unity is provided by the strength of our society, and what society needs right now is the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF): an instrument that puts social cohesion at its core; an instrument that shows how youth and children are a priority for our policy; an instrument that will make the European Pillar of Social Rights become a reality. Because if we are to speak about resilience, this is the pillar on which our resilience relies. The Employment Committee saw that this facility is the solution for citizens, and I think that this paves the way for the ambitious action plan ahead of the Porto summit in May. We have a choice to make, so let’s make the right one. Let’s adopt for our citizens the Recovery and Resilience Facility.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Madam President, Madam Minister, Mr Executive Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, what we are doing today, namely adopting the European recovery plan, is historic. It's historic for three reasons. The first is that, for the first time, we are investing together, united, in future investments. The second reason why this is historic is that we are connecting this recovery plan with the transformation of our economy and in particular with the Green Deal: 37% of these investments will be for the climate and 100% of the European money will not have to harm the environment and the climate. These are key results, which make a huge difference and make the United Nations classify this European recovery plan as the second greenest in the world. The third reason why this is historic is that we are going to pay back this stimulus package, not by making our citizens pay taxes, but by making those who today do not pay taxes pay: the digital giants and the big polluters who import raw materials such as steel to our markets, and who do not pay taxes.  All of this, we will decide formally today. That is why today's vote is historic.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. Madam President, on behalf of the ITRE committee, we have contributed to the work that has been done for this facility for recovery and resilience. First, by adding a definition of resilience that was not present in this text. For us, resilience is about being able to produce what we need to cope with tomorrow's crises. The crisis we have just experienced has shown how dependent we have already become, for basic necessities, on other major world powers. It is, of course, the sovereignty of our Member States that is at stake for the future. We have also included a "future clause" in this work to ensure that the funding that will be mobilized is actually used in a way that will produce the prosperity of future generations, which will enable them to repay the funding we transfer to them. In fact, this recovery and resilience plan continues to pose a major problem: we have together agreed on debt without agreeing on the terms of its repayment. I think there was a political necessity there, but also an ethical necessity to prepare for our future. It is in this long-term sense that the ITRE Committee wished to carry out its work.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. – Madam President, because I am also the shadow for the ECR Group, I will try to touch on both issues – the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the political view from the Group. I would like to thank all the colleagues who worked in the Committee on Transport and Tourism and also on the main dossier on the RFF for this final result, which we succeeded in reaching with the Council. Actually, as you may know, we normally always look forward to how it fits our plans, which is very important for Member States, and also to make it flexible for Member States. The final result was not so centralised and gave Member States flexibility at the same time as keeping reasonable opportunities to control and govern from the EU dimension. It’s also crucial that we look at the grants part of the RFF, that there should be a new approach from the Member States, not only old plans which no longer fit into reality. It also very much touches the transport sector, where we have a huge opportunity to take the environment-friendly approach to mobility, but particularly taking into account that CO2 emissions in transport are still very high in proportion to other branches of the economy. We should also have to check Member States’ cooperation with our social partners and others in preparation for national plans for recovery and resilience, and also that it should cover all the envelopes. Finally, in the transport sector, we have to remember that the ratification of own resources opens us to access for the Commission to go for RFF money to financial markets, to borrow this money. If the ratification of own resources is very slow, partly because some of the Connecting Europe Facility and other dossiers are not yet finished and Member States are very careful on these ratifications, that’s life.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, dear rapporteurs, Honourable Members, Vice—President Dombrovskis, thank you for having invited the Council to take the floor on this very important debate, and allow me to start by congratulating the rapporteurs for their impressive work and to express the commitment of the Portuguese Presidency to ensure the swift adoption and implementation of this regulation. The COVID-19 pandemic caused a once-in-a-generation crisis with deep social and economic impact, which will leave a mark on our societies for years to come. But the crisis also demonstrated that the European institutions could live up to the challenges, showing unity, solidarity, decisiveness, working together on an ambitious common tool. With the help of the European Commission, the Parliament and the Council worked together to put forward the Recovery and Resilience Facility that will help us to heal our wounds and stand back up stronger, ready for the future. This is Europe at its best. The RRF is unprecedented in several ways. First, for its size: almost 40 percent of the MFF and the Next Generation EU combined. Second, for being the first EU financial instrument financed by common debt, even if temporary. Third, for its capacity to provide much needed stimulus and the right incentives to address structural issues in an ambitious and forward—looking way. Fourth, for its ambitious policy agenda on climate and digital transitions. And finally, for how quickly it was done. After intense and constructive trilogue discussions, we found political agreement on the text, which will be voted on today in this House and soon in the Council. We are very happy to highlight the excellent cooperation between the Presidency and the Parliament to ensure a speedy entry into force of the RRF. Now begins a new journey: a journey that the Parliament, the Council and the Commission will make, together with each and every Member State, towards stronger, greener, fairer and more digital and competitive societies. There is indeed a lot of work ahead of us. National parliaments need to continue the ratification process of the Own Resources Decision. Member States should present their national plans as soon as possible, and we all need to contribute to ensure their quality without slowing the process down. The regulation now reflects many elements that are important both for the Parliament and the Council, such as the six pillars, the European added value and the reference to the European pillar of social rights. Also important is the link with Invest EU, as well as the involvement with local authorities and civil society. The Commission will have to properly take these elements into account in its swift assessment of the plans. The Parliament will also play a key role in ensuring transparency and accountability through its structural dialogue with the Commission. As for the Portuguese Presidency, I can only reiterate that we are committed to strengthening the EU through a swift and efficient implementation of the facility, ensuring a high degree of inter-institutional cooperation. We are also focusing on bringing the RRF to citizens and business as soon as possible, and we count on your support in this endeavour.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Recovery and Resilience Facility is a centrepiece of Europe’s economic recovery plan Next Generation EU. It is key for ensuring successful, sustainable and inclusive recovery so that Europe emerges stronger and more resilient from the crisis.  The compromise reached by Parliament and the Council in December is a significant achievement. It is a balanced agreement that cements our determination to combine ambitious reforms and investments to secure our way out of this crisis in a lasting manner. The agreement is an important signal that the EU’s institutions are united at this time of crisis. Let me highlight some of its main points. The compromise reflects the EU’s ambitions on the green and digital transitions. It sets a binding green target of 37% and a binding digital target of 20% at the level of the individual national recovery and resilience plans. It reinforces the green dimension, particularly by improving the methodology for climate tracking. It introduces new safeguards for digital measures that will help preserve Europe’s security and strategic autonomy. While the discussions on governance were not easy, we found a compromise that ensures that the voice of Parliament will be heard – and listened to – throughout the implementation of the Facility, while respecting the constraints given by the institutional balance. The scope of the Facility has been restructured in six pillars and Member States are required to provide balanced recovery and resilience plans that respond to these policy areas of European relevance. They will also help to explain how their plans contribute to implementing the European Pillar of Social Rights, on which the Commission will shortly present an action plan.  At the same time, the compromise preserves the anchor of the Facility in the European Semester, including the need for Member States to address in their plans at least a significant subset of the challenges identified in the relevant country-specific recommendations. Finally, the compromise agreement protects the EU’s financial instruments by making the approval of the plans contingent on adequate national control systems. Now that almost all Member States are preparing their plans at full speed, Parliament’s endorsement of the agreement is very important. It is also essential that Member States ratify the Own Resources Decision as soon as possible so that the Commission can start carrying out its funding operations. We need to put the Facility into effect as quickly as we can. European money needs to start flowing to Member States to help in their recovery, support their businesses and people, and re-start their economies in a direction that is sustainable and resilient. The Commission is in constant contact with all Member States to discuss the preparation of the plans. To date, there has been substantial progress and we have a relatively clear view of what 18 of the 27 Member States intend to include in their Recovery and Resilience Plans. However, there is still a lot of work ahead. Even those Member States whose plans are most advanced are now working on translating investment and reforms into operational milestones or on complying with other requirements of the Regulation. We are there to help. Developing high-quality national plans with a long-lasting impact will be key to the overall success of the Facility. They will make the European Union and its Member States more resilient. For this to happen, we need to find a proper balance between reforms and investment. The plans also match our joint ambition to accelerate the green and digital transitions. Member States need to include genuine green and digital reforms and investments to match the targets. The plans should not include a patchwork of small measures with little impact. Indeed, they should reflect a clear strategy for embracing the twin transitions and implementing reforms in line with the country-specific recommendations. Along with work on preparing and assessing the plans, the Commission will also work on the delegated acts required under the Regulation. First, the recovery and resilience scoreboard will be the main tool to inform the public on progress in implementing the Facility across the six pillars. Second, the Commission should develop common performance indicators that will be published on the scoreboard. Another important and related work-stream will be to create a methodology for reporting on social expenditure. In all of these areas, the Commission will work constructively and transparently with Parliament and the Council to achieve the best outcome. We call on the honourable Members to endorse the Recovery and Resilience Facility so that Member States can officially start submitting their plans for the Facility and to put the Facility into practical effect.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, Secretary of State Zacarias, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, the Reconstruction and Resilience Facility is probably the cornerstone of targeted and sustainable construction in order to be "healed" from the pandemic, to put it this way, but also to sustainably advance our economy in a sustainable way. From the point of view of budgetary control, however, it is also important in this unique act of solidarity that, firstly, we know where the money is going, to whom the money actually flows, and whether it is distributed fairly and according to the objectives actually planned. Because what the European Parliament has negotiated is an excellent starting point, and it is now up to the Member States to make the most of this starting point. However, we also want to know, with regard to the fairness of distribution, whether the imbalances that have existed in some Member States up to now will continue, whether only a few will benefit from them or whether jobs will actually be created sustainably for a wide range of people. We also want to know that the money is not being used for objectives such as .B. the assumption of regular and recurring expenditure in national budgets. We want this fund to be actually used for what it is intended for, for the future of Europe.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Regional Development. – Madam President, colleagues, the current pandemic has taken the whole world by surprise. The best response was that of the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism, providing large-scale financial support for investments and public reforms that increase the resilience of national economies and better prepare them for the future. This is eur 672.5 billion in financial support, which is the centrepiece of the Next Generation EU recovery instrument.  I thank all the rapporteurs, and as rapporteur from the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to thank all those who have accepted that the amount available for non-refundable support, 60% of this amount, be accessed by the Member States by the end of 2024. I believe that it is also important for the Member States that flexibility is also important in terms of macro-financial conditions.  Of course, we all know, the Mechanism comes to supplement the amounts that Member States have at their disposal for the financial period 2021-2027, and support will be provided only on the basis of plans drawn up by each national government, plans by which Member States will have to demonstrate that the money will reach ... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... where they are most needed...  (The President withdrew the speaker's word).

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Madam President, this is one of the largest ever EU funding programmes, a programme that will be crucial in repairing the economic devastation we’ve suffered. The leadership shown from the Commission in supporting Member States economically has been unprecedented in both its scale and speed. But it’s not about repairing only, it’s about looking to the future. We need to constantly reinforce the message we want to build back better. That must be based on the key pillars of green, digital, but crucially, equality. I’m glad to see that the final agreement on the RRF has recognised the gender dimension of the COVID crisis and the differential impact that the crisis has had on women. Parliament wanted to go further. Member States must now take this opportunity to enshrine gender equality targets in their national recovery plans. We must build back better by investing in the green economy, care infrastructure, digital literacy, sustainable finance for SMEs and invest in our cities, such as Dublin, to make them more liveable. Member States must reflect this in their national recovery plans, and the Commission has a responsibility to ensure that governments build back better. Let us use the crisis as an opportunity to build a green, digital and more inclusive economy. This is not just a social imperative, but... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, Madam Secretary of State, it is urgent that the EUR 672.5 billion made available by this recovery and resilience mechanism quickly reaches the economy and is used to modernise our countries. And we can't miss this opportunity.  Madam Secretary of State, countries like Portugal should use this instrument, for example, to create an instrument for the solvency of small and medium-sized enterprises. Don't delay this process anymore. And here is a question: when do they provide for the own resources decision to be ratified by all national parliaments? It is that without it there will be no possibility of having this European mechanism of recovery and resilience.  For the first time, the European Commission will use a guarantee from the European Union budget to make a loan for Member States to promote investment, and interest and repayments of EUR 312.5 billion for grants are assumed by the EU budget. These financial resources need to be used well, otherwise it will be impossible to repeat this show of solidarity. So I ask Mr Vice-President of the European Commission: will the European Commission be attentive? Will it oblige Member States to come up with good plans, to comply with regulations? It is that there are countries that are not listening to local authorities, they are not listening to the regions or the social partners and without that hearing, and without that hearing, it will not be possible to approve, the positive opinion of both Parliament and the Commission. I end up with a request: please don't waste any more time and this is a message to the Member States. The economy needs it. Small and medium-sized enterprises are in a very difficult situation. Hurry up! It's time to move on and act quickly.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, today we are closing a long process of nine months of intensive work to put together, to build this European response to the crisis arising from the coronavirus. I would like to recall the resolutions which this Parliament adopted in April and, in particular, in May, with broad support from many parliamentary groups, demanding a solidarity fiscal response, an ambitious fiscal response and an investment programme which could contribute to the recovery process after the months of confinement and these difficult months to combat the pandemic. And I also wanted to vindicate the role of this Parliament, supporting the Commission's initial proposal and demanding that the European Council validate it at that complicated summit in July, and the work of recent months to improve the multiannual financial framework and to improve the Regulation as well. Because Parliament has made this text a self-contained proposal, a proposal which clearly sets out the investment priorities for all the countries of the European Union, for the whole of the Union, and those six pillars set out in the Regulation, to help, set the lights and guide the work now being done by Member States in implementing the various recovery programmes.  This Parliament has also managed to keep the budgetary conditionality on this future revision of the tax rules and, moreover, the recovery plans have supervision by European citizens, which is nothing more than the supervision of this European Parliament.  So nine months of hard work and now we pass responsibility fundamentally on the Member States, which have to develop, to comply with these national recovery and resilience plans, as I say, under the guidance of the European institutions. And to hope that this very different response from the one that Europe made ten years ago will help to open a new horizon for the whole of Europe.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Mr Dombrovskis, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, today we approve of the rules of the recovery fund which will allow our countries to rebuild their economies after the severe blow of this pandemic, a blow which is being particularly businesses and entrepreneurs, for small businesses in particular. If we do not remedy their desperate situation, we will see a huge wave of insolvencies that will take our productive fabric ahead and make many families suffer. What can we do? The regulation we adopt today requires reforms and investments. The solution of the solvency problems of SMEs and self-employed persons also requires reforms and investments. While it would be the easiest thing to do, investment should not be limited to projects designed for large enterprises: States must ensure that SMEs and self-employed people will also benefit from European money, and this requires one thing to begin with. It requires, at a minimum, that they receive all necessary information; right now they're in absolute darkness. As for reforms, in Europe, from here we have been calling for a second chance for small businesses and insolvent people. We cannot condemn a small businessman to civilian death because the debts have become unbearable. Unfortunately, our insolvency systems make it very difficult, almost impossible, for SMEs to free themselves from these burdens. What changes do you need? First, the European Commission, Mr Dombrovskis, must require countries that entrepreneurs be able to get rid of their debts in an agile and fair way to start over. Second, the State must take away its debts: state appropriations, social security credits and taxes. We cannot allow this crisis to ruin those who have had to close their businesses to save the lives of their fellow citizens.

name: Antonio Maria RINALDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President Dombrovskis, exactly one year after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, we are finally voting on the instrument that should strongly support our economies. I regret, however, that the conditionalities included, if not applied flexibly enough, could create problems for Those Member States that decide to activate the Recovery and Resilience Facility both in the form of a subsidy and as a loan. The basic problem with the RRF regulation is that it incorporates compliance with the recommendations of the Country Report of the years 2019-2020, therefore prior to COVID-19, and this crystallizes the criteria for calculating the output gap contained in the CAM (Commonly Agreed Methodology), which instead turns out to be the subject of criticism from many member countries. In accordance with this pattern, the suspended Stability and Growth Pact would be re-proposed in all its pro-cyclical vigour. On the basis of a reasonable change in the CAM methodology, it is therefore possible to leave the Member States more room for manoeuvre, without the current serious risk of generating hyteresis in excess unemployment and amplifying the fall in domestic demand.  It is also important to point out the constraints on growth due to the next generation EU agenda which, by type of planned investments not calibrated to the real needs posed by the fall out of the pandemic, will not promote the hoped-for growth but strong disputes with the Commission and among the Member States about the level of fiscal consolidation inevitably corresponding to the due financing of interventions rigidly schematized in the New Generation. The crisis generated by the pandemic can therefore be an excellent opportunity to finally reformulate all the economic governance on which the single market is based.  It should also be pointed out the issue raised by President Lagarde, who states that no debt cancellation is possible because it is prohibited by the Treaties. The same cannot be said to make renewals of those government bonds purchased under the PEPP programme perpetual, de facto, while, of course, always using the capital key criterion. It would be a question of freezing sine die of good debt - just to use mario draghi's definition of the debt contracted to support growth. It is a question solely of political will and not of technical impossibility.  We are living in an historic moment in which we must have the courage and the strength to change them with the consent of all the rules conceived over thirty years ago and now inadequate to the needs of growth and social cohesion in the world in which we live.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, today we give final approval to the Recovery Fund Regulation and it is certainly a historic day. We are going to launch the famous Eurobonds, because they are that, "Eurobonds", –shared debt to make transfers.  Gone are the years of the Troika, the years of wild austerity that caused us to suffer a much deeper financial crisis and get out of it later. Somehow, all those who for years have been denouncing austerity in Europe can sing victory. With a European Central Bank finally intervening in debt markets and with debt-sharing financial instruments to make investment, today the European Union and the Eurozone, above all, are much better equipped and the European project has many better prospects.  Much remains to be done, of course, and the risks are great. The largest, in my view: too early a reintroduction of the Stability and Growth Pact which, if decided, must be urgently reformed because it no longer serves to tackle and to give perspective to fiscal policy at European Union level.  We have achieved much as a Parliament in negotiating this regulation and I would like to stress this: greater climate ambition, with a new methodology for calculating climate expenditure: with a principle of not harming, which will exclude much of the polluting investments; with greater participation of local and regional authorities in the management of funds, also with new social objectives. I believe that the European Parliament has done an excellent job and I would like to congratulate myself on that.  Now, of course, it is up to us as a Parliament to monitor the implementation of the instrument and, of course, we are going to be very demanding with the Member States. Complying with climate spending rules; that meet gender equality, which is one thing we are concerned about in implementing the plan as well. But we will also be demanding with the European Commission and the kind of reforms, above all, it will require.  There's a lot of work. Of course, to amend the tax legislation of many Member States. After the leak yesterday from Openlux, I think we have a lot of work there. But above all we do not want, Mr Vice-President, is to return to the kind of anti-social reforms that did so much damage to our economies. We must not walk there and neither the Regulation nor the country-specific recommendations indicate this path. The way is to build more cohesive societies, make investments and reforms that are socially just. Finally, I would like to end by thanking the rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation. Today is a very important day for the European Union and I sincerely believe that this House has risen to the historical moment.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the rapporteurs and other speakers have already discussed at length the characteristics of this fund, which is absolutely necessary to get our economy back on track, as it is called. But I would like to present a different approach in my consideration.  I see this fund as a new opportunity for the Commission, a new opportunity to manage this instrument, to ensure that the quality, sustainability and effectiveness of the projects are guaranteed. I hope that this second chance will be seized, because the Commission has missed the first and great opportunity to propping up that recovery – namely promoting rapid and efficient vaccination throughout the Union.  Do not get me wrong: I fully support European coordination. It would have become much more difficult for small Member States, in particular, without coordination. But that is why it is just as disappointing that the Commission has not given sufficient substance to this coordinating role. Started too slowly, all kinds of manoeuvres which ultimately increased the backlog and uncertainties about contracts – with a confrontation with the pharmaceutical sector as an inevitable consequence. And along the way, they also managed to damage trust. Despite all the statements and apologies, it's really not a good track. When it took office, the Commission set itself the objective of evolving into a geopolitical player. That sounded like music to many of us back then. But with what has happened in recent weeks, the opposite has been achieved. I feel that a great deal of respect and trust has been lost, among the international players, internally in the Commission, and I dare also suspect it because of the heads of government.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, the mutualisation of debt that underlies this recovery fund is good news for the European Union, a news that has taken a long time to arrive. I still remember the time when this proposal was seen as an absolute irresponsibility. But it continues, this recovery fund, to be debt, and it is good that we do not deceive the citizens in this regard. Mutualised debt is debt and is being contracted on account of budgets and cohesion policy of the future if we do not finish the task of approving the own resources that can pay it off.  The second good news about this recovery fund is that the punitive regime which has been approved by this Parliament, negotiated by the Socialists and the right and approved by the main groups in this House, has fallen into the Council and, at a time of patting championships on the back, is news that should embarrass this Parliament. We have been pressing from the point of view of European solidarity, it is a pity that the Council has shown the seriousness of this precedent to this House.  One important aspect is that, despite the fall of the punitive regime, there is still an umbilical link to the European Semester and the threat of the return of the famous macroeconomic conditionality. And there is no point in making appeals to the Commission not to repeat the mistakes it has made in the past, because we know that it will repeat them. The Regulation creates that link and gives these powers to the Commission and it is naïve to think that the European Commission will not use them. Once again, it will be up to the Member States to resist these impositions and to resist the repetition of past mistakes.

name: Mislav KOLAKUŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, respected colleagues, fellow citizens, lockdown and PCR tests with an unprecedented campaign of fear, what have they brought in? They led to citizens losing their freedom, losing their right to move, losing their right to work.  It prohibits the work of certain citizens. Millions of jobs have been lost. Introducing PCR tests as a method of determining disease and cause of death is a crime against humanity. It's a crime against every man in particular.  In history, united states have conquered Nazism and fascism. Now a new, growing Nazism that no one wants to put an end to on behalf of the states will put an end to free citizens. It's time for free citizens to come together and say enough. We want the truth. Enough lies. Enough fear. There was a time when wars were fought with weapons, now they're going to be guided by the truth.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. I quote: 'It goes without saying that this Parliament must ensure democratic accountability and have a say in the whole reconstruction package, just as it usually does with the EU budget'. This is a quote from Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, from 13 May last year, here in this building, dear Valdis, from this place.  And another quote. "I am always committed to ensuring that this House, which means Parliament, has full say in all the important decisions for our Union." This is also what the President of the Commission said here in this Chamber – on 27 May last year – at the presentation of NextGenerationEU.  This week, we are now voting on the core element of this NextGenerationEU – the Building and Resilience Facility. After all, we are talking about more than EUR 670 billion. The European Parliament may decide on the framework, but not on how the billions will be spent in practice. However, if we look at how the preparation of the national reconstruction plans is discussed in the Member States, this would be urgently needed. Too often we see that the Member States are not only pushing for future investments, but also plugging budget holes, funding current programmes and not investing in the future.  A right of veto by the European Parliament could have been an important corrective here. In the end, the Commission not only failed to deliver on this promise, but actively evaded it in the negotiations. The President of the Commission's commitments for a strong role for Parliament have turned out to be empty promises in the negotiations. Even if we do not have a right of veto in the end, I can assure you that we will exercise our rights of control. In the end, it will be all the more important that the Commission does the same. It is now primarily up to the European Commission to ensure that a genuine European project with real added value for the people is created.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, Madam Secretary of State, Mr Vice-President, we all know that the ease of recovery and resilience is the key instrument at the heart of 'Next Generation EU', our European plan to get out of the current crisis. Yes, today's vote is historic. This instrument will make more than EUR 672 billion available in the form of loans and grants to support the reforms and investments undertaken by Member States, hence the importance of the quality of the stimulus packages drawn up by these Member States. This regulation will play a crucial role in mitigating the economic and social impact of the coronavirus pandemic and in improving the sustainability, resilience and preparedness of European economies and societies for ecological and digital transitions. Economic impact, implementation of the European base of social rights, environmental and climate obligations: this is the aim of the ease of recovery and resilience. We can only be satisfied, moreover, with the inclusion of the rule of law regulation in the general conditionality regime. But there are two periods for ease of recovery and resilience: the period in which the general safeguard clause is in place, and it will be up to it to extend, and the period where the general safeguard clause will be lifted. For even if macroeconomic conditionality is framed in the proposal for the facility, what will happen after the lifting of the general safeguard clause? Is the Commission ready to undertake a major reform of the six-pack, the two-pack and the European Semester? And, in fact, to reorient the Stability and Growth Pact? With the same causes having the same effects, it would be appropriate not to make the mistakes of the past, to accurately assess the period we are living in and to make proposals for long-term structural reforms, and in particular to settle the issue of own resources with responsibility.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, this is a great adventure that we are about to have. I hear that thanks to this recovery plan, the city of Brussels will be able to remove the scaffolding from its famous courthouse and even renovate the fiftieth anniversary - let us hope that at that price, the European flag can finally fly under its arcades. More seriously, ladies and gentlemen, this plan will allow us to improve the energy performance of our buildings, and therefore to pollute less. This plan will allow us to digitize our economy, to connect our territories. It will enable us to tackle the scourge of young people without education and without a job. That is the Europe we are building. That is the Europe we are voting on today. Let's be proud. Nevertheless, a watchword: no fraudsters. No state that deviates from our values. No state that deviates from the investment criteria we have collectively decided. We will be very vigilant in this regard, be convinced. Last but not least, and perhaps at the risk of repeating myself, this plan will not cost the states a euro. It will not cost the citizens one euro, because we have negotiated a repayment agreement. This agreement was negotiated by MEPs, but some here in this House claim otherwise. The own resources will be implemented and will be used to repay the recovery plan. Colleagues, Europe is taking a radical historical turn. So I say this bluntly: yes, it is a giant step towards a more integrated Europe and we must assume it, because that is effective Europe.

name: Peter KOFOD
text: Madam President! You quickly catch what the attitude is here in the eu's sacred halls. If the EU does not work, it is just because we have not had enough of it. If the EU construction is wrong, then it just needs to be built upwards. And if the EU's federal trains have gone off the rails, then even more coal needs to be shovelled. That is the EU doctrine over and over again. More and more the EU wrapped up in empty rhetoric about unity and solidarity. We are therefore talking here about a package of hundreds of billions of euros, of which up to half of the money is direct monetary gifts to southern and eastern Europe. It is, after all, an astronomical amount in which countries with order of things will pay for those who are in disarray. All this is just a matter of a project that is thundering in one direction towards the United States of Europe. The aim seems clear: fiscal policy is harmonised, debt policy is harmonised and money is sent to southern and eastern Europe. And then the rest of us are left with EU taxes.  Imagine you're taking advantage of the corona crisis to fulfill your federal wet dreams of even more EU. If you are against this federal money circus, you are exposed as uncool. But to you, I have a message for those of you who are trying to hold on to this concoction: it is not uncooperative to say no to countries such as Denmark, which has reformed our economy several times, now again having to pay for those countries that have neglected due diligence on their own matters of money. It is not uncooperative to insist that the Danes do not have to pay for more gifts of money to southern and eastern Europe. It is not uncooperative to be against EU taxes. I am now sick and tired of the Danes having to pay and pay and pay. I am voting against this and I look forward to the day Denmark exits the EU.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Madam President, dear Ministers, dear Executive Vice—President, dear co-rapporteurs and shadows, dear colleagues, this law is no ordinary law. This law is the centrepiece of the EU recovery fund, and it lays the foundation for something new. When I entered this House one and a half years ago, there was no common European fiscal policy and no needs—based solidarity in times of crisis. When the financial crises hit in the past – and we all know they hit hard – the only support our countries could find lay in unloved and undemocratic tools like the ESM. With our vote today, this will change. The RRF is no ordinary law. It is a political, federalist, European innovation, a game changer for our common European economic policy and solidarity in Europe. Our vote today may very well mark the beginning of a more permanent architecture to raise EU funds and to direct them where they are most needed, irrespective of nationality. This law sets new, unheard-of standards when it comes to investment. It requires countries to address the adverse effects of the crisis on women, to invest in the next generation and to support the ones most hit via its social pillar. It ensures that over the next six years, EUR 250 billion  need to be invested to fight climate change based on an improved investment tracking methodology, while not spending one cent on harmful activities when it comes to the environment. It ensures that over the next six years, another EUR 135 billion will be invested towards the digital transition. But this law is not only about investment, it’s also about reforms. It asks countries to tackle the weaknesses that they have, because we can potentially get out of this crisis with investments, but we will not be able to weather the next one without reforms. So with today’s vote, the ball is in the court of the countries, and they need to draw up their national recovery and resilience plans. But I would like to give them four short messages on this process. First, the struggles we can see in some countries show that these plans need to be publicly debated and scrutinised. You need to involve the public, and this cannot just be backroom deals. Second, all countries need to tackle reforms – also Germany, the Netherlands and France. Third, invest fresh money. Don’t just repackage existing stimulus packages. And fourth, we from the European Parliament, we will be watching, because we care. We will scrutinise every euro spent. We will scrutinise every plan to ensure that this project is a success.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We all remember the popandemic reduction in GDP in the European Union from 7% to 10%. We praise the wise December compromise and look forward to it resulting in a rapid transfer of funds from the recovery plan. So far, countries have rescued themselves. Polish the government helped companies, entrepreneurs, the disabled, seniors.  The Union cannot therefore act through shaming ideologies. Important climate targets should not, after all, impoverish the economies of weak countries. Free soups cannot be a hit with the Union, as it is now in Spain, where unemployment is present. Digitalisation should not be an end in itself and eliminate people from electronic processes.  The pandemic has taught us that Europe must have its own medicines, its own pharmaceutical industry. The current winter teaches that fossil energy sources are not dirty when there is a lack of electricity and heat. In Sweden, green energy has just lost out to frost, and the Swedish government is proposing to switch off vacuum cleaners. All this is happening in the European Union.  The priorities and pillars of the recovery plan must be human, realistic, because then we will succeed. They also need to be country-specific. I wish everyone good luck in their implementation.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, this recovery mechanism has three capital problems which I would sum up as well: how much, who pays and under what conditions will it be applied? Firstly, let us not make this what it is not: money is much less than the European Parliament itself has pointed out that it is necessary. It is not even enough to mitigate the impacts of the pandemic let us more to relaunch and modernize economies. It's not a silver bullet, it's not really a bazooka.  Secondly, most likely, what is certain at the moment is that this mechanism will be reimbursed by the Member States themselves which are now receiving on account of future payments. They will pay what they now receive with cuts in future budget transfers.  Thirdly, this mechanism is tied to the economic and political conditionality imposed by the European Union. In realising what this means, I would remind you that two years ago, in the European Commission's country recommendations, the European Commission had Portugal cut health expenditure. There is always a political margin of manoeuvre in implementing it as any other regulation. But leaving under the dictates of these gentlemen the application of this money cannot give good results.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism is one of the tools of the European Union and civil governments to boost the profitability of the monopolistic groups of specific sectors that prioritise, for example the so-called green and digital transition, with the aim of overcoming the new capitalist crisis, accelerated by the pandemic, and benefiting from international competition, particularly with the USA and China.  Grants or loans are not "free money", as sw claims in Greece, or "dowry" of the country according to SYRIZA. It is the money of the peoples who, in conditions of generalised wage and labour rights, are intended to protect monopolies. They are linked by new tough measures (National Pisaridis-type plans) and new mechanisms to control the "objectives and reforms" added to the unpopular arsenal of the European Semester, country recommendations and evaluations.  We call on the workers of our country to reject old and new memoranda, to organise the fight for their modern needs and to clash with the strategy of the European Union, its capital and its governments, which are burdening them with the heavy consequences of the crisis.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, we are suffering the second, the third, and maybe soon, the fourth wave of the virus. That also means a second, a third and maybe a fourth wave of the economic crisis. This recovery package was designed only for the first wave. I warn this Parliament: Member States will come for more European money. There are three things we need to clarify right now. First, national parliaments must immediately ratify the decision on own resources: in other words, there will be no European money without new resources. Second, Parliament must be involved in the decision—making process from beginning to end, and our opinion must be taken into account by the Commission. Third, Parliament must also be involved in the evaluation of the 27 national plans on an equal footing with the Council. National governments have a very bad habit of quickly being in Brussels when they are ask for money, but when it is about transparency and accountability, they turn a blind eye. This is why, Madam President, I ask you, please, to formally extend an invitation to the Heads of Government of the 27 to come to this Parliament and to present their national plans here, which I must insist are possible because of the generosity of Europeans. We are ready to deliver EUR 750 billion, but for the sake of transparency and decency, don’t do this with the lights off and in the backyard of democracy.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, today is the International Day of the Greek Language and I will speak in my mother tongue, which is also a key foundation of our European culture. Today is a good day. We have an agreement with a satisfactory end result and we will support the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism, which includes grants and loans. It is the European Union's biggest financial tool so far and is going to be its contribution to dealing with the effects of the pandemic to the maximum, in order to restart our economies and become sustainable and resilient in the future.  As a European Parliament we have set out something very specific. Since this is an unprecedented crisis with huge negative economic and social consequences, similar unprecedented measures are needed to be reflected in practice. We have fought persistently in the negotiations and reached a final agreement stating that we are prioritising our joint action to deal with this crisis. This is a very important step we are taking as a European edifice. We are experiencing the second wave of the pandemic and suffering workers, households, businesses, vulnerable groups, women, children, education, culture and so many other sectors that have been affected and need support. This mechanism enables Member States to proceed by raising funding for reforms and investments across a wide range — employment, health, tourism, research and innovation, environment and energy, small and medium-sized enterprises and so much more. But the Member States will have to formulate their own plan, targeted at the framework we have set out. I note that there is a reference in the text on islands and isolated areas and the need for greater attention from the European Union because of the particularities they face. Finally, the exploitation of the pandemic to impose associated small memoranda on the Member States is rejected. It is also an opportunity to proceed immediately with the revision of the Stability Pact.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, Secretary of State, only a year ago in this House no one could have imagined a pandemic of this magnitude, a pandemic that has taken our affections away from us and has put our economy in crisis, but which at the same time has made us witnesses to Europe's redemption.  Of course, we could dwell on the intergovernmental approach with which we arrived at Recovery or on the critical aspects of this regulation. However, I believe that we must highlight the historic turning point that this moment represents for the process of European integration. In the face of the pandemic crisis, we have chosen to make common debt, to distribute resources in a spirit of solidarity, to base national recovery plans on social cohesion and tomorrow's challenges: the environment, climate change, to which at least 37 % of resources must be devoted, digital with at least 20 %, attention to the new generations. It may seem little to some - and for my idea of Europe it is - but the right path has been taken. It is up to us and our countries to follow it courageously and without looking back.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, there will be economic crises. It is rarely predicted by what causes it or when it will come. This time, the crisis was triggered by the coronavirus pandemic. The best way to prepare for crises is to keep your own finances in order to be able to afford to revive when you need to. Malinen, docent in economics, sees the stimulus package as a support package for the euro, because unfortunately the single currency, the euro, took away the Member States' own currency. One of the most important tasks of the currency is to be flexible in crises and recessions. This would be a much more economically sound way of evening out competitive differences rather than transfers. In the single currency, the weakest countries will become increasingly weak and stronger, as capital injections will seek out more productive countries. To compensate for this, the state will have to take on debt and once sufficient debt has been taken out, there will be a debt crisis.  Currency courses have two options. The Transfer Union or it will be throwned into an exit mechanism. I did not support the euro support package for 2011, nor do I support this stimulus package, because I am not in favour of a transfer union at all. I would like us to stand on our own two feet in this Europe and we will be stronger. I would also like to know, or rather ask, why and by whose order the following sentence was removed from the Commission's information pages: the EU must not finance its budget through borrowing. This sentence referred to Article 310. This phrase was still on the Commission's fact sheet in May 2020. Does this mystical loss of phrase mean that now, suddenly, the EU budget can be financed by borrowing?

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RRF) is a crucial part of the EU’s response to the economic shock caused by the pandemic. It is already a historic achievement in at least three aspects: first, the amount of money it will mobilise; second, the way it will be financed through common debt; and third, the priorities it will have to concentrate on, mainly relating to the climate and the digital transition, but also social cohesion and resilience. However, we need to make these funds a success also in another aspect: in their implementation and execution. And for this it is imperative that projects financed by the facility address structural deficits and bring about real transformation of our economies, that in the private sector SMEs can also become the beneficiaries of these funds and sub-state governments, having first-hand information on the needs of their economies and territories, get involved in the whole cycle of decision-making and governance of the investment plans. The recovery and transformation of some of our economies may largely rely on the smooth execution of these funds.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, we are talking about spending a lot of money: EUR 750 billion. But maybe I can say it: that money is not there yet. The ratification of the aid fund is carried out through the national parliaments of 27 Member States. Most countries have a two-chamber system, so we have more than 50 parliaments. The German Bundestag must pay attention. The EU has a lot of power. There is a Gestaltwandel, a transformation of the EU towards the federal state. That could raise the German hurdle to the requirement of a two-thirds majority in the Bundestag.  Also pay attention to the Netherlands. The Senate is not cheering on another round of transfers. There are elections for the House of Representatives on 17 March and public opinion does not like this proposal. So, Mr. Commissioner, don't cheer too soon. You're not there yet.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, COVID has been an unprecedented crisis both in Europe and worldwide. Its impact on the economy and well-being will be long-lasting and large. It is good that, in this exceptional situation, the EU was able to find this exceptional solution. Exceptional times need exceptional means. While the package does not cover all the costs or impacts of COVID, it will bring stability and reliability to the European Economic Area and will hopefully give people faith in the future. And most importantly, there are criteria for spending money that contribute to the goals and challenges that we would face, regardless of COVID. It is important that RRF includes earmarked money for climate, climate work and digitalisation. If the recovery billions are spent in accordance with the principles of the Green Deal, we can succeed in accelerating the transition towards a carbon-neutral society, but the real costs and effects of the virus will only be seen in the coming years when the full impact of COVID on welfare becomes visible. That is why, in the years to come, we will have to strengthen the social dimension even more so that this crisis does not unduly increase inequality.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Madam President, Spain ranks first in COVID victims, but it ranks last in government support to small businesses and self-employed workers. Without support, thousands will go bankrupt, but the Spanish Government has increased the budget for the king and for the army, and has no plans for struggling businesses.  Spain will be the top beneficiary of the recovery fund. Will they invest this money wisely? Well, the government has set up an allocation scheme, tailor—made to benefit the big IBEX 35 Spanish corporations. Spanish crony capitalism periodically threatens the stability of the eurozone. A decade ago, taxpayers rescued banks that never paid back. And once again, now the Spanish oligarchy is ready to take the money – the European taxpayers’ money – and run, with the permission of the Commission! Mr Commissioner, your protection of Spanish malpractice is dragging the Europeans into the mud. Last week’s embarrassment in Moscow with Mr Borrell was just a first taste.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This crisis is not a good time for Community solutions. The drama of the situation prompts rapid intergovernmental responses, which puts Parliament in a difficult position. This was the case during the financial crisis, when various rescue mechanisms were created ad hoc, which over time turned into a sustainable European Stability Mechanism. And so it is now.  This recovery and resilience facility, which is the backbone of the recovery plan, was an intergovernmental undertaking on its pedigree. Siegfried Mureşan and others have undertaken a difficult mission to communize what is intergovernmental. In my opinion, they have achieved the maximum possible by turning Parliament's ex post control into supervision of the various stages of the implementation of this programme. It is said that this is the Hamiltonian moment in European integration, paying attention to the communitriality of debt. Only that the communitarity of debt was already there, as Valdis Dombrovskis, who used the balance of payments facility during the financial crisis, knows well. The scale of this project is extraordinary. But you have to look at the other side of the budget, which is your own income, because it can be a lasting legacy of this program. And it will determine that this will not be a burden, but an achievement for future generations of Europeans.  One more thing: this programme, which is a great gesture of European solidarity, in countries that are authoritarian, can turn into favouring its own with unfair treatment of those who stand up for European values.

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: – Mr President, the Recovery and Resilience Facility is not only a way to address the effects of the COVID crisis, but a great leap forward towards a closer and deeper union. It complements the action of the European Central Bank and partially overcomes the lack of a common European fiscal capacity for the time being. However, we would be wrong to consider this facility as the final destination of our journey. This is just the beginning. Full recovery will require time, energy, commitment and a great sense of responsibility. In order to succeed, new forms of dialogue and interaction, solidarity and mutual understanding are required. Now, more than ever, it’s clear that having a solely national perspective for economic and budgetary measures is not only pretentious, but is short-sighted and inefficient. So a truly European approach is the only way to foster territorial cohesion, to fight social inequalities, and to support policies dedicated to the next generation of Europeans. As a Parliament, over the next years, we will be vigilant to ensure that the Commission carries out the tasks assigned in appropriate ways so that the facility reaches its objectives, especially in terms of digital and environmental transformation, social impact and the Next Generation policies that we have envisaged for the Union. It will not be easy. There will be bumps along the road and divisive forces will always be around the corner, and we got a sample from the debate this morning. So I say to my colleagues that we have created a powerful instrument for unity and solidarity. Now it’s our responsibility to make sure that what was conceived to unite us will not end up dividing us.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very good one. Today we are discussing the Resilience Facility, the European response to our economic crisis.
