We need to make sure that we can get into the future in a truly innovative, stronger and, above all, bolder way. This is not just about spending the money on the right priorities, but also about getting proper reforms in all the Member States. After all, everyone must do their homework so that together we can get more out of this crisis.  When I look at my own country, the Federal Government still sees itself as an economic policy teacher in Europe and now has to sit down itself, because the Commission is calling for further reforms, and that is exactly what is right. I call on the Commission to remain tough. Also on the question of Hungary. I now see that the Commission has called for the regulation of public procurement to be amended in order to finally change systematic fraud – and that is also true.  One last thought. In addition to the RFF, vaccination should have been a greater priority in Europe. We should have invested more and faster in production capacity. The faster we get out of the crisis by vaccinating, the better for the economy and society.

name: France JAMET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, the pandemic crisis has dramatically aggravated the already salient economic difficulties of the European peoples, making clear and strong action essential to support the economy. No one's arguing. Taking action is imperative.  However, the need for action must not obscure the content on which we are expected to vote today. The resilience facility, which aims to have EUR 672 billion as part of the European recovery plan, reveals many uncertainties and shortcomings.  Europe has been merged for too long in this logic of perpetual over-indebtedness. As soon as a crisis arises, we accumulate and accumulate billions of euros of new debts without ever asking ourselves the question of repayment, or almost. Some are pushing back to tomorrow, some would simply like to cancel these debts, as if there were a magic money that could be made appear or disappear, depending on the inclination of the moment. But debt is only a deferred tax.  Some talk about own resources. That means a new tax. By using this EUR 672 billion, we must first and foremost think of our children and grandchildren tomorrow. And to our retirees today, who will try to make the bill pay.  More than ever, we need to change this stateless globalist model that is trashing our economies. We must reintroduce national sovereignty in our economic model in order to restore a real local economic fabric, solid, capable of withstanding the health crises as well as the follies of financial capitalism that kills real entrepreneurs and the real creators of jobs and wealth.  More than ever, to stop this flight forward, the solution lies in the nation, led by lucid and responsible leaders.

name: Alexandra GEESE
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which The Reconstruction Fund shows that Europe is strong when it stands together in solidarity and moves forward.  This fund invests in the green transformation and in the digitalisation of Europe. And that's right. Unfortunately, however, one thing has been forgotten in the basic architecture of this stimulus package: half of the population, who do most of the unpaid work, especially in closed daycare centres and schools, which holds our society together in this serious crisis and which pays the highest price for the crisis. In Italy, the largest recipient of the stimulus package, 70 percent of people who lost their jobs in the crisis are women. The stimulus package, however, invests the majority in sectors in which almost only men work. This is not only absurd and unjust, it is also not economically effective. And it is good that the Commission has now followed up and enshrined gender equality in all priorities. Because a successful economy and strong social cohesion will only exist with women.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you very much for The fight for funds for the reconstruction fund took a very long time, because basically since the spring of the previous year. We hope that it will be a success, although we have already heard voices in this House that some parliaments may not approve this fund and that the funds for the reconstruction of the European economy are really badly needed.  Preliminary Eurostat data show that gdp growth for the whole of 2020 was as high as 8%. There are countries where this decrease will be greater than 10%. Perhaps the first two quarters of this year will also end in recession. I would like the reconstruction fund to be allocated as soon as possible and transferred to the Member States. Let us hope that this will happen in the second half of this year. It is a good idea to be able to reimburse the expenditure incurred by the Member States. Indeed, if it were not for these expenditures, the economic situation would probably be worse. My country has allocated close to 10% of GDP for this purpose with good results.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, the Recovery Fund that we are adopting today is a positive step. The Greek MEPs on the left support it, although we consider it to be totally inadequate. We support this because the issue of a common debt by the 27 guaranteed by the Commission implements — albeit with a long delay — the positive proposal for Eurobonds. We support it because the EUR 390 billion that has been set up by the European Investment Bank (EIB) will be used to support the development of the European Union. This is a serious step towards transfer payments. It is, however, completely inadequate because it was designed almost a year ago and in the meantime the intensity and duration of the pandemic, the scale of the crisis and recession require more drastic additional measures.  The Eurogroup on the left is calling for the Recovery Fund funds to be doubled from EUR 750 billion to EUR 750 billion. at 1.5 trillion. In order to really have a European 'bazooka'. Extend the suspension of the Stability Pact until 2023 and replace it with a realistic convergence and sustainable development pact. European debt relief and accelerating the implementation of national plans to get this money out of the way, away from customer networks and corruption. This money does not belong to governments and parties; it belongs to peoples and societies.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: - Dear Chairman, Europe made a mistake in the crisis of 2008. That's what she admitted after all. Unfortunately, Europe has also taken a wrong approach to this crisis. More than half of medium and small enterprises employing more than two thirds of employees are expected to be bankrupt by the end of the year.  The restrictive measures and lockdown that have been introduced across Europe have a very lean scientific background. Political power centers made these decisions and blindly followed the World Health Organization.  It was politics that decided to use masks. Politics has decided there's no flu testing, so for the first time in decades, we don't have the flu simply. The policy decided to use unreliable PCR tests. Politics decided there were no autopsies after death. Because why should people, like all the years so far, die of heart, cancer and even the flu itself when it can all be beautifully crossed off into the corona. Everything was done to get the numbers that wanted to be obtained. And now comes the Commission here with some kind of economic measures as a savior, and when will they admit more of their mistake?

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism is at the heart of our economic recovery. Our responsibility is great and here we will be to monitor the implementation and scrutinize it. It is now up to the Member States to do their part and apply the resources quickly, competently and transparently.  The great challenge of public health is the containment of the pandemic. The great challenge of recovery is the transformation of this plan into concrete results. But just as the mess in the vaccination plans of some Member States is incomprehensible, any slouch or negligence in implementing this mechanism will be unacceptable.  Over the past year, we have learned that the time of the pandemic goes beyond the time of politics. It's time to reverse the trend and trade your ads for solutions. Europeans do not need the propaganda of their governments, but answers. They do not need captives, but investments made. They need no excuses, but transparency in the implementation of the funds. They do not need money to be spent on bureaucracies, but from their arrival in the real economy: to families and businesses. What the many entrepreneurs and workers who have endured to this day the European social state need is that it does not fail them now and will allow them to rebuild their life, their business and thus contribute to a more smiling future for all.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Amiga Ana Paula Zacarias, Vice-President Dombrovskis, the Multiannual Financial Framework and next generation EU are essential pillars of the European response to an unprecedented crisis, because of its size and because they are based on the basic principle of European solidarity, a principle that presides over the issuance of european common debt, that is, the mutualisation of this debt. An effort by all in a decisive step in the history of Europe. The recovery and resilience mechanism is a unique opportunity to promote real change by enabling the European Union and all Member States to get out of this crisis with stronger, more cohesive, more egalitarian economies. A shift to a green and sustainable transition, based on a digital transformation of citizens and businesses. But complementarity is required to do so: complementarity with the National Reform Plans, complementarity with the Eu budget, the Structural Funds for Horizon Europe, InvestEU, or the EU4Health Health programme.  Together, all these instruments are the key to change. It is therefore indeferred that the next generation EU national parliaments will be ratified to have a fund, but it is also indeferred that partnerships between the European Commission and the Member States work to facilitate the adoption of national economic and social recovery plans. Its rapid approval and good implementation is the urgency of recovery. Let's all do our part.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, I welcome the debate on the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and there is no doubt the pandemic has caused untold damage to economies across the European Union. So this particular facility is very welcome and I hope it’s ratified by Member States and that it will have a meaningful impact in the key areas, the environment, climate and digitisation of our economies. But the significant challenge, of course, will be how we will decide in the next couple of years regarding the Stability and Growth Pact and the review that it’s going through. The fact of the matter is we’ve suspended it at the present time so countries are able to access funding that, in the event of the Stability and Growth Pact being brought back with the very strict criteria that underpin it, it could have a very damaging effect on individual Member States and destabilise. So, clearly, I would suggest that over the next number of months, the review of the Stability and Growth Pact takes into account the new challenges ahead of us in the time and not looking back retrospectively as well. The other key area, of course, is we do need to have a very mature debate in this Parliament across all Member States with regard to the issue of own resources if we are to ensure that this fund is underpinned with genuine funding capabilities into the future.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We are talking today about the Building and Resilience Fund and the Facility. But the word facility awakens bad memories for me.  Remember: ten years ago, we in this House also voted on another facility. At the time, this European financing facility was at stake. This stability facility is not necessarily a confidence-inspiring factor when it comes to setting up a new facility now. And for me, this is a huge problem: if things were going so badly back then, why should things be better today?  Incidentally, we can see that, for example, when it comes to spending money, we still have EUR 300 billion left over, which has not yet been spent from the last MFF. And now you think that with 670 billion new money, we can now spend more and spend better? The money will take long, long years to reach the recipients. But we need help immediately. How do you intend to do that? And at the latest, when the citizens realise that they cannot eat these bonds, they will notice that something has gone completely wrong here.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank my colleagues who have been working on getting this recovery funding getting to a really credible European investment programme that we have been fighting for in this Parliament for a very long while. So I think that is really good, and it is also true that thanks to Parliament there is now credible greening and investment in digitalisation which was not the case beforehand.  But now the real work starts. It’s about the implementation. And here really to the Portuguese Presidency: you have been fighting for a credible European investment programme. It’s now in the hands of the Member States to deliver credible national recovery plans, and really this needs to be done in full transparency. This needs to be under public scrutiny to really see that these are really true investments and not just repackaging of money. And this is also to the Commission: when you are judging it, do it in transparency, don’t do this behind closed doors which is ongoing right now.  And then the last point. This is about European investment money, but we all know the real investments are still at the national level, thousands of billions of euros. Let’s make sure that goes in the right direction as well, otherwise this European investment fund will not deliver enough.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I am pleased that the subject of our deliberations is a concrete programme to help Europe, not another project for its ideological reconstruction. The European Instrument for Reconstruction and Resilience (EUR 672 billion for Europe) is the result of joint arduous negotiations and hard work bringing together the interests of all Member States. But is it sufficient and fair? The need to involve huge common funds to invest in the green transition, which must be seen throughout Europe in the long term as a common important policy measure of the European Union, is in question. It is important that The Member States have different starting points and development points, and today, in common solidarity, we need to understand what investments and reforms they need, creating national recovery plans as europe's individual economies.  Poland needs funding in transmission and distribution infrastructure. Today, Poland needs gas-based electricity and heat production as a necessary transitional solution for common climate targets. Instead of bureaucracy, I urge you to focus on the real needs of each Member State.

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: – I am convinced that Europe and my country, Hungary, have won several times by the birth of the economic recovery fund after more than six months of hard battles. Firstly, because the Polish and Hungarian governments resisted incredibly strong pressure, it exercised its right under the Treaties, thus preventing political ideological disputes from being decided by deprivation of resources. All the citizens of Europe have won by not being added to the EU toolbox. The rule of law is more important to them than letting some people abuse it. Secondly, the Union has shown that it can learn from the mistakes of the previous crisis management. There is no growth by austerity, by making it impossible for workers, SMEs, families.  We have been carrying a work-based economy and many old family policies for years, creating jobs through investment and structural reforms. There is currently a social dialogue at home in which citizens express their views on development plans. Thirdly, this instrument is a chance for Europe to be competitive again. The goal is not to get back to business as normal, but to take on the competition. Hungary partner in europe's finally environmentally and economically sustainable path to be on the digital scene. If we miss this now, the european welfare way envied everywhere will be known to our grandchildren only by reputation. It is our shared responsibility to spend the funds efficiently and with every penny counted. I call on the Commission to help Member States adopt individual considerations.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have an urgency at the moment: to get the resources of the Recovery and Resilience Facility to the real economy, to workers, to businesses, as soon as possible and without delay.  Europe has been able to give an unprecedented response to an unprecedented crisis and has shown that it is not only a large internal market but a community of destiny, a community of solidarity. For the first time we have a common and common debt issue are the objectives to be achieved in order to start again.  This fund will be a success if we do not waste resources on past-oriented expenditure, but we will really be able to direct them towards the economy of the future. We have the opportunity to make this dramatic crisis an opportunity to radically change the pattern of development and growth and to make it more person-friendly, fairer, socially and environmentally sustainable.  These are the only real conditionalities that we will all have to look at and we will have to put aside instead the macroeconomic ones of the austerity season, which we believe have finally passed, and we will work to ensure that the rules that still concern them also change and take into account the new reality that we have before us.

name: Ondřej KOVAŘÍK
text: – Mr President, Vice-President of the Commission, the European Union recovery plan represents a significant boost to the recovery of the economy and to deal with the consequences of the pandemic. However, we must launch it as soon as possible and focus on both the sectors most affected and – from a future point of view – strategic areas. For example, for the Czech Republic, this plan means an injection of over CZK 180 billion in direct payments and another hundreds of billions in possible loans. These funds will enable us to invest more where we need it most, e.g. to accelerate digitalisation, both in the public and private sectors, to help modernise the economy, to promote competitiveness, to support small and medium-sized enterprises so that they can get back on their feet and develop further. As we have seen in this crisis, there is also a need to invest in health and, among other things, in modernising transport and infrastructure. The European plan has the potential to accelerate its return to pre-crisis levels and to strengthen our economy overall, and we should seize this opportunity.

name: Jean-Lin LACAPELLE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many outliers in the European recovery plan in support of our businesses. Aberrants first by what is there. First, an indigestible and unfair financial distribution key through which the largest contributors, including France, will receive less than they give.  Secondly, the vile Article 9 bis, which links the benefit of the recovery plan to respect for the rule of law and the fundamental values of the Union, is a real ideological and financial blackmail.  Thirdly, an obligation for states to prepare national plans for recovery and resilience over four years that apply the orders of the European Semester, a genuine European super-statism.  Fourth, a crazy obligation to spend at least 60% of the amount on climate and digital for each project.  Finally, an extensive yet illegitimate competence for OLAF and the European Public Prosecutor's Office to carry out investigations, i.e., in practice, their control over the finances of the Member States.  On the other hand, this stimulus package is also aberrant because what is missing from it. In fact, this $724 billion will be allocated to the pursuit of the European Union's priorities, when it is because of it that we have been so hard hit. Nothing about relocations, yet promised. Nothing about the national management of strategic industries. Nothing about sovereignty and autonomy.  On the contrary, the report calls for ever more integration. The European Union has definitely not learned any lessons from either the health crisis or our logistical dependence. She was incompetent in the supply of masks, incompetent in the acquisition of tests, incompetent in the management of medical protective equipment, incompetent, finally, in the negotiation and delivery of vaccines.  The European Union dreamed of a great Europe of health. In the end, it was a Europe of fiasco that she presented to us. However, it is through industrial independence and the control of our production lines that we will achieve strength and solidity. There's still time.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: Mr President, we have been discussing public funds for months, which we need to mobilise in an indispensable way to respond to the economic and social crisis that is hitting us. Let us not forget, however, that this crisis is systemic and ecological in origin. It stems from the damage to biodiversity, which is the great sacrifice of this agreement. We need to reorient our economy to ensure both social justice and the protection of our planet. However, the rules we have adopted to frame this stimulus package do not respond to this urgency. On the contrary, the conditions associated with the European Semester are unfair and will be painful in the future. Once again, the long term is sacrificed to the interests of the short term. On the other hand, we do not yet have any guarantee that undated climate funds will not impede the transition. We are told of a safety net, taxonomy, which is fragile because it is weakened by lobbies. According to the High Council for Climate Change, in France, for example, two-thirds of the French recovery plan will boost the economy of the past. Finally, a call: let us study and condition our recovery plans to their impact on the poorest 10%. They are the first to be hit by the crisis. So let's be bold and take this initiative today.

name: Jessica STEGRUD
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr After 25 years in business, I wish I could say that the current indebtedness of future generations will lead to competitiveness, innovation, long-term growth and future prosperity. But is this really what the money goes to? I doubt it. Because in Spain, citizens' pay has been introduced and proposals have been made to reduce the number of days in a working week to four. In France, money is spent on maintaining an unreasonably low retirement age, and in Italy there are plans for tax cuts but no fiscal consolidation. All this while the Swedish entrepreneur gets to see his life's work go down. The Swedish worker has to work longer and longer, pay more and more in taxes and increasingly end his life as a poor pensioner. For someone has to pay, and as usual, the Swedes, with the help of the other Swedish parliamentary parties, draw the short straw. The EU has become a grant union and Sweden is allowed to continue to act as an ATM. It's not sustainable.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the recovery plan that Europe is conceiving, we are playing a new beginning. A new beginning that has for us Italians, for my country of origin, as the first chapter the name of Mario Draghi, commissioned by the President of the Republic to build this attempt for a country so affected. It is a restructuring of the economic and political paradigm that we are preparing for. The parties, all parties, have found themselves forced to play in logic, in the hope of a Europe that will once again become a global power. And that's the advantage we can bring to everyone. Reforms combined with resources, so that after the pandemic this continent is a continent that proceeds at a different pace than before, where the rules bend to the logic of growth.  So let's not waste opportunities, let's not talk about Green Deal as if it were a moralistic extravagance to bring back to a community that has already accepted that challenge. We use this as a tool to bring European industrial excellence to the world in the field of sustainability. In short, a recovery plan which allows us not to be content with being called a Union of States, but which recovers us in the spirit of the Community of European peoples.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: – Mr President, the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism is our chance to get through the current crisis. That is why we have allocated 20% for digital transformation and 37% for the environment area, but the European Parliament has called for more. We have asked for 10% for education, because without education we cannot talk about a long-term vision, and 2% for the cultural and creative sector, which is badly affected by the crisis.  We need more ambition. Recovery plans must be carried out transparently, not politicised, respond to the reform requirements set out in the country reports and be the result of extensive, thoroughly organised public consultations.  Unfortunately, there are governments, such as the one in Romania, that prefer not to listen to European recommendations. The European Parliament must be involved in the implementation of these plans in order for European money to reach the beneficial owners. I propose the creation of a control mechanism at European level to ensure the fairness and transparency of the implementation of recovery plans.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Mr President, the temporary corona fund: this has rightly been negotiated for a long time. And yes, also by the Netherlands. Because in order to deal with economic problems with the distribution of more and more subsidies, no, I do not believe in that. What I do believe in is in implementing necessary and structural reforms.  As far as I am concerned, the agreement that is now on the table is balanced, appropriate and proportionate. It also does justice to the crisis in which many people and businesses are in. These European loans and subsidies for recovery are accompanied by strict conditions. Member States simply need to implement sensible reforms, but also think about the digital and green transition. These recovery plans should fulfil the recommendations of the European Semester. Simply because we must now focus on this resilient European economy. Then I think of investments in clean fuels: hydrogen, synthetic kerosene. Mr President, let us take a hit tonight, but let us agree that we are critically monitoring this fund's investment in Europe's earning power.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The joint reconstruction fund for Europe's Corona crisis is a huge opportunity. This is the first time that Europe has responded to a major crisis with such a show of solidarity. 750 billion euros financed by joint bonds, 57 percent of the money in climate protection and digitalization. These are the right priorities. But it is all the more disappointing that in Germany the corresponding programme, at least EUR 22 billion, is to be spent mainly on political recycling. Three-quarters of the money in Germany is to go to projects that the Federal Government had already intended. And all this only in order not to give the states and municipalities access to this money and simply to record it in the federal budget. Hence my request to the EU Commission and the Federal Government: change this plan. Make sure that regional investment is also accessible and not mainly made easy, as was already planned.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Mr President, the deadline for final submission of national recovery and resilience plans to the European Commission is approaching, but national plans have not yet been published in several Member States. I have therefore turned to the Commission with a parliamentary question as to whether, therefore, it will make these plans public when they are submitted to it. The Commission replied that it did not intend to do so. I believe that the Commission should publish not only these plans, but also its evaluation. Not because it should be a competition between Member States for a kind of European Cup, but because we want all of these plans to be good. And also so that countries can inspire each other with good reforms that are repayable, even economically viable.

name: Angelika WINZIG
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. From the outset, I was enthusiastic about the PPE-DE idea of living European solidarity and setting up a pandemic fund to serve our Member States.  After the Second World War, my country was also successfully helped by the Marshall Plan. But when I saw the proposals of the parties on the left of the centre, I was slightly irritated. Only grants, no loans, without conditionality and control. This would certainly lead to abuse and not lead to a sustainable Europe. I would therefore like to thank our colleague Siegfried Mure'an in particular for his excellent design of this programme.  The link between this Reconstruction Fund and the European Semester will create sound economic governance. Clearly defined areas of application, the involvement of Parliament in review and evaluation will protect against abuse.  Yes, our Member States are now in an exciting competition of the best ideas. You now have to come up with an ambitious program – lighthouses instead of plugging holes. Investments in research, development and digitalisation as prerequisites for climate protection will certainly be the focus here too. However, the competitiveness of our businesses also plays a major role, because only women entrepreneurs create jobs, and we need them in this period in a very, special way. That is why a job initiative must be at the heart of this "..." (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: "We've done a great thing," he said. Politicians and government MPs from all over Europe have joined forces to create the largest financial fund in European history. Moreover, the reconstruction fund set up in the middle of the crisis is about the future. We wanted not only to heal our wounds, but to help the Europe of the twenty-first century. Therefore, there is no government, no member of parliament, no politician who can decide what a country needs in the twenty-first century without hearing from civilians, municipalities, people. That's why a government that doesn't listen to people, which is doing the consultation that's playing tricks on dialogue, believe me, that government just wants to steal. And I appeal to the Commission: in this case, this money must be directed directly to municipalities and civilians.

name: Engin EROGLU
text: Mr President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work. The budget must be balanced in revenue and expenditure under Article 310 of the EU Treaties. Overnight, this central pillar for the EU's prosperity and sustainability will simply be ignored. For the first time, the EU will be making debts in the broad sense. It is always easier to take on debt, to spend foreign money or to solve the EU's problems. It is the case that the arguments have been exchanged here in the last two hours and, in my view, the path of least resistance is being taken. Of course, everyone who benefits from this EUR 670 billion will also agree today. This is in the sense of nature. However, it is also in the interests of nature that many people in this House believe and hope that this money will be handled well in the Member States, so to speak. And that is where the misconception lies. What has not worked in recent decades will not work in the coming year either. I will not be able to vote in favour today, because today we are robbing the ability of future generations in this House to act.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Mr President, in Europe, in the EU, we mourn half a million deaths from COVID and 20 million cases. But as we grieve, we look to a recovery with decent jobs, clean air and climate action at its heart. EUR 250 billion is in place to finance the social and green recovery. That’s a lot of money. But as Chief Brody said in Jaws, you’re going to need a bigger boat. The RRF is that boat and we may need a bigger one. Funding the renovation wave is crucial by retrofitting our public housing with insulation and ventilation. We want cosy homes, lower energy bills, a sense of hygge. On transport, we should boost bus and rail, modernising and electrifying. Public transport is invaluable to our citizens and cannot become a victim of the pandemic. Walking and cycling must also be funded. We need to be active and these modes clean the air, improve road safety and take pressure off our health services. A real win—win. In conclusion, from the rue de la Loi in Brussels to the quays of the River Liffey in Dublin, we can and we must make our cities greener, cleaner and safer for all.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have strongly supported the need for common indebtedness to deal with the emergency. Yet, over the months, what was supposed to be a recovery plan has become something different. It is too long, despite the fact that Parliament's advance is positive, that the loan component is overburded in relation to appropriations, that it is uncertainty about own resources, that it risks turning into new direct or indirect taxes on European citizens and businesses, that the Commission has too much discretion over the so-called structural reforms required of each nation, and finally this regulation, which risks bringing back through the window the rules of austerity that everyone had boasted of having thrown out the door only a few months ago.  And looking at Italy, the main beneficiary of this instrument, the risk is that even the highly esteemed Professor Draghi, let alone his colorful political majority, is not enough to protect us from these dangers. For these reasons, we will abstain and continue to monitor without discounts.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, on reading the first plans that have reached us, in 'easy for recovery and resilience', some Member States have used the word 'easy', there is no doubt about it, but recovery and resilience are not there. It is easy, in particular, to avoid calling on local or regional entities, or for citizens to take full part in this stimulus fund. It is easy, too, in recycling files that were already planned and which do not correspond - at least at first reading - to the reality of what was set by both Parliament and the Commission. It is simply easy, in the end, to do a bit like before, or worse, when you take certain files or projects that concern, for example, a courthouse that you want to renovate. So, yes, there is an urgent need to reframe all member states through the objectives we have set at Parliament and At The Commission level, to ensure that this stimulus fund can be used for employment, for young people, for all those who are now in despair, to effectively offer them a different world and for Europe to finally be , for all European citizens, hope and well-being.

name: Isabel GARCÍA MUÑOZ
text: – Mr President, the greatest mobilisation of funds that the European Union has ever made available to Member States needs to go hand in hand with the protection of financial interests during its implementation. Parliament has also succeeded in meeting this requirement. The rule of law is a condition for access to funding. A parliamentary accountability and control mechanism has been introduced with a specific discharge procedure. Member States should ensure effective internal controls capable of recovering amounts paid or misused. In addition, full transparency is ensured, with the final recipients of funding known, and we must not forget the continued work of the Court of Auditors, OLAF and the new European Public Prosecutor's Office, so to put the lack of control as an excuse not to support the action of governments with their national plans makes no sense. It is time to be constructive, to work together, governments and oppositions, because if governments are supported on this, the Government is not saved, citizens are thought of and the reconstruction of Europe, as we have done in Parliament. Congratulations to the speakers on the great work.

name: Fabienne KELLER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, the ease of recovery and resilience is a major lever to help Member States in the face of the crisis, to promote the European rebound in a dynamic of solidarity.  We are now adopting the rules to finance national plans. In December, we voted in Parliament on a regulation aimed at protecting the EU budget and the recovery plan in the event of a widespread failure of the rule of law. The rule is simple: no European funds if a state does not respect the fundamental principles of democracy, independence, justice or media freedom. This is a major step forward for Europe, which protects its values. It is essential that this rule be applied without delay.  Can the Commission confirm that it is doing everything possible to ensure the implementation of the regulation as adopted by Parliament and the Council, despite the Council's statement obtained by the countries most concerned and without responding to the pressures still exerted by those same countries?  Respect for the rule of law is no longer negotiable. As the guardian of the treaties, we expect the Commission to ensure the implementation of a major achievement of European integration.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr With europe's emergency package now, we are getting a huge billion-dollar roll, for which we really all must jointly take full responsibility – that these huge resources are being used for the right things. We also get the chance, the opportunity, to put in a much, much higher gear in the work on climate change for the whole of Europe. After all, we must achieve a fair and equal recovery now after the pandemic, really with a focus on creating sustainable jobs. We all know how great the investment needs are. We need more renewable energy, new railways, more charging posts. That list would be possible to make as long as you like. Major investments are really needed to achieve climate objectives. This is the time to make these investments and invest in the solutions needed to create a sustainable, fairer and more climate-friendly future in our societies. Let's take that chance!

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, COVID-19 continues to steal thousands of lives every day, and Europeans see their businesses shut down, lose their jobs and live in uncertainty that needs a quick and effective response. That answer is what we are voting on today: the Resilience and Resilience Mechanism. European funds offer a future opportunity for our young people, in the face of anti-European discourses that speak of the end of a model. It is an unprecedented economic injection to create millions of jobs, reactivate our productive fabric and strengthen our health systems. It is the answer to building a more competitive Europe that is committed to sustainable growth and digitisation and that supports its self-employed people and SMEs.  These funds belong to the Europeans, to all Spaniards. They are not owned by any government or ideology. We will not allow populist governments to use them to waste without control, creating client networks and finger-to-finger adjudicating them.  These funds are for creating employment, employment and more employment, and must therefore be divided with transparent criteria, pursuing territorial and social cohesion, involving in the process all autonomous communities, all town halls, the economic sectors and the national Parliament.  That is why Parliament is right today to require two-month national reform plans. We will be monitoring for funds to reach all Europeans, to real Europe. We'll be watching so not a single euro is wasted.

name: Paul TANG
text: Mr President, the recovery fund is an expression of European solidarity, of mutual support at the time when it is most needed. In solidarity, rights and obligations go hand in hand, and therefore there are conditions.  Firstly, there is a duty to spend public money well, to propping up, renewing, sustainability. The standards for sustainability are there and will come, and Parliament will help the Commission to ensure that this is strictly increased.  Secondly, there is a duty not to lurk. That may sound strange, and yet it is being violated by countries such as Luxembourg and the Netherlands: by facilitating tax avoidance, thereby draining funds for aid. So do not let Dutch politics complain about the hole in other people's hands, as long as the richest have the opportunity to spend their untaxed income on the proverbial drink and women, as long as the richest do not contribute fairly to the recovery so desperately needed for their own and European economies.

name: Martin HOJSÍK
text: – Mr President, sometimes I feel that many governments see money from the recovery plan and resilience as prey that they can share according to the election result. As the Slovak Prime Minister is unfortunately talking about it. First of all, it's not just about the money. It is about the reforms that are necessary to manage the biodiversity and climate crisis, about a just transition to a circular and digital economy. Not about spending, but about investing in the future, responsible for the planet and for the people, for the benefit of all, not just our people, as it is said in Slovakia. For the benefit of the young, who will bear the burden of the climate crisis, for which they cannot, and therefore must not go into fossil fuels and the destruction of nature. The preparation of the recovery plan must be about involving the public, towns and villages, non-government, but also companies. Not just about PR, but about real debate. We in the European Parliament have an important task ahead of us, to scrutinise. We must look and look at the Commission, but also individual countries, on our fingers and act. Recovery and resilience really need to be about the next generation, green, digital and fair. This is not a time to divide prey, but to help people and the planet.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the What does the EU bring to the people of Europe? Today, in plenary, we have an impressive answer: the EU has put the biggest stimulus package in the history of the EU on the table in the face of the Corona crisis and economic challenges. And through the RRF Building and Resilience Facility, at least 37 percent of the funds will go to climate protection and at least 20 percent to digital transformation. What is ecological determines taxonomy, and no investment project must affect the EU's environmental objectives. This is a green success! The RRF means EUR 672.5 billion financed in solidarity. And this is also a great European success of solidarity. What is missing is the European Parliament's co-determination on the national RRF plans and green bonds. And it's still much greener. And yet, the RRF is a constructive response to the Corona crisis and to the climate crisis. This is because we are accelerating the green transformation of our economy and industry in order to achieve the Paris climate goals. And this is a European ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, the consequences of the health, economic and social crisis caused by the pandemic are much more severe, deeper and longer than we had hoped for a year ago. And the year ahead is still fraught with uncertainty for millions of families across Europe.  In record time, a safe and effective vaccine has been provided as well as a package of common European recovery. However, this in itself is by no means enough. Now it is the turn of the implementation that will be the key to the recovery and that will determine Europe's position in the world after the global pandemic.  Digital transformation and long-term sustainability are not a question of choice today but a necessity. Therefore, if we want to be relevant in the long term, but also if we want to be an actor in creating standards of a digital society that will also be based on our European values, it is necessary to make good use of 20 percent of the funds earmarked for the digital transition. The unprecedented crisis is also a time of historic decisions for a new generation Europe. €673 billion of recovery and resilience instruments must be used efficiently, responsibly and to create added value.  We have a tremendous opportunity ahead of us that we must not miss. For the recovery of the European economy, for the recovery of European society and for the recovery of European life.

name: Nils UŠAKOVS
text: – Mr President, Europe has gone through a dramatic process of finding solutions to the largest crisis we have faced since the end of the Second World War. It has required great effort from the European institutions and European leaders to show historic unity. As a result, the Recovery and Resilience Facility (RFF) can become a plan providing unprecedented financial support. EU Member States will have the unique opportunity both to lead their countries and nations out of depression and to advance their economies in environmental, digital, social and employment terms.  We cannot fail this opportunity. Unfortunately, there are many ways to fail. Let’s take one example. An EU Member State government is planning to spend EUR 2 million from the RFF on creating a digital tool for long—term forecasts for a social insurance system. It’s probably a great and fantastic project itself, but it has nothing to do with either the COVID crisis or with recovery or resilience. It is just a project taken from a shelf at one of the ministries, which can be tagged as digital and sent as an application for guaranteed EU money. That was one particular example from the government I know best, but we can presume that there is definitely not going to be only one project like this across the Union. There will be hundreds and thousands of projects like this, applying for hundreds of millions of euros from the fund.  This is exactly how the Recovery and Resilience Facility plan should not work. We need to rebuild our economies, not to finance doing business as usual. The RRF is designed for the long—term goals of the continent: to serve them, not to serve the short—term goals of the governments. It is really great news that the European Parliament will be involved in all stages, from the preparation of national plans to their evaluation, approval and implementation. Controlling the functioning of the fund should become a crucial task for this House immediately after establishing the Recovery and Resilience Facility.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Mr President, this Parliament fought for and delivered legal guarantees for the protection of our historic recovery fund so that taxpayers’ money does not get diverted by corruption. So that this time, it’s not Viktor Orbán’s son-in-law scooping up these funds. One of these guarantees was that Member States must involve local authorities, because people on the ground need to have a say in how this money is being spent.  A colleague of mine is deputy mayor in charge of development for Szeged, the third largest city in Hungary. Up until this day, he has not seen any meaningful documentation, let alone been consulted, about the needs of his constituents, and mayors all across Hungary tell us just the same. Budapest is in urgent need of funds for zero-emission transport development and there are recovery funds for that, but they are not being consulted. So how does this square with the legal obligation to involve local stakeholders? How can the Commission make sure that Member States do not breach their obligations to consult? Citizens of Szeged, Budapest, Hungary and communities all across Europe deserve an answer for that.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Mr President, the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism is one of our great weapons as a Europe against the economic recession caused — and continues to cause — by the coronavirus pandemic. But it is not just planning that is enough. We need to accelerate; we need to throw hot money into the market now. Unemployment is constantly rising and economic indicators tend to get worse by the day. Extra resources as new money are more important than ever to have targeted interventions to launch investments to maintain and create jobs.  After years of questioning our effectiveness and hard work as a country, I am proud to be able to tell you that we are one of the first states to submit a national recovery plan and even with praise for its analysis and interventions. The dynamic response and the immediate reaction we are showing as Greece during the pandemic to economic and social problems I think — and it is recognised everywhere — is remarkable. Our Action and Resilience Plan includes an integrated and coherent set of reforms and investments that will increase potential growth and, consequently, job creation and economic and social resilience, with green growth and digital transformation as their main objectives as well. In conjunction with the other funds, we have been able to create our own billion-euro 'vaccine' against the economic and social impoverishment of our citizens.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Mr President! What we are now completing with the vote was unimaginable less than a year ago. I agree with everyone, this fund is really historic, with all the dimensions it brings, including the change in the very structure of the Union. The framework is excellent, thanks in particular to the negotiators of the European Parliament. But it's one thing to make it happen. It's complicated elsewhere, in execution. Everything stands or falls on national plans, which are, of course, drawn up by the Member States. So is it logical and right that these plans do not involve the general public? Plans to spend public money that should be aimed at future generations? We must strive for the rapid implementation of new own resources and make this fund permanent, and countries must carry out projects wisely, not by heart, and not without a clear vision. Here, however, you really need to take on your role decisively in the Commission, because the key implementation will be in practice and an excellent framework on paper alone will just not be enough.

name: José Manuel GARCÍA-MARGALLO Y MARFIL
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, today for European federalists is a great day because it is an important step forward in the process of European integration. In the 2008 crisis the European reaction was late and timid, and we had to endure lasting and probably useless sacrifices. Today we have reacted infinitely better on the basis of two principles: solidarity and responsibility. You have to spend whatever it takes, you have to spend it soon, but you have to spend it well, and in my opinion there are four commandments that would have to be fulfilled. First, the principle of transparency in the selection and award of projects to avoid discretion and clientelism. Second, strengthening post-post controls as public procurement rules are loosened to prevent waste and corruption. Thirdly, surveillance, that the measures taken comply with country-specific recommendations without seeking shortcuts. It is not permissible, for example, to combat school drop-out by decreeing a general approval. And, fourthly, sustainability. Recovery is now based on many pillars; the flexibility of the Stability and Growth Pact, which allows to borrow what is necessary, is not the least, but a period of stabilization will come and markets will begin to prioritize, select and punish those who do not comply.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues, the economic and social impacts of the pandemic are asymmetrical. They vary from country to country and lead to an increase in poverty and inequality within Europe.  Service sectors such as tourism, on which the economies of several Member States depend to a large extent, are hardest hit. Covid-19 has also increased demographic challenges, which pose perhaps the greatest danger to maintaining a European way of life in the future.  I am pleased that the final proposal for the mechanism goes towards solving these problems on the trail of amendments that I have proposed myself. Particular attention is paid to rural areas, islands, outermost regions and regions exposed to serious and persistent demographic difficulties. It will invest in increasing the availability of health and care capacity, with equal protection for all being ensured. It is inadmissible that in certain parts of the Union mortality from certain diseases is 30 or 40 percent higher than in others. It will also invest in the sectors of tourism and hospitality that have suffered the worst as a result of the disease, which in some Member States cover up to 20% of gross domestic product.  All of this needs to be supported by those investments that bring European added value, which strengthen the competitiveness of the European economy, not just return us to a state before the pandemic or serve to patch holes in government budgets. Of course, Member States will play a key role in this. In addition to the public sector, it is extremely important that funds reach businessmen, especially SMEs, who have suffered the most as a result of the pandemic to help them recover their jobs. In this way, we will show that the European Union contributes very specifically to the quality of life of its citizens through actions, not just words.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Mr President! Dear colleagues! The recovery and resilience plan, together with the Multiannual Financial Framework, is a correct, robust response to the crisis that has arisen in Europe as a result of the Covid crisis. The plan has a great note of solidarity, which we have seen as necessary in difficult matters, and this plan allows for more resources for those who have been more affected in the crisis. What is crucial in this plan is that, through the investments that are being made together with the multiannual financial framework and the funds from the mechanism, we can respond to the european Union's key vision – a green Europe, a digital Europe – building on the competitiveness of the European economy, which is crucial to also respond to social cohesiveness and, above all, to respond to the shortcomings that have emerged during this time in the field of health care. , long-term care. In my country, Too, it has been shown how it is necessary to invest in health care, in long-term care and how well the funds will come from both the recovery and resilience plan and the multiannual financial framework. The key steps are now to adopt our national plans, to adopt the reforms that underpin the absorption of these funds, and to respond to future generations. I am also pleased that special attention is paid to the young people who would lose the most in this crisis.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: Mr President! This is a staggering amount that EU heads of state and government agreed to borrow this summer to repair the many corona damages. Injuries that in several places are more or less self-inflicted. But the need for the money is in doubt.  There is no doubt that there is a difference in how the money is spent best in each country. But there is also no doubt that if money is cheated, tampered with or wasted, it will fuel dissatisfaction with the EUROPEAN Union and the distrust of our neighbours. And we, ladies and gentlemen, we are all getting beat. Some of us will use it for our own gain, but most of us will get the rump on comedy. In many ways, the European Parliament is the EU's exam guards and motor ing system. The elected house needs to be targeted for a little bit of each. It is therefore essential that all the Member States respect the rules of the game that are now on the table. Among other things, countries must provide clear national action plans.  Since it is all our money, it is natural to be clear that transparency and full transparency must be ensured both with the European Parliament and, above all, with the citizens and SMEs in the countries. The impact of the EU Aid Fund is, of course, to be commended and criticised in openness. I hope national governments will ensure that.

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Yes, the Corona Reconstruction Fund is a strong expression of European solidarity. A great opportunity for the future – if we get it right. We have responsibility for EUR 750 billion. Money that we did not have, but for what we had to do, for which the Commission had to be indebted to the member states. Repayment at the limit of what is feasible by 2050. EUR 750 billion – the European Union has only this one arrow in its quiver in the Corona crisis. He has to sit. Otherwise, Next Generation gets a bad taste. If the money slips into ailing treasuries, it will be the next generation that blames us. Apart from debt, we will be accused. Therefore, the money must be invested in the energy transition in a targeted and binding manner. It must make health systems more efficient and digital. It needs to modernise many national education systems and universities and to align vocational training much more closely with the needs of business and society. I am already concerned about whether some governments are capable of doing so. If they had recognised the signs of the times, EUR 290 billion of EU funding from the Structural Funds would not be in stock today, ladies and gentlemen. Because in many countries it is too slow to call up the funds, because the ideas are lacking, because the approval procedures are too complicated. Ladies and gentlemen, EUR 750 billion now, there must be a jolt through the nation states. Make a effort to use this money quickly, sensibly and efficiently for reconstruction and the future.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, today's sitting is to confirm the struggles of dozens of colleagues here in the European Parliament for joint borrowing and — at last — solidarity and common treatment of the effects of our generation's war. From now on, implementation is important and there are two parameters that are of particular importance. The first parameter is time; From today begins the marathon of recovery effort. Member States and national parliaments should urgently approve own resources in order to guarantee the repayment of joint lending. My country, Greece, has already planned and planned a series of major interventions for the digitisation of the public sector, education and health, for the deep upgrading of buildings and the environment, for sustainable transport and for the definitive detoxification of our energy mix from coal. These actions require strong private sector involvement, with mature projects supporting green growth and the digital economy. The second aspect is that the recovery funds reach the citizens. Support for small and medium-sized enterprises through specific programmes. Supporting small and micro innovative enterprises will give taxpayers' money capital gains; Today we are voting to borrow in the name of our children. It is the way in which we invest the last euro that determines their future.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, this is World Greek Language Day today and I am honouring my language. The pandemic was unprecedented for all of us. Dealing with an ongoing battle at all levels. It has created huge wounds but also challenges both in the economy and in society. Our fight is two-way. We are dealing with the health crisis with vaccines and the economic crisis collectively with direct financial support to the Member States. Europe has shown readiness and I am proud as a member of the European People's Party that it has pioneered the creation of the Recovery Mechanism that we are discussing today. This money will help millions of businesses and workers affected by the pandemic to stand on their own two feet. We are building the future for a smooth green and digital transition; for a better tomorrow with more opportunities for our young people. Europe shows that in such economic and humanitarian crises it stands united and in solidarity and we are proud of our European identity.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, today is an important historic moment for the European Parliament and the European Union, because for the first time the European Parliament and the European Union together have managed to respond to the socio-economic crisis with a powerful weapon of the Recovery and Resilience Fund's 672 million. We must and must be proud as the European Parliament, because also through the Committee on Budgets — first and for most, and above all my dear colleague Siegfried Mureşan, who was one of the rapporteurs — we have managed and achieved an important framework for supporting the economies of the Member States of the European Union and also of European citizens. It is particularly important to say that, in order to consider it a success, the recovery and resilience plan must safeguard the next generation; This plan must secure new jobs and zero unemployment. This plan must give money and liquidity to small and medium-sized enterprises in a dire economic position and more broadly and in general support society so that no European citizen is left on the sidelines; so that no European citizen is left homeless; so that no European citizen is left without a job. I come from a small country, Cyprus, which was tested in 2013 and is still being tested today by the socio-economic crisis. It's based on tourism. It is necessary, my dear friend — Vice-President of the European Commission , to aim to support tourism but at the same time to be ready if we need a second package to support the economies of the Member States to implement it.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first I would like to thank you for today’s very comprehensive debate. If the European Parliament endorses this regulation today, the Council Presidency has foreseen a fast process so that the agreement can be signed as soon as this Friday. So if all goes well, the regulation could enter into force as early as this month, with the publication date in the Official Journal likely to be in late February. We could then look ahead to the remaining steps before a formal submission of the plans for the assessment by the European Commission. It will require a great deal of effort both to get Member States’ plans ready for formal submission, and to get the plans assessed and approved quickly. This will be the focus of the Commission. The European Parliament’s involvement is very important and so the Commission is ready to continue our exchanges in the context of structured dialogue. The communication on the Recovery and Resilience Facility must be strong. So I trust the voice of Parliament to support Member States and the Commission on these efforts. Ownership lies at the heart of the Recovery and Resilience Facility. This is why it is important to work closely with local, regional and national authorities, social partners and relevant stakeholders at all stages of preparation and implementation. A key element is ratification of the own-resources decision. And we must not lose sight of this. Only then can we start borrowing under Next Generation EU and provide the first payments to the Member States. And in parallel, we must make sure that all measures are put in place to finance a recovery by issuing green bonds. The Commission will present a legislative proposal to this end as soon as possible.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, rapporteurs, distinguished Members, Mr Dombrovskis, thank you very much for the possibility of having participated in this debate which has clearly shown the relevance of the recovery and resilience mechanism, particularly when associated with the implementation of the Financial Framework and also the Next Generation EU. This Parliament makes history today.  Several points have been mentioned which seem to me of great importance. Firstly, that the RRF should be managed efficiently and transparently respecting the role of the three institutions. The Commission will have to report regularly to the European Parliament and Parliament will have an important role in verifying and scrutinising the whole process.  It is also important that, in addition to digital and climate transitions, the European pillar of social rights is at the heart of the RRF. This regulation is very clear as regards the social quality of expenditure, in particular in promoting social cohesion and gender equality. It is also important, as has been said here, that the RRF is aligned with the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Next Generation EU with regard to respect for the rule of law and the defence of the Union's financial interests.  Finally, several members of this Parliament mentioned the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises. They are the backbone of our economies and without them there will be no recovery. We're in agreement.  The Council is ready to continue work with the European Parliament and the Commission in finding the best solutions to address the many challenges that will accompany us over the coming years. We must therefore have a sense of urgency and work on the implementation of the regulation.  As has already been said, Member States now have to ensure ratification by their national parliaments of the own resources decision and, at the same time, to present good national recovery and resilience plans, ensuring that reforms and investment quickly reach regions, cities, businesses, citizens, making a difference in the recovery of the crisis and reorienting our economies to a more sustainable future , more innovative, more supportive.  As the motto of the Portuguese Presidency says: "For a fair, green and digital recovery: it is time to act." Thank you so much.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. My fellow Members, I would like to thank you for your support. The European Union is about to adopt the Recovery and Resilience Facility, a €312.5 billion grant and a €360 billion loan, to kick-start the economic recovery following the COVID crisis. What we have been constantly saying since the beginning of the health crisis – that global challenges must be answered together – now seems to be coming to fruition. Let us not forget that the Europe of our children is at stake. It is therefore of the uminent importance that, as described in the Recovery Fund Regulation, Member State governments fulfil their obligations to develop a recovery plan on the proportions of distribution of supported programmes only after consultation with local and regional authorities and NGOs.  The distribution of EU support under the Recovery and Resilience Facility should comply with standards of transparency and fair competition. In order to fulfil these conditions, the European Commission recently called on the Government of my country, Hungary, to increase the transparency of public procurement procedures and to reduce corruption, so that hungarian households and businesses that are most in need actually have access to EU funds. I would ask the Commission that, if the Orban Government does not comply with these consultation and transparency obligations, the Commission should allocate EUR 6.3 billion to Hungary directly to local and regional authorities and NGOs, so that Hungarian citizens are not punished for the corrupt policies of the Orban government.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – The recovery package for the coronavirus, including the creation of the RFF, is undoubtedly historic in the LIFE of the EU. The financial framework in the reconstruction package is brutal in size and the general objectives set out in relation to its use must be supported. As a Hungarian Social Democrat, however, I say that the use of a development package of this scale should give priority to health improvements, the provision of housing and the protection of jobs, as well as a meaningful reduction in overhead costs. I also consider it particularly essential to consult widely in the Member States on the spending of the resources included in the RFF.  I know that there are states where the government is in open and responsible consultation with advocacy groups, civilians and a wide range of citizens before submitting its reform plan on the use of resources. Unfortunately, I see that in Hungary, where the Fidesz government is so proud to seek the opinion of the people on all important issues, this consultation is being sought. It is extremely regrettable that, in relation to the use of the thousands of forints of reconstruction funds in Hungary, the Orban government is almost not involved at all. Moreover, it is once again using money from the EU only for its own propaganda campaign, denying that the funds for development are provided by the EU programme. We are facing a grandiose reconstruction process, which can only be a success story if it is transparent, serves real recovery and reconstruction, but also focuses on social goals.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – The European Parliament has made a significant contribution to the improvement of the European Recovery and Resilience Mechanism, a central element of the Next Generation EU instrument, which aims to mitigate the economic and social impact of the coronavirus pandemic.  An important amendment concerns the increase from 10 %, the EC proposal to 13 %, of pre-financing granted to Member States. Another change gives MEPs the power to assess the programmes and decide, every two years, if necessary, to improve those aspects that do not work properly under the Mechanism. Funding will support greening and digitisation projects in the Member States, in the field of economic competitiveness and cohesion, in territorial and social cohesion, as well as youth projects.  Romania must make full use of the EUR 30.5 billion funds it will get through this Mechanism and will have to continue, through investments and reforms, the modernisation process. Our country must prepare itself adequately to meet the challenges of the transition to a green and digital economy, and with THE support of the EU, our society must become more sustainable and resilient once it leaves the pandemic behind.
