name: Roberta METSOLA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, thank you for allowing the Presidency of the Council to intervene on this important topic. On 27 January, the Polish Constitutional Tribunal ruling of last October which restricted abortion to cases of fatal defects came into effect. This has prompted a wave of women’s demonstrations in several Polish cities, as was the case last November.  Abortion and reproductive rights are highly sensitive and complex issues across Europe, including from a legal perspective. The European Court of Human Rights has consistently ruled that the Council of Europe member states enjoy a wide margin of appreciation as to whether and under what circumstances abortion is permitted under their national law. But once a member state decides to allow abortion, it has, according to the European Court of Human Rights, a positive obligation to create a procedural framework enabling a pregnant woman to effectively exercise her right to have access to lawful abortion, in compliance with relevant provisions of the European Convention on Human Rights. As far as the European Union is concerned, primary law confirms that Union law in principle does not interfere with constitutional provisions and other national legislation of EU Member States relating to abortion. The Charter of Fundamental Rights does not provide an autonomous right to abortion, even though it contains various rights that are potentially relevant for reproductive matters. Pursuant to Article 51(1) of the Charter, these rights apply only when Member States are implementing Union law. In accordance with Article 168(7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, Union action in the field of public health should respect the responsibilities of the Member States for the definition of their health policy and for the organisation and delivery of health services and medical care. In this regard, the European Pillar of Social Rights states that everyone has the right to timely access to affordable, preventive and corrective health care of good quality. Indeed, the EU has no competence on abortion policy. But as a woman and as a member of a government, I would affirm that women’s rights are fundamental human rights and that sexual and reproductive health rights are at the core of gender equality and human rights. Also, the Union has a strong policy in terms of gender equality with a cross-cutting approach to all policies. The Council has in several instances reaffirmed the EU’s commitment to the promotion, protection and fulfilment of the right of every individual to have full control over, to decide freely, and to have full responsibility on matters related to their sexuality and sexual and reproductive health; free from discrimination, coercion and violence. In this regard, let me stress that we certainly need a gender—sensitive approach in our responses now more than ever, and I thank the Commission for all the initiatives and actions included in this gender-equality agenda. The Presidency also calls for support for women’s NGOs in their advocacy role, ensuring that they can access EU funds – including those of the European Social Fund – in the new programming period, the rights, equality and citizenship programme, and other funding and schemes.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, Minister, honourable Members, after our debate in this Chamber in November, the situation in Poland regarding sexual and reproductive health rights has not improved. The ruling of the Polish Constitutional Tribunal of October last year stipulating that the abortion law is unconstitutional has now come into effect, bringing a near total ban on abortion. Abortion will no longer be permitted in the case of a severe and irreversible impairment of the foetus. In practice, this means that 98% of abortions so far carried out in Poland will become illegal.  The EU has no competence on abortion rights within a Member State. Legislation in this area is up to the Member State concerned. When making use of their competences, Member States must respect fundamental rights which bind them by virtue of their national constitutions and commitments under international law. High-quality sexual and reproductive health services are essential to women and girls and to men and boys, and this goes beyond abortion and includes access to contraception, education and prevention, as well as the treatment of HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases and fertility and sex-specific cancers. We must take an intersectional approach. Women with disabilities, for instance, or with a minority racial or ethnic background can be more vulnerable to violations of their sexual and reproductive health rights than other women.  As regards the Constitutional Tribunal, back in December 2017 the Commission already formally considered in its reasoned proposal under the Article 7 procedure, that the independence and legitimacy of the Constitutional Tribunal is seriously undermined and the constitutionality of Polish laws can no longer be effectively guaranteed. As the 2020 Rule of Law Report recalls, these concerns have so far not been resolved. So I thank you and I look forward to your interventions.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for No one imagined that once again we would be talking about Polish women in the European Parliament. We deluded that the judgment of the Constitutional Court will not be published and that no one will force Polek into heroism and will not take away their already very limited choice. I would therefore like to make it clear: it was the PiS Government that decided on today's debate. One can get the impression that such a socially important topic is trying to cover up a number of inedibility, and this is wicked.  I will repeat what I said so recently in the European Parliament: no one has the right to be the conscience of Polish women. Increasingly, I hear that Poland is not a good country for mothers, and pregnancy instead of being a state of emergency and awaited becomes a state of risk and fear. When we look at the statistics, we see that Polish women are giving birth to fewer and fewer children in the country, and in 2020 we achieved the lowest growth in 20 years. Unfortunately, this problem is being downplayed.  We know how many women have trouble becoming pregnant. Nevertheless, the in vitro program, which had very good results and was an opportunity for its own offspring for thousands of couples, is being abolished. It closes our eyes to the problem of access to prenatal research, perinatal care, adequate support for mothers raising a disabled child or sex education. No woman will become pregnant because that is what politicians would like. Neither the law nor the social allowance will change that. It is time to create smart solutions that will allow women to choose and, above all, give them the feeling that they are safe in this choice.  I have the impression that the Polish wants to force women into the role of women decades ago. I believe it won't work. I am with Polish women, as are my colleagues in the Citizens' Coalition and the PPE Group in the European Parliament.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, they finally did, perhaps they expected us to be entertained in other discussions or unprepared. But it's not like that. Today we are discussing women's rights in Poland in plenary. Because it's about debating women's rights. Because it's about debating human rights.  The publication of the judgment of the Constitutional Court of Poland and the support of the Polish Government implies a de facto ban on abortion. The decision is made by a court which should not be called that, since it is fully controlled by the Law and Justice party, that of Mr Kaczy-ski, who does not respect the separation of powers. And it is an issue that this Parliament must deal with.  Let's consider something else. With the ban on abortion, we are not managing to end this practice. What we're doing is playing with women's lives, because those women who need to terminate their pregnancy will—have no doubt they will—putting their own lives at risk. They'll do it without the sanitary conditions. They'll do it elsewhere outside Poland. But they will.  We therefore need to talk about these issues here in the European Parliament: how to avoid the clandestine abortions that cause the deaths of thousands and thousands of women. Some people have wanted us not to hold this debate, that Parliament should not talk about women's rights in Poland. I'm going to make it very clear: we'll talk one, we'll talk five, we'll talk as many times as necessary, because it's not the women of Poland, we're all. And I'm going to repeat the same message I gave less than a month ago: "You're not alone. We are going to defend all women in Europe."

name: Samira RAFAELA
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, an unlawful Polish Constitutional Court ruled that abortion is no longer permitted in the case of severe foetal abnormalities, which obliges women to give birth to babies with no chance of survival. The Polish Government, like some parties here in Parliament, does not care that women suffer an incredible amount physically and mentally as a result. There is simply no respect for women's bodies, no respect for women's well-being and no respect for women's rights in these conservative, anti-feminist movements, including here in Parliament. On the backs of women, they are implementing their non-ethical agenda. Less than three months ago, we met in Parliament and condemned this violation of women's rights. But they're still going to keep going. Now we see that it's not just words. Despite massive street protests, the judgment has now been officially passed into law by the Polish government. So the Polish Government is simply completely out of our way. It is a new low in the systematic wave of attacks on women's rights in Poland and on the rule of law. We cannot accept that a bunch of pseudo-tribunals are going to serve in European Member States supported by a strong anti-abortion lobby organisation in Europe. My question to the Commission is: what are you going to do in practice? Are we going to watch this inhumane policy curtail the fundamental rights of women in Poland? I don't think so. Parliament is clear. Please do not raise funds, and support the women's organisations in Poland.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen! Once again, an EU Member State is to be pilloried today. I think that is indecent. But what is it all about? The Poles want to protect marriage, family and the human right to life, thereby protecting them and fighting them for the very values that are at the heart of European identity. One of our founding fathers, Robert Schuman, said that democracy will be a Christian or it will not remain. And I remind the Christian Democrats, who are still so called, Otto von Habsburg, who once said: 'Europe will be Christian, or it will not be'. Colleagues, do you want to throw all this overboard? Do you want to undermine the foundations of the European Union? We should be grateful to the Poles for their commitment to European values in this way. For democracy, for freedom of expression and speech and, yes, for life and for the dignity of human beings, of all people, from conception to death. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the May you succeed in preserving the foundations of a values-based Christian society. And may you succeed in ensuring a sustainable community for your families and children in your country and, hopefully, in many Member States.  When I look around here, it seems hopeless. But you, dear Poles, have proven several times in history that your fight and your commitment will be rewarded in the end. I rejoice in arguing with you and wish you good luck and God's blessing.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: On behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We are not discussing the judgment of an independent court today, but about a political decision. It was taken by persons not authorized to adjudicating, sitting in the Constitutional Tribunal dependent on the ruling party. This is not a ruling, but a political attack on women's fundamental right to decide for themselves. Another such attack in Poland.  There is no longer a rule of law in Poland and no women's rights. This was also because the European Commission was not effective in enforcing Poland's compliance with the rule of law. Nor has the European Commission been effective in achieving the adoption of a horizontal anti-discrimination directive guaranteeing equal treatment for all women in the European Union in the area of health, including access to abortion. Because abortion is a normal medical benefit. And so it should be seen by law. When will the Commission finally take action and use all its tools to protect women in Poland? Time is running out.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Once again, we are witnessing a debate about the allegedly violated rule of law in Poland. Once again, the European Parliament, which so often calls for respect for the rule of law, is de facto breaking this rule of law, because issues relating to the protection of life and the relevant regulations fall within the competence of the Member States. It was not enough for you to make a statement from the European Commission, Commissioner Dalli, two months ago, who said here in Parliament that the issue of abortion is a competence of the Member States. But no, you want to fuel the political dispute in Poland. They want women to take to the streets in times of pandemic, at a time when we are fighting for the lives of our citizens. You are de facto concerned that disputes in Poland are expiring, which is why this debate is taking place today.  Ladies and about! The Court examined the constitutionality of the law, a constitution signed nota bene by a left-wing president and adopted under the rule of the left. The previous Presidents of the Constitutional Tribunal have made it clear that the Court could not have ruled otherwise, but this does not bother you. You absolutely want to fuel an ideological dispute.  Not so long ago, you came to Parliament wearing t-shirts that read 'constitution', calling on the Polish government to respect the constitution that you believe is being violated. Today you are dissatisfied that the Court is ruling in accordance with the Constitution.  I'm tired of suing Polish women, suing the Polish government. Poland has one of the smallest wage gaps. And it is in Poland that regulation is prepared, which is to consider the wage gap as one of the forms of harassment. Remember! Share the civilization of life!

name: Eugenia RODRÍGUEZ PALOP
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, the judgment of the Polish Constitutional Court, a body devoid of legitimacy and independence, must be framed on the parallel agenda of the far-right governments and the conservative groups that support them, whose objective is to boost the achievements made in terms of gender. And these antigender campaigns, let's not kid ourselves, are not just national trends or isolated occurrences, but are part of a transnational organization with common strategies and patterns. The criminalization of abortion is a violation of the right to life because it condemns women to clandestine and unsafe abortions and the right to health and medical care, equality and non-discrimination, personal safety, reproductive autonomy, privacy, reproductive health information, including sex education , to decide the number of children and the interval between births, to enjoy the benefits of scientific progress, and to religious freedom and conscience, when it becomes brazen apostolate from the institutions. Moreover, it is a violation of the right of women, like other human beings, not to be subjected to cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment. When abortion is banned, the state becomes a true institutional aggressor who monitors our bodies, sexuality and reproductive capacity. Poland has health powers, no doubt, but no State that is part of the Council can have the competence to violate human rights or to attack the rule of law. Polish women have taken to the streets and resisted. We're with them. We're not slaves to any government, and we're not going to take a step back.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, we are having this discussion in this House today because we are concerned about the rule of law, credible justice and fundamental rights in Europe. Polish justice is European justice, and as such it must follow common European principles and commitments that all European citizens’ rights are fully respected and protected. Unfortunately, this is not the case in Poland today. Last October, the Polish Constitutional Court, the Polish Constitutional Tribunal, made an important decision with consequences for the lives of many Polish and European citizens. The decision on abortion was delivered by judges fully dependent on politicians from the governing majority. Let us remember that three members of the current Constitutional Tribunal were appointed in violation of the Polish Constitution. And this decision has taken place in the context of a broader ongoing struggle for independent justice in Poland.  Dear colleagues, reliable institutions matter and are crucial for credible rule of law and judiciary. Important decisions such as on abortion must be taken through mechanisms that enjoy the trust of the people, but 78% of Poles opposed the Constitutional Tribunal’s decision, and many have taken repeatedly to the streets to protest it. Women’s rights are human rights and they deserve proper treatment, not political shortcuts. What kind of a democratic government sends masses of its citizens to protest in the streets? I therefore stand here in solidarity with those who are calling for the return of justice, rule of law and human dignity in Central Europe.

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We have 2021. We are in the middle of Europe. In 2021, in the heart of Europe, the current rulers raised their hand on women. They limited the rights of women, which successive generations of Polek fought for centuries. Moreover, this authority raised its hand on women who took to the streets to defend their rights. She used gas against women, she broke their hands. She unjustifiably detained them. And these right-wing fanatics, of course, today have no intention of stopping, because they have led to the fact that today Polish women have more limited rights than women in Iran. And often the example of Iran falls here as an extremely conservative state.  The situation is absurd, because in 2004, when Poland joined the European Union, Poles had more rights than today in 2021. I therefore call on the European Commission to supplement the proposal on the rule of law in Poland (on the basis of Article 7 of the EU Treaties) with the issue of restricting women's rights in Poland. This proposal must be extended so that Polish women finally have the same rights as Belgian, French and Germans.

name: Karen MELCHIOR
text: – Madam President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, equality is a fundamental value of the European Union. Equality starts with our right to decide over our own body. The decision by the ‘unconstitutional’ constitutional tribunal in Poland flies in the face of this fundamental value. The last five years the Polish Government has abandoned the values that unite Europe. Minorities have been under attack, the rule of law has been under attack, and women, women’s bodies, have been under attack. The right to abortion has slowly but surely been stolen from Polish women. The fight of Polish women for their rights is also my fight. I am not free and equal until all women in Europe are free and equal. The right to abortion should not be an ideological battle, but the Polish Government has made it into an ideological battleground. Ms Jadwiga Wiśniewska, would you force your daughter to carry her embrypathological foetus to term, to force her to give birth  not to a baby, but to a corpse? It is time to say stop. Dość tego!

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The debates on Poland and the alleged violation of the rule of law are, after all, an evergreen in this Parliament. But today's debate, for its part, is an attack on the rule of law. It starts with us discussing something for which the European Union has no competence, namely the right of abortion of the sovereign state of Poland. It goes on to say that Here Members think that they have to deny the legitimacy of Poland's legitimate Constitutional Court because they do not like his decisions. Yes, that's just the way it is in court. Some decisions don't please you.  And it is, after all, a joke, because there is no fundamental right to abortion at all. There is also no human right to abortion. But there is a human right to life, and that also encompasses unborn life. And that is why 32 nations – including the United States of America, but also Hungary and Poland – have chosen to fight abortion in the Geneva Consensus Declaration on Promoting Women's Health because there are far too many abortions. The countries of France, Germany, Spain and Italy alone: half a million a year.  Every abortion is a tragedy, and politicians are called upon to fight for the right to life and decent conditions for families and not to attack countries that do. It is time to be against abortion and for life, not for immigration. And it is time to stop calling for a concept of the rule of law, which is that the rule of law is what is left-wing, and that everything that is legal and correct is evil.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, what the Polish Government is very obviously trying to do is to transform Poland into some sort of dystopian Gilead, a place where men have control over women and their bodies. And nobody who is watching the situation can deny that any longer. But, for years, the people who were pointing to that fact, most of all millions of women in Poland who were warning and saying how scared they were for their own rights, were told by many not to be so overdramatic and hysterical. And now they are angry and they have every right in the world to be so. That is why they are rising up. They are going onto the streets and protesting for their fundamental rights. Let us learn this lesson, colleagues. When women warn that their rights are in danger, you’d better listen to them instead of trying to shut them up. But, most of all – and I can repeat this another million times if need be, Madam Commissioner – act, do something about this situation. The Polish judiciary, Polish women, the LGBTI community in Poland – what else has to happen so that we finally see true commitment from the Commission for European values and for the fundamental rights of European citizens?

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to point out that the title of this debate is a blatant lie. There is no total ban on abortion in Poland. In Poland, according to the Constitution, the right to life of those unborn who cannot defend themselves is protected. Exceptional situations are. When the health or life of the mother is at risk or when pregnancy comes from a crime.  I would like to stress that no international human rights instrument to which Poland is a party provides for the right to abortion. There is no mention of such a right in the European Convention on Human Rights and the case-law of the European Court of Human Rights.  Before 21 March, on People's Day with Down's Syndrome, you will be willing to take selfies and put on different socks in order to later call for those who are not yet born to have a fundamental right to life, I will remind you of the words that the Commissioner has said in this Chamber: 'From a legal point of view, it is clear that the Union does not have competence when it comes to the right to abortion in a Member State'. Helena Dalli, Commissioner for Equality, said this during the November and today's debate. Haven't you heard that? Forgot those words? Today's debate is nothing more than an attempt to interfere in the internal affairs of a Member State incompatible with the Treaties.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! Women have the right to control their own bodies. It is a human right and that right should not be infringed. But it is happening right now in Poland. The far-right Polish government has pushed through the ban on abortion. It is not only a breach of women's right to control their own bodies. It is also a blatant breach of fundamental principles of the rule of law, as the decision was taken by illegally appointed judges. The abortion ban is being implemented despite large protests from the Polish people, who have for many months defied police violence and abuse. Polish women deserve the right to control their own bodies. Poland deserves respect for fundamental principles of the rule of law. That is why the European Union must act. The rule of law mechanism must be activated. No EU support should go to the Polish Government as long as it violates human rights.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, the situation in Poland is very bleak and utterly inhumane. We have a government that seeks to discard the rule of law and human rights, a government that thinks they have a monopoly on what the truth is, a government that persecutes their own people, advocating for ‘LGBTI-free’ zones and a government that believes they can control women. I’m pretty sure if it wasn’t for free movement and the European Union, Poles would be applying for asylum in many EU countries, persecuted at home. A safety net provided by the EU for what is a European shame. Ironic. The absolutist approach of banning abortion entirely shows no compassion for women nor for their bodily integrity or faith in them to make their own decisions. Mr Kaczynski, are you so afraid of Polish women that you seek to keep them under your control? Pregnancy can be a joyous and happy occasion, but it can also be complex. And as humans, as dignified citizens, we must understand that complexity, and have flexibility for the circumstances that are not clear cut, like fatal foetal abnormality – where a much-longed-for child cannot survive. Are you so afraid of women that you want to put them through the trauma of giving birth to a child that cannot survive? What made you and the Polish state the sole arbiter of moral decisions? I believe the people of Poland will win the day.

name: Predrag Fred MATIĆ
text: – Dear Chair, Commissioners, first and foremost, a few devastating data: estimates are that around 25 million unsafe abortions are performed annually and 23 000 women die worldwide as a result. It has been shown that bans do not lead to fewer abortions but to more of those abortions performed in unsafe conditions, and Poland is again pushing its citizens to be part of this difficult and devastating statistic. It's sad, worrying and inadmissible. It is about the health and lives of your mothers, sisters, daughters, friends and they cannot be left at the mercy of a political agenda aimed at banning, restricting, downgrading. We cannot hide forever behind the arguments of the competences of the Member States and I really hope and appeal to all those in Poland who have the power to change this shameful decision to do so. We will always advocate against this in this house loud and clear, and this way I want to express solidarity with all those women who are protesting on the streets of Poland. Colleagues, this is a matter of life for European citizens, their health, human rights and freedoms, and if we do not react to this, then we have abandoned the European Union in its fundamental values and we will have to ask ourselves what binds us and brings us together, if not the preservation and respect of basic human rights? In the end; I do not want to believe that some members from the east have entered the European Union simply to take money from richer countries; to me, European values are much, much more than that.

name: Chrysoula ZACHAROPOULOU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, a bit of history. For nearly 40 years, from 1956 to 1993, Polish women were entitled to free and free access to abortion. In 1993, access to abortion was severely restricted. Today, abortion is in fact prohibited by the Constitutional Court. What is happening in Poland is serious. This judgment appears to have been written by priests and not by lawyers. This case endangers the health and lives of women and criminalizes doctors. Commissioner, obscurantism is back at the heart of Europe. Civil society is mobilized. The European Parliament has been standing with Polish women for months. But now it is your turn, Commission and Council. You have the tool: it's the budget. Then act with courage and responsibility!

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Every week you demand special rights for the 200 undefined sexes who already have their special rights, their special measures, their commissioners, their resolutions. And recently, even here, you organized a conference on special activities for women who provide sexual services. In general, in this House, everyone has their rights except for children who are accused of disability. They, according to a large part of you, can be removed even in the eighth, ninth month of pregnancy on request. And yet you say that this is a human right, and you are challenging all those who defend these most vulnerable children, the most vulnerable children. And indeed, in many places it is the case that children with Down's syndrome are no longer born, and patients can be euthanized without their consent. The key question is: who has given you the right to decide which life is better and which life is worse? Many Poles do not divide life into a better life and a worse life. And I'll tell you more: we're not ashamed of it.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the fight for women's rights, labour rights and equality, but also for sexual and reproductive health rights, is a decades-long struggle.  In this debate, we want to underline and value the struggle of women in Poland, but not only in Slovakia and other countries, which, even in times of pandemic, continue to fight on the streets not only for sexual and reproductive rights, including access to voluntary termination of pregnancy, but also to combat serious setbacks in the law.  Portuguese women, in their struggle to decriminalize the voluntary termination of pregnancy, received the solidarity of women from various countries. We are now repaying this support with the dynamic in Portugal of an initiative of solidarity with the struggle of Polish women, which were associated with outstanding women with intervention in various areas.  We believe that legislative setbacks in the field of voluntary termination of pregnancy are attacking the health, rights and dignity of women, with increased risks for women from the most socially and economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

name: Tomasz FRANKOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab "An open heart is accepting, not evaluating." These are the words of the wonderful Polish actress Małgorzata Braunek. Meanwhile, tens of thousands of Polish women took to the streets of more than 100 Polish cities outraged by the decision of the government and its subordinate Constitutional Court. Dependent on the Polish Government, the Court has changed the existing abortion law without public consultation. There was an outbreak of discontent and across the country women spontaneously took to the streets to express their dissent. Neither the fear of coronavirus nor the behavior of the police stopped them, quite aggressive in certain situations.  The decision to terminate a pregnancy always remains in the mother's conscience, and the consequences of this decision often determine the further life of the woman. In a civilised world, every democratic government asks its citizens about such important changes in the law. Unfortunately, the Government of Law and Justice has violated women's rights and imposed its views on millions of Polish women, denying them respect, tolerance and empathy and depriving them of the right to decide for themselves.  It is all the more sad that in my homeland women have been given the right to vote as one of the first in Europe. This was more than a hundred years ago, in 1918. As a husband and father of three children, I will always be on the side of choice and women's rights, because these are human rights, and it seems that the party currently ruling in Poland in the name of ideological war, while turning its attention away from the problems with the pandemic and with vaccines, decided to ignore it.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Every hour, five women die because of unsafe abortions, and studies from the WHO show that a strict abortion law is not linked to low abortion rates. Any woman with an unwanted pregnancy who cannot have access to a safe abortion risks an unsafe abortion.  Poland's restrictions on abortion rights are not only a serious restriction on access to legal and safe abortion; it is an attack on the rule of law, and it is an attack on women's human rights that can endanger life. I have said it before: the European Union must uphold the rule of law and fundamental rights on sexual and reproductive health and rights and the right to safe and legal abortion. Every woman and girl has the right to control her own body. This also applies to Poland.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, it is very hard, actually, to find a policy in today’s Europe which is so harmful to so many people while at the same time being such an affront to the rule of law. The de facto ban on abortions in Poland actually does both because, on procedure, it has been put in place by a constitutional court whose composition is illegitimate after the ruling government interfered with its independence, and the lack of judicial independence is also made clear from the fact that the government delayed the publication of the ruling for its own convenience. On substance, of course, the ruling, the de facto ban, will heap suffering on hundreds of Polish women every year. Abortions will continue, they will just be less safe. Already before the ban, there were some 80 000 to 200 000 abortions being carried out legally, and this number will grow, which is why, rightly, the Polish people have taken to the streets to protest against this infringement of their rights and we should stand with them.

name: Cristian TERHEŞ
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened very carefully to what the previous speakers have said about the alleged abolition of abortion in Poland and for any independent observer it is shocking to see the double standard that you are demonstrating both to the rule of law and to the constitutional order of the Member States of the European Union. Both the representatives of the Council and the Commission have said, and I quote: 'The EU has no competence in the issue of the regulation of abortion, the theme being one of the Member States'.  However, 17 previous speakers spoke on this subject simply from an ideological perspective, without explaining with legal argumentwhy, legally, the decision of the Constitutional Court of Poland would not be correct. In its decision of 22 October 2020, the Constitutional Court of Poland ruled that abortion on genetic grounds or malformations violates the constitutional provision guaranteeing the right to life of any person. No previous speaker criticof this decision explains why the precedent to be set at European Union level, of deciding who lives and who dies, would be in line with the rule of law.  Colleagues, through the majority positions expressed here to speak only about the right of women to commit abortion, ... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... but not to talk about the right of unborn children to live, ... (The President interrupted the speaker) ... simply sentenced the European Union to death.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: – Madam President, the Polish Constitutional Court is illegitimate and so the ban on abortion is unlawful. It is as simple as that. And it is a head- on attack on women’s rights and women’s bodies. Women have gone to the streets – women and men – and the state has answered with repression and violence and persecution in courts. This must be condemned from the highest level. Next time I want to see the President of the Commission here. I want to see Didier Reynders alongside Commissioner Dalli to condemn this. It was not so long ago that Swedish and French women went to Poland to get access to abortion care. Today the abortion care goes the other way round. So, to all colleagues, friends in Poland, I want to say you are not alone. We will take this fight together with you. We will win this fight together with you. We will not accept any control and that our bodies and our rights are trampled upon. Not in Poland, not anywhere.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: – Madam President, I will not tire of saying to the government in Poland that no, we do not accept your moves to restrict women’s rights. Banning abortions only leads to one thing: dead and intimidated women. Your politics are jeopardising women’s health and lives. Getting an abortion is never an easy choice, but it has to be a choice, everywhere in Europe. In addition, I say to the Polish Government that you are undermining Polish democracy. The biggest protests since 1989 are taking place right now against your politics and all you do is to take one step back when we call you out, as in November, and then, just a little bit later, you secretly leap five steps forward into the dark ages again.  Women’s rights are fundamental rights and those are part of the rule of law, so I reiterate my support to all the Polish people peacefully protesting.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, I come from a country where thousands of women lost their lives during communist years because they had no choice. I am the granddaughter of a woman who suffered tremendously because she had no choice. I was born and raised in this country, but then this country grew so that I can become a free woman. If Mr Kaczyński or his League had ever had an abortion, then they would know that this is not an easy choice. It is one of the hardest choices one can make in search of a safe and dignified life.  Every woman has a right to such a life, to such choices, to decide upon her future. Every leader or entity who does not understand that does not belong to this century, to the European Union, and to our community of values. I stand with you, women of Poland, and, yes, I am too the granddaughter of one of those witches that they did not burn.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Commissioner for Equality, once upon a time there was a European Union in which the States which aspired to accession modernized their legal systems to absorb common values in respect of equality and the rights and freedoms of all. And we see in recent years, and in this case in 2015, as, in a state of recent accession, an increasingly anti-European government has embarked on Poland in a succession of judicial reforms in which independence is no longer recognizable. And as a Constitutional Court, challenged before the Court of Justice of the European Union, it restricts the options for voluntary termination of the pregnancy of thousands and thousands of Polish women, condemning them to clandestineness or an inesumable risk, and millions, in Poland and throughout the European Union, to protest on the streets. So what this resolution wants is for Poland to return to the European Union, but to do so with the rights and freedoms of all its women intact.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, may I say at the outset that the ban on abortion in Poland is a breach of basic fundamental human rights. It’s an attack on women and it limits their choice to make decisions in their interests. I have no doubt that abortions will continue, but they may be exported from Poland, and I just want to say at the outset that I fundamentally believe that women have to have this choice, and it should be a choice available in every country. In the context of Poland, what the Government has decided to do is effectively to force Polish women to go abroad, force young Polish girls to access abortion pills on the internet and use them in the privacy of their own home without medical supervision, maybe bleeding for hours in a bathroom, unable or unsure of what will happen to them in the future.  So I urge the Polish Government to look and decide to change this ban on abortion because it is fundamentally putting Polish women at risk. I condemn the Government’s attitude to this and I support the women and girls of Poland in their protest to ensure their basic human rights and values in Poland as well.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Forcing women to give birth in all circumstances, an act of cruel state violence, will result in thousands of women facing a dramatic choice and the need to seek medical help outside their own country. Unfortunately, not all women will be able to afford it. This situation requires our strong response.  Unfortunately, in response to my and my colleagues' interpellation on the situation of women in Poland and the possibility of reimbursing the costs of abortion in specific cases within the Union, the European Commission has stated that it will not take any action on this matter. This is all the more disappointing because the Commission has many other options for achieving its objectives than legislation. I am referring to providing direct support to civil society programmes and organisations working for education, contraception, the protection of women's rights and health.  The European Parliament has repeatedly called on the Commission to do so in its resolutions. calls on the Commission, using the available resources and newly created EU programmes, to effectively support the protection of women's rights in Poland by, inter alia, funding organisations, programmes facilitating sex education and reproductive rights; The state of emergency introduced in Poland requires exceptional action in the European Union.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Madam President, since 27 January, the right to abortion in Poland has been illegal. Since 22 October, women and men have been demonstrating against the decision. I say women and men, because even if we talk above all about the right of every woman to dispose of her body as she wishes, it is not a struggle of women, it is the struggle of all. We have built ourselves on common values and a common will to defend a model of society that is dear to us. In this model, it is essential that women's rights and freedom of choice are guaranteed. This is no longer the case in Poland: a leap back into a dark past. If the Polish government and the court persist in violating the rule of law, we will have to use all the means at our disposal, including budgetary ones, to protect essential and fundamental rights, including the rights to contraception, health and education, as Commissioner Dalli has just pointed out. That is our role, it is our duty. To all those who fight, I would like to say, "You'll never walk alone."

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Madam President, the de facto ban on abortion in Poland... The need for a new debate on abortion in Poland is appalling, but no one believes that we will give up our arms. We will remain alert and vigilant. After the threats to the right to abortion in this country, we are now facing its outright ban. Once again, the Polish authorities are in the spotlight, but for some very bad reasons. I would add that we are now well aware of their relays in the European institutions which are lobbying uninhibited.  My message of support today is for the Poles who have been demonstrating in their thousands since 22 October against this appalling decision, it is for NGOs and civil society who have been fighting for years against reactionary practices. We have supported them and we will continue.  I would also like to pay tribute to my Polish national parliamentary colleagues who are doing their best to preserve women's rights. This decision in Poland shows us that they seem to be a given, but they are fragile. This fight is the business of all men and women to ensure that access to abortion is a guaranteed right throughout the European Union.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, we are in the 21st century and it is always the same old story: men decide, women drink. Polish men have therefore decided that Polish women will no longer have the right to have an abortion. Here is summed up in one sentence the good old patriarchal oppression. Every year, 100,000 Polish women abort clandestinely. Every year, 100,000 women, at the very heart of the European Union, put their lives at risk - 100,000 today, even more tomorrow. Commissioner, you have the means to act. Act! Fund access to abortion in neighbouring countries for Polish women who wish to do so. And we, ladies and gentlemen, show that Europe stands up for its citizens. Let's take up this beautiful idea of Gisèle Halimi, the most favoured European clause. Let us harmonize our laws from the top for laws that affect women's lives. Hundreds of thousands of Poles demonstrate in the streets. They are the honour of Europe. They're looking at us. Let's be worthy of them!

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I should like to begin by saying to Polish women that we are with you. You're not alone, you're not alone in this battle. We feel part of this battle that concerns us, because we have learned that governments that have a labile idea of the rule of law attack women first, first women and their rights - they start with us - but then attack the rights of everyone and everyone: freedom of expression, in a word, and democracy, which is a very precious asset that we must defend. But more pressing is the attempt to turn back the clock of history, the greater must be the effort not to fall back a millimetre, to look forward, knowing that it is not enough to win a battle, knowing that it is not enough to get a right respected. We must be vigilant, and we in this House do and will always do so.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner Dalli, throughout history and in all cultures there have always been women who, for various reasons, have decided to terminate their pregnancies. Making this illegal does not diminish abortions, all it does is put women's lives at risk or push them to go to other countries, as was the case in my own country when it was not a democracy with those who had the means and were going to have an abortion in London. Now many women in Poland are also forced to leave their country in order to terminate their pregnancies with guarantees for their lives. How many times are women and men going to have to take to the streets in Poland to tell their own government and their Constitutional Court to admit that they are legislating against women, against citizenship, against democracy and against European values? Because we must never forget that women's rights are human rights. From Parliament and from my political group we will continue to support Polish women with initiatives to finance their democratic vindication activities and for Europe to finance the payment of health services outside Poland's borders. You're not alone, we're with you.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we strongly reject any pushback on sexual and reproductive health and rights. While the availability, access and nature of sexual and reproductive health services fall under national competence, the Commission continues to support Member States’ efforts in implementing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals relevant to women’s health, such as on universal access to sexual and reproductive care, family planning and education. To this end, we are planning regular exchanges of good practices between Member States and stakeholders on the gender aspects of health, including on sexual and reproductive health. I am fully committed to doing everything in my power to push forward on women’s rights. Strong women’s rights are an asset and an achievement the whole of Europe must be proud of. We will continue pushing forward. Backsliding is not an option. Progress is hard won, but easily lost. I count on your support to continue working for progress and leaving no woman behind.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me assure you once again that the Presidency attaches great importance to the protection of fundamental rights and the protection of women’s rights, particularly those in a vulnerable situation. Especially during this COVID—19 pandemic, the Union as a whole needs to be very vigilant on respect for the values set out in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. We should all join forces to ensure a robust legal protection for women throughout the whole of the European Union.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission /High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on his visit to Russia in the light of the recent crackdown on demonstrators and opposition representatives (2021/2538(RSP)). It is my job to remind you that, during this part-session, the debate does not give the floor on request and the blue card questions are not accepted. I would also like to point out that, as in previous part-sessions, it is possible to speak remotely from the liaison offices of the Member States.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, Russia—EU relations have come full circle since the 1990 Paris Charter. This charter represented the equivalent of what we call the ‘end of the history’ after the fall of the Berlin Wall. The vision of a common space from Lisbon to Vladivostok has not materialised and Russia has not fulfilled the expectation of becoming a modern democracy. Instead, there is a deep disappointment and growing mistrust between the European Union and Russia. Many of the traditional pillars of Russia—European relations are giving way. Conflicts in Ukraine, the situation in the South Caucasus and Moldova—Transnistria are fuelling EU—Russia tensions, but they are also their product; as is Belarus. Russia’s economic ties with Europe have been severely hit by the sanctions. Energy shipments that have been for decades the backbone of the strategic relationship between Moscow and Europe will be deeply affected by the greening of the world economy. Maybe during our discussions we can come to this issue.  Political dialogue has come to a standstill since the 2014 conflict in Ukraine. Since then, the Russian economy has been shrinking. Today, their GNP per capita is 30% less and the adversity of the present political climate makes values and principles a sore point once again.  And then there is the Navalny case. It is in this context that I decided to travel to Moscow last week. The purpose of the visit was twofold. First, to convey eye to eye, face to face, the European Union’s position on matters of concern to us: human rights, political freedom and the situation of Mr Navalny. This I did and they didn’t appreciate it. The case of Alexei Navalny was at the centre of my tense exchange with Minister Lavrov.  Second, as part of the preparation of the discussion on the next European Council on Russia relations, scheduled for March, I also wanted to test if the Russian authorities are interested in a serious attempt to reverse the deterioration of our relations and seize the opportunity to have a more constructive dialogue. The answer has been clear. No, they are not. They are not if we continue to put the political situation and human rights issues in the package. But human rights are part of our DNA and we cannot refuse to talk about them. My visit included consultation with Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, meeting with civil society representatives, think tanks and representatives of European business, journalists and a number of European Union ambassadors. I also paid tribute to Boris Nemtsov, who was murdered six years ago, shot to death on a bridge near the Kremlin. His tragic assassination, never clarified, was a warning of what we are seeing now.  This struggle was taking place in a particularly tense context, and this visit presented obvious risks. I took them. I took them, on the one hand because we condemned the handling of the Navalny affair and, on the other, because it allowed me to assess, first-hand, the challenges of engaging with Russia. I had no illusions before the visit. I am even more worried afterwards. What do I take from my interaction? First, the Russian Government is going down a worrisome authoritarian route. The space for civil society and freedom of expression continues to narrow and there seems to be almost no room for the development of democratic alternatives. The Russian authorities have shown in the Navalny case that they are merciless in stifling any such attempts. Indeed, the current power structure in Russia – I would like to talk about the ‘power structure’ in Russia, not about Russia because Russia is the Russian people – combining vested economic interests, military and political control leaves no opening for the democratic rule of law. The strong pushback on any discussion related to human rights and democratic values indicates that they consider this to be an existential threat. Second, the visit confirmed the long—running trend whereby Russia is disconnected from Europe with little or no progress on conflicts in our common neighbourhood, and, as I said, they are disconnected because they consider our liberal democratic system as an existential threat to them.  During my meeting with Minister Lavrov, the discussion became heated as I called for Mr Navalny’s immediate and unconditional release, as well as for a full and impartial investigation into his assassination attempt. I also asked him if I could meet Alexei Navalny. They addressed me to the court. This was impossible due to time constraints and the fact that Mr Navalny was sitting in front of the court at that time, but a senior member of my delegation met with Mr Navalny’s lawyer during the visit and we will continue maintaining contacts with the team to signify our support.  We also had exchanges on foreign policy issues. I insisted on the need to advance toward full implementation of the Minsk agreements, to fully respect Ukraine’s territorial integrity. I underline the need to heed the call of the people of Belarus to freely choose their President.  However, on a few issues, notably on the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), we have managed to establish effective cooperation over the past years. There may be other issues, such as supporting Israeli—Palestinian dialogue, where we could expand our engagement, but the overall environment of the visit did not allow us to explore this further. In my exchange, one thing became clear: there is no intention on the Russian side to engage in a constructive discussion if we address human rights and political freedom. The news of the expulsion of three diplomats on the basis of unfounded allegations came when we were ending our talks and they didn’t come through an announcement from the Russian side. We heard it from the networks. I understood it was a clear message. The meeting was over. I asked Mr Lavrov to reverse his decision, but to no avail. That same night, I issued a statement denouncing such a confrontational move.  Now, allow me to look at the conclusions I draw from the visit. I’m very concerned about the perspective of the Russian authorities’ geostrategic choices and the implications of the action they will have for us and for Russian society. We are at a crossroads in our relations with Russia and the choices that we make will determine the international power dynamics in this century, and notably whether we will advance towards more cooperative or towards more polarised models, based on closed or on free societies.  First, we will discuss this issue at the Foreign Affairs Council on 22 February and at the European Union Council in March. There we will provide guidance on the way forward and it will be for Member States to decide the next step, but, yes, this could include sanctions. I will put forward concrete proposals, using the right of initiative that the High Representative has. Containment efforts should include combining robust actions against disinformation, cyber-attacks and other possible hybrid challenges. Second, at the same time, despite any difficulty, it is of key importance to preserve a space for official engagement where it is in our interest. Russia remains our biggest neighbour. We must define a modus vivendi that will avoid permanent confrontation. Third, but not last, we must find a way to continue engaging with Russian society. Russia mostly forms a European country and an important part of the Russian population wishes to maintain strong links with the European Union and harbours genuine democratic aspirations. We should not turn our back on them. Maybe the Russian power wants to disengage and to disconnect from Europe, but we should not disconnect from Russian civil society, from the Russian people.  We have to find a way to advance on these issues and, in doing so, to preserve our unity and determination. Without unity, there will not be determination and, without determination, we will not be able to address a good policy. Russia has been trying to divide us. They seek to divide us. They haven’t succeeded. On Ukraine and on human rights issues, they haven’t succeeded in dividing us. This seemed to be a clear objective during my visit. We should not fall into these traps. On my side, I will continue defending the need to speak and maintain open channels of communication, looking each other in the eye, especially on issues that are conflictual. Defending Navalny’s rights in Moscow when his trial was unfolding is a way of showing that foreign policy cannot be reduced to issuing written statements from a safe distance, from my office in the Berlaymont or the External Action Service. I think it was important to show our concerns, directly in person, at the right moment and in the right place. I hope this discussion will provide enlightenment for the future decisions of the European Union Council and to look forward to how to handle our relationship with Russia.  (Applause)

name: Michael GAHLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the High Representative’s consultations in Moscow must serve as an eye-opener for all those who had illusions about the real character and policies of the Kremlin. The visit as such, High Representative, but especially the infamous press conference, sparked outrage among many of my colleagues in the PPE Group, and you will hear this later. The behaviour of Foreign Minister Lavrov was unfriendly, uncooperative and unacceptable. We duly noted that you put forward several points of our concern: the demand for the release of Aleksei Navalny and the 10 000 arrested citizens, the Russian aggression in states in our immediate neighbourhood. But, was it not to be expected that Lavrov would produce an attack on the EU? It would have been appropriate to address the long list of Russian misbehaviour in response and to rebuff Lavrov’s ‘What about-ism’ on Latvia, Cuba and Catalonia? Russia is the aggressor in Ukraine and elsewhere, not us. Russian authorities have people murdered at home and abroad, not us. Russia secures dictators in power, not us. Things are now crystal clear: no more wishful thinking; no more appeasement. This Russian leadership does not seek dialogue, even less so before the Duma elections. These Russian leaders are adversaries of the EU and want to divide us. We Europeans must now act together and defend our values and interests. We demand a clear message of unity and determination from the Council and our leaders. We expect Member States to allow use to be made of the European Magnitsky Act – you said you will initiate it, thank you very much.  Let every judge and prosecutor playing their role in political trials against opposition and peaceful demonstrators feel they have booked a place on our sanctions list; and then grill the big fish, the profiteers and big supporters of the regime. Let them feel the same: no more trips to the EU; an asset freeze; real anti-money laundering action in all of our Member States. In parallel, let us step up support and dialogue with civil society. Our interests and cooperation were genuine, so must now be our resolve.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, what we witnessed in the case of Navalny is ‘Kafka: Year 2021’. After having failed to kill him, he had to be put away. Navalny is seen as a threat because he puts his finger on the sore spot. Russians have had enough of Putin’s kleptocracy, while ordinary people face economic hardships.  Moscow abused the visit of High Representative Borrell to humiliate and offend the European Union. It expelled three diplomats during his visit, and Lavrov called the EU an ‘unreliable partner’, while Russia is doing everything to divide us. But to put the blame on Borrell for this? Would it also have happened if the EU leaders had taken a tougher stance? But instead, the Council has so far failed to put any meaningful sanctions on Russia after the assassination attempt on Navalny. Orbán prevented the EU from issuing a joint statement. The Cypriot government has been issuing golden passports to Kremlin enablers for years. French President Macron just recently renewed his call for a dialogue with Moscow, and last Saturday Moscow resumed work on Nord Stream 2, with the support of German Chancellor Merkel. Colleagues, what we need is a united strategy on Russia, not an appeasement, in view of the challenges Russia is posing to our security. This means that the Council will have to come with clear and tough sanctions against Putin and his enablers, and I believe Mr Borrell has drawn the same conclusions.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Vice-President and High Representative, your visit to Moscow at this time was, in my view, a mistake. The Renew Group pointed out that the wisest thing to do would be to postpone it if you don't have the margin of action to put pressure on Navalny's release from prison.  Obviously, keeping diplomatic channels open is important, we do not deny it, but an official visit to Russia in such a tense context is also a symbolic gesture. But this visit has, in our view, given the wrong diplomatic signal.  The coherence and strength of the messages that the European Union sends about Russia are extremely important for those fighting for democracy in Moscow, but also in the eastern Partnership countries. You went to Moscow directly in a media trap mounted by Putin's regime, just two days after Navalny's conviction and hundreds of arrests by protesters.  Under Putin's leadership, Moscow too often trampled on international law and the rights of its own citizens. Illegally annexed Crimea, maintains conflicts, organizes cyber attacks against our institutions. Russia commands assassinations across the Union and carries out disinformation campaigns against Europe. I know that, Mr. Vice President, even from the Reports of the External Action Service. You cannot say that you did not know how sensitive such a visit was in these circumstances. By expelling three European diplomats during your visit, the Kremlin has once again shown us, as you mentioned, that it is not yet interested in a constructive relationship with the European Union.  For years we have been trying to build strong, influential and credible European diplomacy. The visit to Moscow, in these circumstances, and its consequences have unfortunately affected the credibility of the Union as a factor of diplomatic influence. We now have consequences to repair and a lot of lessons that I hope we all learn from what happened.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Mr High Representative, intellectually, we come from different political families and I have never failed in this Chamber to point out that sometimes your initiatives seem questionable to me. But this time, I'd like to pay tribute to you. Your recent trip to Moscow was, I think, courageous, realistic and necessary. Yes, I am one of those who believe that the European Union cannot have unified diplomacy. You saw it yourself, since your allies were all ready to stick a knife in your back when your movement wasn't even over. Inconsequentic enlargement, constitutionalized Atlanticism, a public desire to return to the Cold War now prohibit the European Union from adopting a realistic policy. So you had little chance of success and it was certain that Russia, so regularly insulted by the European institutions, would not give you a gift. That is precisely why it was necessary to take this risk, to go to Moscow and to make contact with our Russian partners. That is precisely why we had to get out of hypocrisy. If Europe looks towards the Atlantic, it must also look towards the East, at least as far as the Urals, according to General de Gaulle's formula. It is obvious that we are not naïve and we know that Russia will pursue its interests in its relations with Brussels. It is a matter of stopping pursuing, as far as we are concerned, the interests of other countries in our relations with Moscow. To say these simple things is to want a policy of independence and dignity for our Member States. To say these simple things is to affirm that we must stop being the laughing stock of the world by giving moral lessons to the whole world, while we continue to make sweet eyes to Turkey or Pakistan. Foreign policy is a matter of power. The Russian power is here. Germany knows this with Nord Stream. France knows this in the Middle East and Africa. The European Union is rediscovering this by admitting that the Sputnik V vaccine may soon be needed. Colleagues, Joe Biden began his presidency by saying "America is back." The right policy for us would be to say 'Europe is free'.

text: No interties, the speeches have been distributed.

name: Sergey LAGODINSKY
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In politics as well as in diplomacy, personal experience is a precious treasure. You, Mr Borrell, have had very special personal experience over the last few days. Fortunately, these experiences were not comparable to the experiences of many Russians who have gained their experience in recent weeks. Yes, Mr Mariani, we are looking at Russia as far as Vladivostok. And who do we see? People who have been arrested, beaten. People like Aljona Kitaeva, a woman, an activist who was strangled with a plastic bag until she pulled the PIN word out of her phone. People like Margarita Judina from St. Petersburg, who was kicked with boots until she landed in the intensive care unit. And then she was also urged to refrain from her complaint. Your experience, Mr Borrell, was special, but they were one thing: you were sobering and degrading, not only for you, but also for us and also for the Member States, for Berlin, for Paris, for the national governments on whose behalf you travelled. And now is the time to draw conclusions from this visit. In other words, we must stop cooperating with Putin's allies of all stripes. We must put an end to the saleability of people like Gerhard Schroeder. We must launch anti-corruption offensives in the EU. We need to think about sanctions. And yes, we also need to think about stopping Nord Stream 2. And I say this not only to your address and not so much to your address, but to Berlin and Paris. Because there are those responsible.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I say to Mr Borrell: I reiterate my position delivered to you before this unfortunate visit. I maintain this position, of course. You decided, under the influence of major Member States, Markus Ederer –considered to be a so-called Russia-understanding politician – and advisors within the Council and the Commission, to go there and were led into a trap carefully prepared by Sergei Lavrov. You decided to do this against the advice of countries of my region and politicians in the European Parliament over political divisions. You, by this trip, actually strengthened the regime in the run-up to a parliamentary election and you denied a trace of hope for the heavily-fighting Russian opposition.  You communicated your strong messages eye to eye, allowing Lavrov to deliver his lies and arrogance to millions of people all over the world, also seeing your humiliation in this effect. We know that you achieved something, that is to boost your personal position, because your personal position in attempts to reinvigorate the JCPOA is well known. In this course of events, you decided to consult with Moscow rather than the US, and during this endeavour you allowed Lavrov to actually offend our allies and our friends like Ukraine and others. It was a really bad mistake. You have to... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Clare DALY
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, listening to the relentless Russiaphobia in this place, why are people surprised that Russia sees no point in engaging with the EU? I’m as happy as anybody else to stand up for anybody’s rights, including Navalny’s. But let’s be honest about him. He’s a vicious, anti—immigrant racist with maybe four percent of the support, rallying hundreds and thousands in cities of millions – hardly a mass movement. We wouldn’t be discussing him at all if he’d been arrested anywhere else other than in Russia. Meanwhile, Julian Assange has been incarcerated for almost ten years for exposing US war crimes. We can’t mention his name. Tomorrow, Pablo Hasél, a Catalan rapper, is going to prison for his lyrics. Where is the call to sanction Spain? Tomorrow, 62-year-old Clare Grady is going to prison in West Virginia for her role in the non-violent Plowshares action against Trident. Where is the demand to break off links with the US, or the outcry about the hundreds of people arrested in this city on a protest a week ago? Nowhere – because this isn’t about human rights. This is a geopolitical agenda against Russia, fuelled by a military industrial complex who need an enemy to justify their millions. Of course, you’re right to go to Russia; we should be engaged in dialogue, not war. (Noise)

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: May I ask that we remain calm here anyway. It is very important that everyone respects the speaking time that your group has given you.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, you, Mr Borrell should have told Minister Lavrov that he’s wrong. That Spain does not have three political prisoners, but has nine. That it cannot be compared to Navalny, because he has been sentenced to three and a half years in prison and the Catalan leaders have been sentenced from nine to thirteen years in prison for organising a referendum. We have warned that the double standard applied by the EU undermines its global credibility as a defender of freedoms. There are now humiliating consequences for all. The EU cannot go around the world recommending recipes that it does not apply to itself.  I want a Europe with a strong voice for human rights and without complexes in front of anyone, not only in front of Russia, not only in front of the United States, China, Morocco or Turkey, but with anyone. You are not that voice Mr Borrell. Mr Borrell, please do a Borrell exit.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Madam President, let’s remember that the main blame for the fiasco of this visit lies with Russia – it is Russia that was rude and perfidious towards our High Representative – but nevertheless, this visit was a mistake. This was predictable and it was predicted, and, High Representative, you didn’t go with the full support of all the Member States. If you wanted to hear what you heard from Mr Lavrov you could have met him on the margins of OSCE or the UN, where the environment would not have been controlled by the Russians. They just obviously can’t help but show their bad manners towards Western representatives.  We are not supplicants of Russia – it is Russia that needs the lifting of our sanctions – and while Russia is still occupying the territory of its neighbours, while it’s murdering people in our streets, while it’s interfering in our political processes and, above all, while it’s repressing its own people, this was not a good time to go. We need a sign from Russia that they are willing to change their policy. And then, of course, we should always show them the so-called ‘off-ramp’ away from authoritarianism.  But I hope that this experience has inspired you to a better understanding of us in central Europe, and I’m counting on you to support sanctions against Russia while their bad behaviour continues.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, High Representative, the human rights situation in Russia is deteriorating on an unprecedented scale. Thousands of peaceful protesters are being detained and their right to demonstrate is being suppressed without valid legal arguments. Large-scale countrywide demonstrations are creating internal problems that are always easier to externalise.  As we witnessed last week, Russia is not open towards hearing the facts being raised directly, either by their citizens or by foreign representatives. It is easy to conclude that our relations with Russia are at a very low point. We should put in use additional targeted sanction measures through a global human rights sanction mechanism and continue seeking options on how to better assist civil society organisations.  Finally, we have to adopt a new, substantial and comprehensive strategy towards Russia. While working on this, the EU should not keep falling into political traps, further narrowing space for our political actions, but rather strengthen common foreign and security policy. Energy overdependence, divergent strategies of the Member States towards a vaccine, and Russia’s very active role in disinformation campaigns and support for anti-European forces should be on our ‘to do’ list for the next Council meeting.  Prevailing particular interests are only a great opportunity for Russia to impose further leverage. We should re-examine and put an end to the ongoing projects that undermine the credibility of the European Union as a whole.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Madam President, with an ounce of intelligence, he could have grasped the message of Josep Borrell's mere arrival. With an ounce of lucidity, he could have understood that, of course, of course, we totally condemned and condemned, and would say it loud and clear, the judicial harassment inflicted on Alexei Navalny and the arrest also of the demonstrators who support him, but at the same time we wanted to keep open bridges with Russia, especially on Iran. Nothing is more legitimate and easy to understand than this positioning. But what Mr. Putin understood was that he had to behave like a little terror of a playground to tell the world and Russia that he did not fear us. Well, Mr Putin, it's a failure. By behaving so badly, you have only let your panic show. The one that now blinds you because the Russian opposition has found its figurehead. Because you're losing your footing in the states of your old empire. Because your popularity is waning and this one-on-one with China to which your blindness condemns your country, no one wants it in Russia, neither the great fortunes, nor the security forces, nor the urban middle classes. You're losing your hand, Mr. Putin. And if your end of reign can be long and painful, it has opened. You open it with your obvious panic.

name: Filip DE MAN
text: Mr President, the EU representative wanted to lecture the Russians, but he came back from a barren journey. Lavrov simply felt that the EU was not too difficult with domestic affairs, and that is a principle that forms the basis for diplomatic relations. It is painful, but mr Borrell, of the Spanish Socialists, does not see the bar in his own eye. He wanted to hijack the Russians over the Navalny trial and pick up protesters. However, Mr Borrell received a njet from President Putin, who was elected with 76% of the vote, more than any head of state in the EU can say.  Meanwhile, in the same EU, Catalan politicians are either in prison or even not getting their elected seat in the European Parliament. And this with the agreement of the President of this Parliament, also a socialist. The fundamental right to argue should not be blown too high off the tower here either. In my country, 500 people were arrested last week for arguing against the many deprivations of liberty carried out by the Belgian government because of corona. In the Netherlands, the government even used violence against innocent protesters who stood up for their freedoms. I'm just saying, Mr. Borrell: swipe on your own doorstep before waving your moralizing finger elsewhere.

name: Markéta GREGOROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I don’t have questions for Mr Borrell as, Mr Borrell, you won’t answer me anyway, anymore. Instead, I want to speak about what is important right now: the thousands of Russians in the streets being beaten and detained and many more of them that don’t want a corrupted government and hoped for support from the international community. With your ill—executed visit, you not only ashamed European citizens, you also helped Putin and harmed the Russian people. You provided a mafia state with more images and sound bites to make us look weak and corrupt, and make the Kremlin’s regime look legitimate. You also failed to visit Navalny or at least support him during his trial.
