A missed opportunity to back up the EU’s strong claims about this case and to bring at least a little dignity through this visit. For this public damage, you should step down from your post immediately.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Naivety in relations with Russia is an inexcusable sin, but I would nevertheless prefer your visit to Moscow to be motivated by inexerence and gullifiability, rather than by anyone's incomprehensible belief that Vladimir Putin can be persuaded to do something. The worst fears of the Member States, including the Polish, have been met, warning that this trip will only harm our existing sanctions policy, which, while not ideal, seemed resolute and thoughtful.  Your visit has undermined these efforts. The impression has arisen that, regardless of Russia's attitude towards human rights, repression of the opposition, attacks on its own citizens or violations of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of our neighbours, we are ready to normalize our relations. Well, we are not and should not. Is it true that you talked to Minister Lavrov about the possibility of cooperation on cybersecurity when Russian hackers attack our institutions every day?  In 1945, Moscow was visited by former prime Polish of the emigration government, Stanisław Mikolajczyk. Four streets away from the Kremlin, the trial of 16 leaders of the Polish Underground State, its recent subordinates, took place at the same time. Mikolajczyk was humiliated, but at least 2 years delayed the introduction of Stalinism in Poland. He was humiliated, but he did not lose his face. And the Lord? What was worth such humiliation in Moscow? European diplomats were expelled during your conference with Minister Lavrov. Even at this point, you could not stop this shameful visit. And the virtue the Lord lost and the ruble did not earn.  Señor alto representante, les ha dejado burlarse de usted.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell, free opposition and a free civil society are the basic prerequisites for a free society. Both have been suppressed in Russia, have been for a long time.  The visit of the High Representative leads to the unfortunate conclusion that the Russian political leadership has hardened its grip and is moving in an even more authoritarian direction and thus dining away from Europe, but we must nevertheless strive for a common context. The EU must defend human rights and democracy in all its activities with all partners. There is no way to compromise on this under any circumstances. We must continue to call for Navalny's release and for the opposition to have the freedom to take action. The Russians themselves must be allowed to choose their political leadership and be allowed to do so freely, without fear of a manhunt. The demand that Russia respect human rights and fundamental freedoms comes from international human rights treaties and obligations. It is not a political attempt to interfere in the internal affairs of another country;

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Madam President, the opposition leader Navalny is showing immense courage, testing the waning leadership of Putin. This brave man and the entire opposition need our full support. Mr Borrell on the other hand, made a fool of himself last week in Moscow. By his actions, he made a mockery of the ambition of the EU to play a major role on the world stage. His actions are, I’m sorry to say, in line with several recent ill—considered actions of the Commission. However, let us remember, we are able to criticise our political leaders freely – a right that every human has, but in many countries is trampled on by so-called political leaders and tyrants. Mr Nevalny is on a mission. He should have our support. The unfortunate actions of Mr Borrell must not distract us from the principle that is at stake here: freedom.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Mr High Commissioner, High—Representative, we strongly condemn the decision to prosecute Aleksei Navalny. We strongly condemn the attempt to murder Navalny. We strongly condemn the repression of demonstrations that took place all across the territory of Russia. We strongly condemn the unacceptable expulsion of three European Union diplomats and we strongly condemn the cynical attitudes of Foreign Minister Lavrov. We praise the courage and the resilience of the Russian people, of the Russian opposition, of the Russian civil society. We praise in particular the courage of Aleksei Navalny, of his family, of his supporters. High—Representative Mr Josep Borrell: because we strongly condemn the Russian authorities’ behaviour and their authoritarian regime; because we praise the extraordinary bravery of the Russian people and oppositionists, we deeply regret your vision and your actions in such an important, decisive and sensitive file. We deeply regret your decision to go to Moscow. We deeply regret your unfortunate and condescending declarations. We deeply regret that you did not have the courage to face eye-to-eye Mr Lavrov’s unacceptable stance. Mr Borrell, don’t get us wrong, the European Union peoples and this House, the European Parliament, will never give up. We will be always on the side of the Russian people’s aspiration for freedom and democracy. For some reason, our human rights prize is the Sakharov Prize. We shall never surrender. (Applause)

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, we are talking a lot about Mr Borrell and less about Russia, which is something that will surely be pleasing the Kremlin, as we will be able to read tonight in the pro-Putin media. The same smile with which they received the gift of the letter asking for Mr. Borrell's resignation, which is in itself a success of Putin and which is why he should only make his promoters reflect. When the sage points to the moon, some look at the finger. Let's look at the moon!  The awkward thing is to go to Moscow to defend our values and Mr. Navalni. The easy thing is to put a tweet from the sofa at home or write a letter. We want mature European diplomacy that uses the language of power and we are astonished when we exercise it with all the consequences. Also with the uncomfortable consequences, as in this case. The gestures have been aggression towards Europe and, instead of already thinking about our response, we spend a few days feeding a division that, I repeat with all the letters, only favors Russia. When the European Union has been armed by AstraZeneca, we have closed ranks with the Commission and have made an exhibition of unity and strength. Would it have been helpful to ask for Mr. Dombrovskis' resignation in the face of this threat? I don't think so. It would have been easy, but unfair. We closed ranks because the problem had been created by another: a pharmacist and not the Commission; and because we decided not to give anyone an image of disunity to which the Socialists will in no way contribute.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Madam President, I would like to ask Mr Borrell whether he knows how a bear is tamed. Once you try, you’d better be prepared, by bringing a pot of honey and a big stick, because the moment the bear senses that you’re not in control, he attacks. If you’re lucky, the bear only hurts you badly, but often their attacks are lethal.  Last Friday, the Russian bear badly roughed you up, Mr Borrell. Your disastrous visit to Moscow damaged you personally. But even worse is the damage done to the EU as a whole. We have never looked so weak and clueless about how to deal with Russia. I even fear that our relations with Russia are worse than before your visit, and that’s not good.  There are colleagues in this House who want to finish the bear’s job and send you home. I don’t think you must step down. But today it’s clear that Parliament is giving you a yellow card. Let this humiliating experience be a lesson. We must agree, colleagues, on a clear strategy on how to engage with Russia – a strategy supported by both the Council and this Parliament, so that next time, Mr Borrell, you are prepared and have a real chance to tame the bear.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her No plenary in this House without praise for the rule of law in the EU and accusations of lack of it all over the world. Indicted today, Russia is once again in the Navalny case. What do we know? There is a final Russian verdict for fraud and money laundering with probation, a violation of Navalny's probation conditions and a judicial revocation of probation. The revocation is formally justified and justified, albeit harshly and probably also politically opportune.  But the US would have been very different with Edward Snowden. Probation is revoked thousands of times, including in the EU. We also know politically willing judgments. And the EU has been breaking its own treaties almost every day since 2012, and again just now that I am speaking. This Parliament is currently approving EU debts for EUR 3-quarters of a trillion in breach of the Treaty.  There is evidence that peaceful protests in Moscow have not been so peacefully dispersed by the Russian police – we do not welcome this. However, such images are no stranger to the EU. Just think of the french police's brutal crackdown on the yellow vests.  It would be helpful if the EU and its Member States were to eliminate their own shortcomings in the rule of law before they set themselves up as teachers and moral world champions. The EU is not the best of all possible worlds, nor is it all necessary.  As Voltaire says in response to Leibniz: "Everyone first order his own garden".

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, I really regret having to listen to colleagues in this House, from the extreme right and the extreme left, who show more understanding for the dictatorship of Putin than for our own democracy. This, I must say, as the first sentence.  Mr Borrell, your visit to Moscow was the very opposite of a success. It was a failure, but it is also true that you had been dealt a very bad hand because of the lack of unity in the Council. Russia played foul, so let’s stand up to them. I do object to those that now call for your resignation. The dire situation in EU—Russia relations has deeper roots. Let’s not fall into a trap. Your words, today, Mr Borrell, were strong and severe. I hope they will resonate in Berlin and Paris in particular. But you must fight to turn words into deeds, and you will have us as allies.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: – Madam President, in Moscow Lavrov checkmated High Representative Borrell in four moves. You compromised your credibility, High Representative, damaged your office, and undermined the foreign and security interests of Member States. You did not threaten sanctions or harshly condemn the arrest of Navalny, nor did you censure the aggression in the Ukraine or denounce Russia when they declared our diplomats persona non grata. As a Swede and a northerner, I ask myself: where does this unassertiveness come from? Is it from sheer lack of experience?  Is it that Western and Southern trade and gas contracts trump Northern and Eastern security interests? Please answer this, because for us in the North, this highlights the danger in transferring power over foreign policy to Brussels by abolishing national vetoes. Those who hope that the EU will have their back surely do so in vain. High Representative Borrell, you should resign. We need someone who can play in the grand tournaments.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, thank you. Mr. Borrell, you went to Moscow unprepared for a confrontation with Lavrov. In your speech, you referred to a few generalities, from Russian students, a late Europe from Lisbon to Vladivostok, and finally, you also touched on the issue of the arrest of Navalny and thousands of demonstrators.  For this last point, Lavrov gave you a video illustrating violence in the West, and a journalist questioned you about the issue of Sputnik journalists arrested in Latvia. And for your drift to be complete, you have fallen into the trap of the question about Cuba, which has permanently taken you away from the possibility of giving the necessary and expected messages to European citizens.  Lavrov, for his part, gave the Russian version to all topics of bilateral interest, such as the Eastern Partnership states, the situation in the Caucasus or North Africa, illegal migration, disinformation campaigns, and did not hesitate to compare the US - Cuba with Russia - Ukraine.  Unfortunately, the Union's approach to the themes announced by Lavrov has not been heard by European citizens because Mr Borrell has not spoken it. Finally, Lavrov concluded that the European Union is not a reliable partner, and after the press conference, three diplomats were expelled. We have one solution: not to believe in Moscow, and believe them, colleagues, and the politicians of the east, who tell you what Russia means.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Madam President, the question today is not whether we need to talk to Russia. Of course we do. The real question today is how we talk and what position we assume when we talk. We need to make sure that we talk with Russia from a position of strength and confidence and, above all, moral authority. We must always remember who we are and who it is we are talking to. We are the European Union. We are a leading promoter of democracy, the rule of law and human rights in the world. We are a leading defender of the rules-based international order.  Russia is none of these. It is a country that has, only in this century, waged two offensive wars against its neighbours and continues to occupy parts of their territory, a country that routinely violates international agreements, and a regime that violently suppresses political dissent and peaceful demonstrations. It is a regime whose critics have to fear for their lives, both at home and abroad. We should not ignore that, and we must treat Russia with the same resoluteness we apply to other regimes with a similar track record. Only when our communication with the Kremlin is defined by moral clarity, consistency and unity can we expect to be heard and taken seriously. This applies in similar measure to the EU as a whole and to individual Member States.

name: Elsi KATAINEN
text: – Mr President, High Representative, the situation with Russia is exceptionally difficult. The EU shares a border of 6 000 kilometres with a country which, as domestic political pressure increases, creates confrontation and enemy imagery towards the EU as well. The expulsion of diplomats is one example of this. Although relations between Russia and the EU are now at a low point, the common border is not going away. It is precisely because of the contradictions that the dialogue must be kept open. It is clear that the visit to Moscow was disappointing and completely paceed by the Russians. It is clear, High Representative, that you will be asked for answers for a long time to come as to what was achieved during the visit and what its results were. More importantly, what are the next steps for the EU. Do you believe that the new, carefully chosen sanctions will have tangible effects? Or do we have to put our faith in the will of the new generations of rising Russians to fight for the rule of law in Russia?

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Madam President, Mr Borrell, ladies and gentlemen, in the face of a Russian power that is increasingly mocking democratic rights, I would like to express my support for Alexei Navalny and this repressed but courageous civil society.  Last week, Mr Putin also wanted to make fun of Europe. The treatment of our high representative is indecent. Mr Borrell, surely your visit should have been programmed differently, but the real problem with this provocation is our disunity.  That is why I call for a unity of the 27 Member States and targeted sanctions. That is also why I, along with many Member States, call on Germany to stop Nord Stream 2 today. We need more autonomy from Putin and fossil fuels, not the other way around.  Finally, as the clerical is getting richer, the Russian suffers. Our role is to support people more than ever. It's a priority.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, first a message for all those who have been making grotesque and ridiculous comparisons here between Mr Navalni, a persecuted dissident, a persecuted opponent, and a number of criminals, thieves, coupists, who in Spain have been convicted and are currently campaigning for election. Those in Russia would have been shot by coupists, shot or been put in prisons and then poisoned, so let's not compare what is not comparable. Mr. Borrell, it's your thing to go get wool and get back sheared. He went to Moscow to calm the waters, to get along with them, to seek some formulas of understanding despite the Kremlin's latest barbarities, despite Navalni's, despite imprisoning Navalni, despite poisoning Navalni, despite stopping and systematic beatings in hundreds of cities where such demonstrations are now taking place. He went there, let's remember, as he went to Iran: he went to Iran after a thousand and five hundred dead; thousand five hundred dead and went to rope, too. Now this has gone very wrong: Mr Borrell, you have failed resoundingly.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, we once again need to talk about Russia and tense, difficult relations with the European Union, far from what would be desirable, given our common Europeanity and intense economic and energy exchanges. But the situation is what it is.  The truth is that, despite being a European country that has made commitments as a member of the Council of Europe and the OSCE, Putin's Russia rejects the international order built in recent decades and does not share our vision of a pluralistic democracy and the rule of law. From Moscow, the European Union is perceived with distrust and our positions are considered inconfidable of Russian sovereignty. However, for our part, we cannot renounce eer the so-called liberal international order or respect for human rights, which is one of our hallmarks.  Mr Navalni's case openly highlights the European Union's deep differences with Russia and turned its meeting in Moscow, Mr High Representative, last week into an announced failure. The situation was certainly lousy.  Moreover, Mr Lavrov's provocations were totally unnecessary and the press conference was unfortunate. In these circumstances we cannot be optimistic about the future of the European Union's relations with Russia. In any event, the different positions of the Member States which are due to historical reasons and different economic interests do not augur for the easy adoption by the European Union of drastic or sharp decisions. You have a difficult job ahead of you, Mr. Borrell.  On the other hand, from Washington, the new Biden Administration sends no sign that it will improve relations with Putin. Quite the opposite.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, your humiliation in Moscow must put an end to 20 years of European illusions and powerlessness. For 20 years we have heard the same story in Brussels, in Paris, in Berlin, about the necessary cooperation with this criminal regime. Putin exterminates the Chechens? We have to cooperate! Putin invades Georgia, then Ukraine? We have to cooperate! Putin razes Aleppo, Homs, Idlib? We have to cooperate! Putin kills my friend, my model in life, Anna Politkovskaya, and so many other Russian journalists and opponents? We have to cooperate! Putin funds our right-wing extremes and interferes in our elections? We have to cooperate! It is time to understand that he is the one who does not want to cooperate and that he has nothing but contempt for our weakness. It's time to get out of impotence, to hit where it hurts: the wallet. Let's freeze the assets, seize the yachts, block the money of the oligarchs. Let us show that we are strong and only then will we be respected.

name: Michal ŠIMEČKA
text: – Madam President, I thank Mr Borrell for being here with us to take stock of what might well have been one of the most ill—advised foreign policy trips in the EU’s recent history. Mr Borrell, I share your view that it is important to talk to everyone, including and especially our adversaries or dictators, but without any real leverage — such as a credible threat of new sanctions or suspension of Nord Stream 2, this particular diplomatic visit was never going to advance European interests, and many of us had warned you of that beforehand.  So unfortunately, the trip will not be remembered as a show of support to jailed Russian protesters, but it will be remembered as a moment where the EU’s credibility was weakened, particularly because of the performance of Sergei Lavrov at the press conference. The best we can hope for now, is that it will also be remembered as a wake—up call that finally prompted EU Member States and yourself to adopt a more realistic and principled Russian foreign policy and to move toward sanctions finally.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Europe's neighbourhood is on fire. We are seeing mass arrests of peaceful demonstrators in Russia. We see continued police brutality in Belarus and we are seeing scenes of war from eastern Ukraine. We must do everything we can to support these democracy fighters in our neighbouring countries and continue to fight against those who seek to stifle democracy.  But today we cannot do it fully. In foreign policy, Europe is held back by our fossil dependence – on imported gas, oil and uranium from Russia. Germany's hesitation about Nord Stream is an example of this. It is time we set ourselves free of shackling pipelines and focused on what cuts our dependence on Putin's fossil energy. As long as we depend on Russian energy, we will not be able to have a fully independent and effective foreign policy. That is why we must fight for 100% renewable energy and to support our friends of democracy.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Señora presidenta, señor Borrell, ¿dónde están los cojones de la Unión Europea? I have to ask. I also have to ask where you sat with your head. This was a disaster. Everyone knew Moscow was a mistake, but you went anyway. You were warned that Lavrov would de thingly fool you. Why couldn't you see that?  You also went unprepared to a press conference and then you shot yourself in the foot. Twice: first by attacking our ally the US and the second time by praising the Russian Sputnik vaccine before it was allowed in Europe. The leader of our geopolitical EU should know that Russia will use his vaccine as it uses its energy: as a cynical weapon to divide us.  The EU will never be taken seriously as long as it only responds with words. Autocrats only respect action. So, Mr. Borrell, there is only one way you can fix this disaster: come up with a comprehensive package to sanction Putin's kleptocracy. Do it now or make way for a high representative who can and wants to do so.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, as far as Russia is concerned, many here know that the real villain resides in Moscow. This requires a strong European policy, decisive and with strong wording. And I missed that, Mr. Borrell, last week. You did not go there to lecture Putin, no, on the contrary! You have told our transatlantic allies in Washington what the Americans are all doing wrong in Cuba. And beyond that, what did I miss at that press conference? You did not mention the Russian occupation of Crimea. You did not mention the rude Russian action to ruin the investigation into MH17. You did not talk about tough sanctions that are necessary because Russia has been grossly violating human rights for a long time. And what did we hear about that press co? Praise for the Sputnik vaccine.  Rarely has a journey been so painful, and also a disgrace. During the press conference, Moscow raised a thick middle finger to Mr Borrell and to the EU by expelling three diplomats. I would like to see a different and more decisive European High Representative here.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Madam President, High Representative, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the way in which Relations between Russia and Europe are at their lowest point. And why are they? Because Moscow repeatedly disregards fundamental human rights. Moscow continues to break international law. Navalny, overcrowded prisons because protesters are imprisoned, Ukraine and Belarus and, and, and. The list is long. So was it right to travel to Moscow? Yes, because we need dialogue and diplomacy. Unfortunately, Russia has shown how little interest there is in dialogue. And that, that's the problem. What is needed now is a European strategy. Proceed together and together. Let me say it again: proceed together and together. Implement targeted and effective sanctions. The freezing of accounts, anti-money laundering measures and oligarchs. And it is time to talk seriously about the end of Nord Stream and other projects.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Mr Borrell that, during his hearings in the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) two years ago, he committed to working for a stronger Europe in the world, a global player.  Mr Borrell, you promised a truly integrated EU foreign policy which combines the positions of the Member States, the Commission and this Parliament. After your visit to Moscow, the EU is being portrayed as weak. The EU is being called an unreliable partner. The visit was organised without proper preparations to prevent traps set by the Kremlin and went under a complete Russian script.  The collateral damage and disappointment about the visit is really massive. Maybe it is easiest to explain through the perspective of EU citizens, those inquiries full of regret and criticism about the EU not being able to meet their expectations that I receive. I struggle to provide my fellow EU citizens with a reasonable explanation of why the first diplomat of the European Union went to Moscow against the advice of several Member States and this Parliament, particularly when the visit failed to open the door to freedom for Aleksei Navalny and to halt the violence against peaceful protesters in Russia.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It's time to end this theater of hypocrisy. Well, in your words, you condemn Putin, and everything he does, i.e. trying to poison his opponents, put them in jail, attack his neighbors, create a totalitarian system that destroys citizens' freedom. Yet when it comes to action, you do the opposite: build Nord Stream 2 with it, which not only destroys European values and European solidarity, but also gives Putin a tool to blackmail other countries.  And in addition, the head of European diplomacy demonstratively goes to Moscow at a time when he is condemned Nawalny. It is time to decide, Europe: either you support values such as solidarity and freedom or Putin's interests. Enough of these theatrical gestures. Pause Nord Stream 2 or finally stop telling us about values. Deeds, not words, dear Europo!

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, Putin’s regime gave us a lesson and we should be grateful for that. It is evident that EU policy towards Russia should go through a deep strategic revision. I have prepared a list of ten major points for review of the strategy, with immediate, medium-term and longer-term actions. First point, no more illusions about Putin’s regime. Putin will not be different, but Russia can become different. Second, the EU has to impose immediate sanctions on those from the regime who are responsible for the Navalny case. Third, the EU immediately has to stop the Nord Stream 2 project. Fourth, the EU has to move in relations with Russia from the ‘Putin first’ to the ‘Democracy first’ paradigm. Fifth, the EU should put the defence of democracy at the same priority level as the fight against climate change. Sixth, the EU needs to agree with the new US administration that the global defence of democracy should be top priority.  Seventh, before the Russian Duma elections, introduction of new type of preventive sanctions against stealing and bribing elections. Eighth, the launch of justice hubs for the people of Belarus and Russia on the territory of EU countries. Ninth, much larger-scale EU investments into the success of Eastern Partnership countries, which can inspire Russian people. And tenth, the EU needs to have a strategic vision of its future relations with democratic Russia, which could also inspire Russian people.  Based on these ten points, the EU can change its policy on Russia. EU policy change will help Russia to change itself. (Applause)

name: Robert BIEDROŃ
text: – Madam President, High Commissioner, when mass protests broke out in Belarus, we drew attention to the fact that there is too much talk and not enough action from the EU regarding, of course, foreign policy. Even if we had the best diplomats, there is little they could do because of the lack of a unanimous approach towards Russia. The new EU sanctions mechanism should be revised by deleting the unanimity rule in the council. We need also to enlarge the sectional restrictive measures against the Russian Federation. The European Union cannot remain idle in the face of all the human rights violations in Russia. What we need is a new horizontal strategy towards Russia. What we need is a common, firm approach towards Russia. This is what we need.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, the role of the High Representative is to interact and engage with his counterparts from other countries, even in difficult times and on problematic topics. But this visit to Moscow had an extremely bad timing. Despite EU calls on Russia to refrain from arresting opposition leader Navalny and to stop the harassment of demonstrators, Russia does exactly the opposite and the EU is advised to keep its mouth shut. By expelling EU diplomats on the same day as the visit and by publicly stating that the EU is not a reliable partner, Russia has confirmed once again that it does not wish to mend the relations with the EU and the EU must build on this knowledge. The level of naivety towards Russia in Europe should be kept low. Russia has made its geopolitical choices for now. Hopefully the EU will draw quick conclusions about what happened: among others, the inclusion of human rights violators on the sanctions list and the suspension of Nord Stream 2, which is contrary to European energy security policy.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab One of the greatest humiliations in the history of the European Union's foreign policy. Spectacular image failure. Sad performance. Russia is making a fool of the Union. These are the reactions of politicians and the media to the visit of the head of European diplomacy, Josep Borrell, to Moscow, who was trapped there and publicly scolded by Sergei Lavrov as a student. Poland and the Baltic States warned against the visit. The warnings turned out to be all too true. The Lord did not listen. Is it because there are no experts in Eastern politics in your cabinet? Or are Russia's allies in the Union in the background: Germany or France seeking to reset relations with Moscow in the name of its ad hoc interest at the expense of the interests of the Union and other Member States, not to mention human rights in Russia? You have overestimed your own abilities. It is pride, pride, which often prompts politicians of the old Union to induce ex-cathedral of the state of Central and Eastern Europe. This time, the Union got what it deserved, and unfortunately it bowed its tail under itself. What lessons from this failure? Further sanctions, while obvious, will not produce the expected results. Today, the only adequate response to Russia's confrontational attitude is to stop nord stream 2 investment.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, High Representative, as a former diplomat, I deeply regret the expulsion of three European diplomats by the Russian Federation. This decision is completely unfounded. Why do we have a Vienna Convention on diplomatic relations? A diplomat is entitled to assess the developments in the receiving State and to report to the government of the sending State. When diplomats are hindered by a State from objectively observing a democratic protest, profound questions can be posed on the functioning of that State, on the compliance with the rule of law, on the respect for democracy and human rights. Our relations with Russia are at a low point. A European strategic approach is more than necessary. We must prevent further deterioration, show readiness to respond with sanctions, but also a willingness to rebuild ways towards renewed dialogue. Please let diplomacy do its job, because we know what happens when diplomacy ends.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Dear President, honourable colleagues, last week's visit to Russia by European Union High Representative Jospo Borrell raised many doubts. It is clear that the Kremlin's aggressive policy no longer meets Russian citizens, as evidenced by mass protests, and Navalno's poisoning and imprisonment for almost three years is a blanuous violation of international law and an example of a political crackdown. We see with our own eyes how the Kremlin continues to try to downplay and eliminate any resistance or opposition. The Kremlin took advantage of the European Union and our image when, during the visit, german, Swedish and Polish diplomats were asked from Russia. You, High Representative Josep Borrelli, had to express your call for the release of Alexei Navalny during the joint press conference, as well as to respond to the russian Foreign Minister's remarks on the annexation of Crimea and other issues on which we have expressed a firm stance in the European Parliament. Unfortunately, we have not heard from the European Union's tougher position. At the moment, we are calling for severe and precise sanctions against the Kremlin regime and we call on the European member states currently looking at the Kremlin's aggression to respond to what is happening at the EU border.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Mr Borell, i would like to thank you for your support. You went to Russia last week. You went to Putin, who just threw his strongest rival in prison after failing to poison him. You went to Russia, which locked up over a thousand demonstrators. You went there empty-handed and unprepared.  In Moscow, it should have been obvious that the EU will tighten sanctions so that it stings, that the EU condemns human rights violations, threats and harassment against journalists and activists, that Alexei Navalny must be released, that cooperation such as Nord Stream 2 should be stopped.  All these things that Putin doesn't like. But we don't like Putin's policies. At the same time, among other things, a Swedish diplomat was thrown out of Russia. The visit can only be described as a fiasco. Much went wrong in Moscow, but the biggest error was that the trip actually took place.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, serve as a guide for future dialogues with regimes such as Venezuela, Cuba, Turkey or Iran. The obsession, after all, of all of them is to end our democratic European system of principles and values. History repeats itself, said a companion of mine: fascism and communism, extreme left and right pulling—and funded by our regimes—here to Russia today. There is the vice president of the Government of Spain, of my own country, Pablo Iglesias, funded in the past by Venezuela and Iran and now acting as spokesman for the Putin regime in his daily task of undermining Spain's prestige and eroding the democratic system that cost us so much effort, sweat and tears. And in the Spanish case, of course, not a step back from Russian interference supporting racist and exclusionary nationalisms in Spain and Catalonia. Mr Borrell, we must sit down with the democratic opposition in Russia and support them. And to do this you have to resort to the only weapon that these gangsters understand: sanctions already. Here I have heard many colleagues talk about Mr Borrell's resignation, but I have heard very little about sanctions, which are a thousand times much more effective. It's enough to hide behind the European Commission. We must make public at the next European Council who is in favour and where unanimity is in imposing sanctions on Russia. And whoever is not, to say it publicly and to face the consequences of Democratic European public opinion. The time for soft diplomacy has passed. It is time for European political leadership, which, together with the new US administration, has a duty to defend our democracies and freedoms.

name: Eero HEINÄLUOMA
text: – Mr President, Mr Borrell has been criticised by some colleagues for going to Moscow. But did our representative, Mr Borrell, Vice-President of the Commission, not carry out the very task for which we have elected him, that is to say, to take forward the European Union's unified message of our opinion on Russia's activities? We have condemned Navalny's poisoning, we have condemned his arrest and we are calling for civil rights to be respected, so this is a line that must be taken by the Union and united. It became clear to us that Russia is now distancing itself from European values, and that is what we are having to react to. This means that discussions on sanctions on human rights issues will resend. To this end, we adopted a new mechanism for deciding on personal sanctions. The EU must now move forward in a unified manner and point the blame where they belong and not blame its own Commissioners.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Madam President, Mr Borrell, a popular Russian saying that was heard a lot in Moscow this weekend basically says: 'Who too hastens is at risk of being mocked'. And unfortunately, it's hard to say anything else today. The fiasco was announced everywhere, by us in particular, and the trap of Putin and Lavrov skilfully orchestrated. We are always in favour of dialogue, of course. But your trip to Moscow did not advance Alexei Navalny's cause one iota, nor did he advance the cause of human rights in Russia. You said - I have listened to you religiously - that you want to speak to the Russians, and you are right, that is essential. That is the challenge of tomorrow. Talking to the Russians, talking to these young people, by the thousands on the street and who have basically only known Putin in power. But I'm not sure how this mess speaks to them today. One last thing, even if I am the devil's advocate in this debate. It must be noted that you were caught between the hammer and the anvil, between our ambition, your ambition surely, and the reluctance of the Member States. All this to say that it is the office of high representative that must be reinvented by the Conference on the Future of Europe.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, High Representative, it is with regret and a sense of shame that I stand here today speaking of last week’s events. Unfortunately, Mr Borrell, your visit to Russia has demonstrated that reaching out to Moscow under the current circumstances is not only futile, it is dangerous. The last thing we need to hear from a European politician speaking in Moscow today is a criticism of our ally in Washington. When I see the frustration of the Belarussian and Russian people and the unstoppable force of Lukashenko and Putin’s regimes, I expect from the representative of European diplomacy clear messages about sanctions, political prisoners, disinformation, Russia’s dirty money, and its attempts to undermine the European way of life.  I want to convey my sincere support to those fighting for democracy and fundamental rights in the streets of Minsk, Moscow and other cities and towns across Belarus and Russia. Russia is a regime that kills and jails its political opponents. The European Union cannot engage with it in a manner of business as usual. And, by the way, our messages to Russia also have foreign policy implications for actions in our neighbourhood and in the Western Balkans. Believe me, the fight for the European hearts and minds of our neighbours will be easier with clear red lines towards Moscow.  I wish sincerely that we did not need to have this debate today for Europe’s biggest opponent in our relations with Russia sits in Moscow. Let us not give him any more comfort. Let’s stand up to Russia’s dark side, united, and in clear defence of Europe’s values and interests.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, it is as cold in Brussels as it is in Moscow, but that does not mean that we will be trembling in front of Mr Putin. High Representative, let me say that you were not well prepared for this journey and underestimated Russia's reality, the power structure, as you yourself said today. You may have gone to Moscow with a vision to establish constructive dialogue as some Member States call for it. But it's time to pour some pure wine. Your visit has also shown that Russia, with its current leadership, is not a credible partner, because Putin sees us, in the European Union, as an enemy. Instead of being held accountable for the Russian regime forcibly suppressing the democratic opposition, for locking up students, the Russian Foreign Minister is lecturing us on what democracy in the European Union should look like. And, unfortunately, you watched in silence as the diplomats of the Member States were expelled.  It is not about criticising you today, because I think we are aiming for a common goal. We have missed a chance to show the way to the future for real partnership and dialogue. This journey begins with the release of political prisoners and free elections. These must be our terms. This debate of ours today is supposed to be about what we are going to do for this future. You yourself have acknowledged that your journey has not been successful and that you have learned your lesson. And I appreciate that statement. The European Union must also learn its lesson and must rebound. It must introduce sanctions against those responsible for navalny's imprisonment, stop the Nord Stream 2 project and unequivocally support the democratic direction of the EaA countries.

name: Rasa JUKNEVIČIENĖ
text: – Madam President, even before the visit to Moscow, it was clear that the Kremlin would mock.  However, today I think the visit was needed. Why? After Black Friday in Moscow a different understanding must come in the EU. Putin will not change. Russia will change, but not Putin.  First of all, we need to stop thinking of Russia as Putin’s Russia. We need to think about the people in Russia. Putin is the biggest threat to the Russian people. Putin is the world’s largest Russophobe because he is afraid of Russians.  The change in EU policy must aim for changes in Russia. After decades of dreaming of a Europe from Lisbon to Vladivostok, we must realise that such a Europe is impossible if we build it with the Kremlin regime. A democratic Europe from Lisbon to Vladivostok, without Lukashenko, without Putin – is a dream I support.  Mr Borrell, in order to help Russians it is not necessary to travel to meet Putin. We need to sit down at the same table with our partners in Washington DC and make a common plan for democracy. It includes a Putin containment strategy. Not assistance.  If we do not learn from the bitter lessons of Mr Borrell, our fight against disinformation and interference will be a fight against windmills, and our citizens will no longer respect this Union of Democracies.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: – Respectful Chair, Mr Vice-President of the Commission. Your visit to Moscow, as you have heard, has received a great deal of negative attention. I believe that you are very well aware of everything that concerns the visit to Moscow, because you were at the epicentre of these unfortunate events.  But let this end of the debate and, for the sake of the stenogram, be read out once again, these major misses that have brought your actions, and especially your inaction, into a sharp public interest. The timing of your visit was extremely inappropriate, given the ongoing repression of the Putin regime against the Russian people. With your visit, you symbolically accepted the brutal behavior of the Russian authorities as normal. You made false claims at a joint press conference with the Russian Foreign Minister that there is no interest or initiative among the Member States of the European Union in imposing additional sanctions against Russia. You did not defend the interests of the European Union and did not clearly oppose the attacks by the Russian Foreign Minister, which targeted the European Union and our ally, the United States. You did not defend the interests of the European Union. You did not interrupt your visit after receiving information about the expulsion of diplomats from European Union countries from Russia. Mr Borrell, I hope that you will understand the mistakes you have made and their impact on the European Union, draw your own conclusions and act accordingly.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I am going to speak Spanish, after all it is the second most spoken language in the world, and we have a very good interpretation system. So I will use my own language. Thank you very much for all the comments you have made, for the comments, very different from each other, covering a wide spectrum of interpretations regarding this visit and relations between the European Union and Russia. I take good note of them, and we will take them into account in the preparation of future discussions in the Foreign Affairs Council and in the preparation of the Council of the European Union. However, let me tell you that, when I have been listening to some of you, I felt that the one who had expelled the European diplomats was me, because it really seemed that I was the one who had expelled the European diplomats. You forgive me, the one who expelled the European diplomats was Mr Lavrov. What was in reaction to my public statements on the Navalni case? You may, but I suppose you'll agree that you've done them.  And please, some of the things I've heard about what, according to you, I said or didn't say at the press conference, just, they do not reflect reality, they do not say things as they were, because, clearly, in the transcription of the press conference it is clearly collected how I said twice to Mr Lavrov, who was there, and had told him at our meeting, that we were absolutely, more than concerned, against, denouncing the trials that were taking place against Mr Navalni, the attempted poisoning he had suffered and the repression about the demonstrations that this had generated in civil society. On two occasions: at the beginning and at the end. How can you come here to tell me that I did not talk about Mr Navalni's problem or defend the opposition and public demonstrations? You guys, no, you're not talking about the same thing. There's a transcript, read it. Let's see, what's the problem? For some of you the problem is that the visit took place, that the high representative has decided to make a visit to Moscow. Do you know how many visits by official delegations at ministerial level or higher have there been in the last two years to Russia by Member States of the European Union? Nineteen, nineteen times there have been visits to Russia. So what's the matter, do you have to go or you don't have to go? Or can everyone but the high representative go? Then why do they have it? My colleagues can go, but I can't. Nineteen times. So it seems that going is not something that is so forbidden. Rather it's a pretty normal thing: nineteen times, nineteen times. The problem then is that maybe it was the wrong time. Well, there are opinions on that: some may think it wasn't because Mr Navalni was being judged, and others may think that it was precisely an appropriate time to make our position clearly, directly and personally apparent. It's easier to write statements from my office, without moving from it, certainly much more comfortable and less risky, but to think it's fair right now when you have to, frankly, doesn't seem crazy to me. Someone may think no, that there was a lot of risk, that to see what was going to happen, than better not to go, or not to go now, to go later, when Mr. Navalni would have already been convicted. Well, look, I have had a different assessment and, by the way, supported by the majority of the members of the Foreign Affairs Council: there are not only a few who opposed it here, there was a majority who were in favour. And it seems to me, frankly, that it seems to me and continues to seem to me that, if the defence of human rights and the defense of political freedoms is in our DNA, there are times when we have to stand up and go and explain what we say in the communiqués to make it clear to the recipient. Has that harmed the opposition in Russia? Has that weakened Mr Navalni's position? Frankly, I don't understand why. Then we can discuss whether, at a time when we publicly express our positions, we should have done things differently, and there are interpretations as well; certainly, in the light of the general assessment, I should surely have approached it differently, but I do not understand a joint press conference as a debate or as a pugilato; I explain my position and repeat it, I convey the message I have come to convey: that the European Union is in deep disagreement and condemns Mr Navalni's assassination attempt, the trials to which he is being subjected and the repression of civil society and demonstrations. I say it and I repeat it, because that's what I went to say. And I also say, because that it is also what I have gone to say, that, despite that, there are areas where it would be possible to imagine cooperation for the benefit of both parties, and of course, the IAIC is one of them. I do not understand what someone has said that, in the case of the PAIC, I have been supporting Russian positions against U.S. positions. But please criticize me with foundation, do not make up the facts to support your criticisms. As coordinator of the PAIC board, I have tried to keep this treaty alive despite the defecation of the United States. Russia believes that the European Union is too divided for it to make a firm policy in front of it. And they also consider, and they also say it to your face when you argue with them, that we are an appendix to the United States, and that we will always condemn what they do and we will not when the United States does, because they are our friends and allies; we have two pesos and two measures. And I think that's also something that has to be called into question: we are allies of the United States, but we are not 100 percent aligned with them in all the positions they take and in all the decisions they make, no. There are cases where, if we disagree, we have to say it and we do it. And we do; we do this when we believe it is necessary and convenient to do so, and that is what some people may somehow be surprised by because they have an overly one-sided view of events, but my obligation is not to exercise a fluoric attitude towards anyone, it is to build bridges when possible and to mark firm positions when necessary. Yes, you can believe that the opportunity was not the good one; you might also think it was. It can be understood that the result has not been good, and it must certainly be accepted and admitted that the media interpretation and the majority in this House is that it has not been. But it wasn't, why? Wasn't it because you didn't have to go? Wasn't it because you didn't have to go then? Wasn't it because we haven't addressed the issues we had to deal with? Wasn't it because we haven't defended Mr Navalni's cause and the opposition? There are different reasons, different facts, that we have to analyze one by one if we do not want this to become a pimpampum of which the only beneficiary is the Kremlin, who will be happy to perceive our divisions. Because, deep down, what it is about is acting with unity and determination; because autocratic or authoritarian countries believe that democracies are weak, inherently weak, because of their own functioning and the division that entails, but historical experiences show that this is not the case. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall and the breakdown of the Soviet empire, what has become clear is that democracies are more resilient, we are stronger, because we inherently have a unity above our differences, but we cannot let our differences weaken us, and in this case, as in all, what needs to be built, before and after my trip to Russia , is the unity of the Member States and the unity of action between the European institutions. And that must be done, from now on, in the next Foreign Affairs Council, with the guidance and guidelines of the Council of the European Union at the end of March. And from then on we will have to seriously analyze what our approaches are to Russia, for which we inevitably had to talk to them. Yes, and the result has been that it is, if we put the question of human rights on the table and, in particular, mr Navalni's case, the Russian answer is: 'There is no talk of anything else'. You talk about humiliation, but rest a surely it has not been comfortable, nor, for Russian power, to see how someone goes there directly, expressly and personally and tells you what we have said since communiqués many times. No, frankly, I don't think we should go and tell them in the face what we tell them by correspondence; I think it was time to defend, with all our strength and with the strength of the physical presence of a high representative, our position on Mr Navalni's case. Regardless of all the mistakes, inadequacies and any other but that can be found, I believe that if we really consider that human rights and public freedoms are at the heart of our political project, the situation of Mr Navalni and the Russian opposition demanded a strong and strong presence. Do you think I would not have liked to enter a melee with Mr. Lavrov and openly dispute some of his observations? How, for example, to compare the case of Mr Navalni, who suffers an assassination attempt and who passes, one after the other, trials that can continue to convict him for no reason or foundation, with that of any Member who sits in this House and some of his colleagues who are freely campaigning in Catalonia right now? Do you think this comparison makes any sense? For anyone it is clear that it does not have it, it is clear that it does not have it. But I didn't want to get into that discussion because I didn't come to mind, I preferred to repeat the message I went to carry again. The European Union expresses its condemnation and protest and calls for an investigation into the circumstances in which Mr Navalni was poisoned and to be released because his trial is neither a fair trial nor a guarantee, and calls for respect for the rights and freedoms of Russian citizens; and at the same time, yes, it believes that there are issues on which it is necessary, inevitably, to seek areas of cooperation, but to cooperate it takes two. If Russian power has not wanted to do so, we take good note and will have to look for other ways to develop this relationship. Nevertheless, I believe that we have extracted positive elements from this visit. We know better the terrain we set foot on, we know better what reactions we can expect. And for all that, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that what needs to be done from now on is, in all instances of the European institutions — Parliament, Council, European Council, Commission — to analyse with intelligence and serenity what our future steps have to be in order to decide to define our relationship with Russia. I hope this debate has contributed to this.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: in writing. – While High Representative Borell’s visit to Russia was disastrous, ill-timed, and ill-planned, it laid bare fundamental divergences and issues in the EU-Russia relationship. First and foremost, it is time for the EU to adopt a more robust posture toward Russia. President Putin has shown his disregard for the EU’s criticisms and condemnations and continues to pursue an aggressive foreign policy with impunity. Second, we cannot allow Russia to exploit economic interconnectedness as a political tool or coercive instrument. More specifically, the Nord Stream 2 project must be stopped immediately and Member States must expand the targeted sanctions package on those responsible for human rights violations in Russia. It is altogether clear that politics and business are not separate domains, and that the EU must not be held hostage by ‘strings attached.’ Third, the EU’s relations with third states must always be built on the principles of democracy, rule of law, and human rights, Russia cannot be an exception to this rule. Mr Borell’s failure to stand up for these principles was an embarrassment for the EU and a disappointing signal to those fighting for democracy around the world. Russia has made its disdain entirely clear, and the EU must act accordingly.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: Writing. – Yesterday, many of us signed a letter to the President of the EC calling on you, Mr Borrell, to resign. Your visit to Moscow, at the time and place, was, in our view, humiliating and dehonesting for the EU. You set out of your own choice, even though many had warned you in advance. By being silent on the war that Russia is waging in Ukraine, ignoring the imprisonment of Alexei Navalny and the beating of peacefully demonstrating people on the streets of Russia, you have turned your back on the values on which the EU is built. What a blatant difference from another Social Democrat, former Dutch Foreign Minister Max van der Stoel, who visited Prague in 1977 and met the persecutioned spokesman of Charter 77, Prof. Jan Patočka, to express his full solidarity. However, your trip was also wrong from the point of view of real policy. By rejecting the new sanctions and not immediately ending the visit when the diplomats of Poland, Germany and Sweden were expelled from Russia, you have condemned the EU to the role of a defenceless statistician and a weak, sly beat-up. The best thing you can do for the EU in this situation is to leave office as quickly as possible.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the humanitarian and political situation in Yemen (2021/2539(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, yes, the humanitarian and political situation in Yemen deserves more attention, much more than we have paid to it. The war has been raging for almost six years with a devastating impact, 24 million people – which means 80% of the Yemeni population – are in need of humanitarian assistance and more than four million are displaced. Beyond this terrible humanitarian crisis, the war in Yemen has become a source of instability in the whole region and we need to take decisive action to avert a mass famine. The situation can still deteriorate if restrictions on imports of basic commodities and humanitarian access persist. The COVID-19 pandemic has already exacerbated the humanitarian situation in Yemen. And additionally, the Safer oil tanker stranded in the Red Sea is a ticking time bomb that could cause an environmental disaster.  Since the start of the conflict six years ago, the European Union has not only made diplomatic efforts, but also provided nearly EUR 1 billion to Yemen, as a response to the crisis through humanitarian and development assistance. You can be sure that we will keep working to support the only way out of this crisis, which is a political settlement for peace and stability. To this end, we fully back the efforts of the United Nations Special Envoy, Martin Griffiths, in support of a ceasefire and a political solution. Current prospects for a rapid breakthrough in Yemen are certainly, and unhappily, slim.  The latest attacks by Ansar Allah showed how challenging the situation remains. But at the same time, we feel a growing sense of urgency in the international community to find a way out. The latest announcement from the Biden administration, ending support for Saudi-led offensive operations, on the appointment of a special Yemen envoy, show a genuine interest from our partners to address the crisis. We also welcome the announced revocation of the designation of Ansar Allah as a foreign terrorist organisation. This designation could have catastrophic consequences in the context of Yemen, as the country is highly dependent on commercial food imports. Yes, it has to be very clear that to declare an entity to be a terrorist organisation can create a blockage on trade, because nobody will dare to face US sanctions. And this is one example that has to be criticised about some decisions of the outgoing Trump administration.  We strongly condemn the 13 December attack on the new government. The unprecedented mission of eight European ambassadors to Aden, that demonstrates our strong diplomatic support. We are ready to push for a concerted action to unlock the stalled process and to nudge the parties to implement a permanent cease fire and begin political talks. I am confident that progress towards peace in Yemen will also help de-escalate the tense situation in the wider Gulf region. I will personally continue engagement on all these issues, along with Commissioner for Crisis Management, my colleague Janez Lenarčič and other partners, and I am looking forward to working with you on this critical file. Six years of war, one of the biggest humanitarian crisis in the world has to stop and we in the European Union have an important role to play in it.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Dear Mr Vice-President, Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Yemen is facing one of the world's worst humanitarian crises in years. Today, 400,000 children are struggling to survive. The incomes and opportunities of the families have practically disappeared. There is a general food shortage, with millions without access to drinking water, fuel and fuel. The civil war has so far claimed more than 233,000 lives. One problem cannot be highlighted, all of which simultaneously make normal life impossible in Yemen. In the midst of Covid, it turned the country into hell. We cannot ignore the fact that the country has been ruled for years by terrorist organisations on an extreme scale, persecuting religious minorities. The epidemic has further worsened the vulnerability of Christians and other religious minorities.  According to humanitarian organization Open Doors, local officials simply refuse to hand over aid when it comes to Christians. Such violations of humanitarian principles are, I stress, not a religious issue, but a matter of human rights. The Union simply cannot tolerate this. Since the Union has neither an army nor a decisive influence on military processes, and Mr Borrell has rightly stated this here, instruments must be used for which he has a great deal of experience and a long tradition. Europe simply does not need to be heroic or threatened, but the effectiveness of humanitarian action must be strengthened. A humanitarian response developed in cooperation with the locals, based on real needs, should be provided. This is a key issue for preserving the credibility of the European Union in the region.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Mr. High Representative, today's debate is timely, and I am glad that my group has taken the initiative. We may be at a turning point in the tragic situation in Yemen, a country tormented by a bloody civil war since 2015 and hit first by a cholera epidemic, then by COVID-19 and also by famine. The situation on the ground, in all parts of the country, is dramatic and it is no coincidence that what Yemenis experience on a daily basis has been repeatedly described by the United Nations as the worst humanitarian crisis of the last thirty years. In this context, we can only be relieved that the new US administration has decided to change course, in relation to the disastrous regional policy pursued by Donald Trump and that it has already taken important decisions. In this regard, Mr High Representative, I would very much like us, the Europeans, to be able to act together and clearly affirm our position and our determination to do everything in our power to ensure that a solution to the conflict is likely to put an end to the ongoing humanitarian crisis. In the resolution that we have finalised and which we will vote on, we affirm simple and clear concepts: First, in the chaos of Yemen, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates bear a heavy responsibility. Without denying the specific responsibilities of all Yemeni actors, their war with Western weapons and the deadly raids of their planes have caused immense damage to the population, especially the most vulnerable citizens. While strongly supporting the peace process, I believe it is our duty to continue to insist on an effective embargo on the sale of arms to these two countries, to support the referral of the situation in Yemen to the International Criminal Court so that no actor involved can go unpunished for the war crimes he has committed on Yemeni soil and in the meantime consider that the leaders most directly involved can be subjected to the measures under the Council's new human rights sanctions regime.

name: Barry ANDREWS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the UN Humanitarian Coordinator is clear in his view that the people of Yemen are being starved deliberately. The UN funding call for 2020 was 40% underfunded, as you know, and this has brought Yemen to the brink of famine. But it’s not just a matter of funding. As you know, starvation has been used as a weapon of war. The United Nations Security Council called this out very clearly: that it is a breach of international humanitarian law and it is a war crime. The resolution today calls on the EU to do three things: to contribute to a sustainable political process, to ensure adequate funding on the humanitarian side, and also to join the war against impunity because starvation is not the only war crime that is being committed in Yemen. There are multiple examples, catalogued by the Yemen Data Project, of assaults on civilian infrastructure, including hospitals, schools, markets and even weddings, and this cannot go unpunished.  This resolution is also unequivocal in calling for an end to arms sales. The EU common position sets out eight very clear criteria that must be satisfied in order to allow arms sales to third countries, and very few of those criteria are met in relation to arms sales that are used in Yemen. I think we have to be absolutely clear about that.  Conflicts in the 21st century are very complex and long running. Mr Borrell, you’re very fortunate in Team Europe here, the humanitarian community, the development community and the full weight of the diplomatic community. We’re adding our political voice today and we hope that 2021 will not be another lost year for Yemen.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It seems so long ago that we talked about Yemen and the most serious humanitarian crisis facing the world. And yet, for some inexplicable reason, this issue does not make it onto our agenda. We are not even treating it as an urgent matter, which always surprises me very much.  Let me make my position very clear. The international community has let Yemen down. The High Representative is often content to repeat the UN Security Council's statement, with a commitment to Saudi oversight of the entire conflict and a commitment to Yemen's territorial integrity. This was expressed despite assurances that a Yemeni solution to this Yemeni problem must be found.  The High Representative will surely agree that there is a lot of support among the people of the South for a separate state, and that the only political group currently in serious talks with the Houthis is the Southern Transitional Council. If the talks are to be successful, then all options must be put on the table, including a two-state solution.  Let me conclude by giving you a few figures. Since the beginning of 2015, the European Union has allocated €896 million to Yemen. During the same period, some 3.6 billion dollars worth of aid were sent to Yemen. Is this really a policy from which we can hope for a lasting peace for Yemen?  What is needed is a genuine political dialogue between the Yemeni factions, with an agenda set by the Yemenis. Death and destruction are the only things that have brought the interference of third parties to this troubled country.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Yemen is indeed the worst humanitarian crisis around the world and the people of Yemen are suffering in a way I think we can’t even imagine. But it’s also part of the story that this war is fought with weapons made in the European Union. The Eurofighter from Airbus is used to bomb hospitals in Yemen. French Mirage bombers are used by the United Arab Emirates to do exactly the same. Both airplanes are equipped with MK-80 bombs manufactured by RWM, the Italian subsidiary of German Rheinmetall. And the French company DCI is at this moment training Saudi soldiers on how to better launch rockets into Yemen.  So we actually can do something as the European Union to stop this war. That’s why I think the message from our Parliament’s resolution needs to be crystal clear: no more weapons, no more spare parts, no more maintenance until the war in Yemen is over. And I want to say to Mr Borrell that I really hope that the message from the next Foreign Affairs Council will be just the same, because this is the only way we can build credibility, to put pressure on Iran and everyone else who wants to make money or politics with the suffering of the people in Yemen, to get out of this beautiful country and let the people of Yemen sort out their conflicts.  And there’s actually a window of opportunity, and Mr Borrell, you mentioned that. The new US Administration is doing exactly this. They are working on a suspension of all arms deals to Saudi Arabia and the UAE and a diplomatic initiative, a new diplomatic initiative, to end the war in Yemen. I think that all of us in this room and beyond should do everything possible to make sure that the European Union picks up on this initiative, and to build a transatlantic alliance to stop the war in Yemen and the suffering of the people of Yemen.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, the last line of Yemen’s national anthem is ‘the world will not see a guardian upon my nation’. Since reunification, foreign powers have been trying to carve up, exploit and pauperise Yemen and its people. Sana’a dutifully followed the IMF and World Bank reform programmes for two decades until the people of Yemen had had enough. Obama helped install the puppet Hadi, promised change in elections. What Yemen got was more austerity, privatisation and land grabs by foreign investors. Ansar Allah put a stop to the plunder in 2014. They negotiated a deal with Hadi and others, making elections the top priority. But the Saudi—led coalition went to war to stop the prospects of peace, power-sharing and independence in Yemen. With Western help and barely a word from the usual human rights defenders, they killed hundreds of thousands of Yemeni people and committed brutal crimes on a daily basis. They are still at it and Yemen is still resisting.  You say you care about democracy. Why don’t you stop the genocide, stop the plundering of Yemen and allow elections to take place?  Who would win? Well, that’s none of our business. It’s for the people of Yemen to decide that, not the EU, Saudi Arabia or the UAE, not the US, not Russia, not China or anyone else. It’s justice they need more than aid. And for too long, we’ve turned a blind eye and the Yemenis are not for lying down.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear High Representative, indiscriminate bombings, cholera epidemics, famine: nothing has been spared to the Yemeni people in these six years. The Saudi-imposed naval blockade and the COVID-19 pandemic are just the latest act of the tragedy. In this horrific proxy war, in which hunger has also become a weapon, the gap between necessity and assistance is constantly widening. The humanitarian aid provided by international donors is by no means sufficient to counter an increasingly critical situation. This is a race against time, where the price paid for inaction is measured in human lives, ladies and gentlemen.  Increasing humanitarian aid is certainly important, but it is not enough. The change of course of the US Administration, in particular the stop to indiscriminate support and also the review of arms sales to the Saudi coalition, offers us a valuable opportunity to make a fundamental breakthrough in the peace process.  It is an opportunity that we must not and cannot miss, and I am proud to say that Italy, thanks to the coherence of the 5 Star Movement and Minister Di Maio, has done its duty by revoking the licenses for the supply of more than ten thousand bombs to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, worth several hundred million euros. That is what we must all do as European countries. This is the signal that we must send out, bringing to fruition what this Parliament has been calling for for years: a total compulsory export embargo on coalition actors in Yemen.  As long as we tolerate the ambiguity of European affairs on the skin of Yemeni civilians, we will never really be part of the solution but only part of the problem. Until we act, Europe will not be a mediator, it will not even be just a player, it will be complicit. Every day fifty lives of children are broken in our silence. I want an architected Europe, I do not want an accomplice Europe.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, the crisis in Yemen is going into its sixth year, and we cannot stand by as over half of Yemen’s 30 million people threaten to fall into extreme food insecurity, as a senseless war that has killed half a million continues to rage on with no regard for human life. Fifty thousand infants die in Yemen each year and thousands of children are on the brink of starvation today. High Representative, I commend the work the Commission and the Member States have done to prevent a greater humanitarian disaster in Yemen. But this is the moment to step up. The funding shortages faced by aid organisations must be addressed immediately. We have to be honest: acute humanitarian aid only wins you the battle and not the war. All parties to this gruesome conflict must return to the UN negotiating table. Some welcome steps have been made in recent weeks. After years, the internationally recognised government returned to Yemen, and just days ago US President Biden reversed the previous administration’s disastrous policy on Yemen. By ending support for the Saudi—led coalition, he was loud and clear: this conflict has no military solution. Yemen doesn’t just need food, it needs peace. This is the time to deliver.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Madam President, when a war becomes a carnage, when military targets become schools, 3,100 children killed, more than 5,000 children maimed, 24 million people – 80% of Yemen's population – threatened with starvation... Therefore, Mr High Representative, we must take advantage of the change of position of the new Biden Government , which has withdrawn its support for offensive operations in Yemen, including the sale of arms to the Saudi-led coalition — to resume political dialogue, obtain a ceasefire and call on Member States to comply scrupulously with the Common Position on arms sales. We need to ensure through the final certificates that no weapon reaching the region ends up in Yemen; other than, any budgetary efforts to help humanitarian aid will be insufficient. And the moral weight on our conscience, unbearable.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Madam President, "far from the eyes, away from the heart," says the proverb. The Conflict in Yemen is one of those forgotten conflicts. For more than six years, a terrible war has been raging in Yemen. The war pits the Houthis against an international coalition that in 2017 has delegated the handling of the conflict to local powers Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates. Hundreds of thousands of civilian and military deaths are now being deplored as a result of the bombing, famine and fighting. Composite and fragile, Yemen is one of the oldest centers of civilization in the Middle East. Today's Yemen was born in 1990, and the country's history is marked by strong political instability and uninterrupted unrest. The European Union, which would like so much to participate in the concert of nations, is once again demonstrating its powerlessness and inefficiency in resolving this conflict. Powerless because totally discredited by his naïve wonders at the Arab Spring, the results of which are not a democratic advance. Powerless by his criminal support for the Syrian rebellion. His guilty silence in the face of the destabilization of Libya by Islamist terrorists and his glaring powerlessness in the face of the establishment of Daesh have finally erased his word and influence in the Middle East. The European Union persists in uttering condemnations that sound false and are in fact wishful thinking. Only Member States with influence in the region, including France, have legitimacy and credibility to try to resolve a conflict that is now mired. And that uncertainty will grow. The interventionist desires of the new US president, who wants to restore his country's global leadership, risk increasing regional instability. Incoherent and discredited, the European Union must leave it to the nations to make their contribution in the resolution of this conflict.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We are in the sixth year of this war. Twenty-four million people are in need of help, including more than 12 million children. 2.1 million children are acutely malnourished. If we look at Yemen, we are looking at the world's worst humanitarian crisis and yet a rather forgotten crisis. Perhaps this is also because hardly anyone has the opportunity to flee to Europe, from the people who are affected there. The gap in humanitarian funding last year was 45 percent, or nearly half.
