And yes, the EU states, including the Commission, are giving money. But in terms of economic power, we are lagging far short of what is possible. And this is particularly tragic in the face of a global pandemic. There are outbreaks of malaria, cholera, dengue fever, but also of COVID-19. And the medical staff has hardly any protective equipment. Most don't even get a salary. If we want to counteract this cruel crisis now, we need diplomatic efforts, but we also need more money at the forthcoming donor conference by the EU states.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Madam President, for more than six years, Yemen has been the scene of a civil, regional and international war, involving Member States of the European Union, either as part of the coalition that bombs the country or either profiting, selling the weapons that kill civilians in Yemen. But humanitarian crises are rarely natural phenomena, even if they are treated as such many times in this House. In addition to emergencies, there are casualties, and in conflicts, above all, there are interests and responsibilities. And the humanitarian crisis in Yemen has one clear cause: war. And there are those responsible: Saudi Arabia and its allies. Yes, Saudi Arabia, yes, that country that is an absolutist, fundamentalist, misogina, homophobic and criminal technocracy. How is it possible that Saudi Arabia is and remains a key partner of the European Union? How do we continue to maintain standardized trade, military, diplomatic relations when Saudi Arabia bombs Yemen? That makes us complicit in the murders that take place in Yemen. Because many of the bombs that kill people in Yemen are European-branded. And I wonder: why do the criteria of democracy or human rights that are being applied in other countries not apply here? Why isn't there an arms embargo in Saudi Arabia? Why? Because there are too many interests at stake that make our words hypocritical.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Madam President, we denounced human rights violations in Yemen, but in 2019 Spain continued to export arms to Saudi Arabia, with your endorsement, Mr Borrell, when you were Minister of Foreign Affairs. We've warned you over and over again from this Chamber. It is impossible to defend the flag of human rights without credibility. Aren't you ashamed to go to Moscow to demand the release of Mr. Navalni without condemning the prison of Catalan political prisoners? Aren't you ashamed? It is this inconsistency that sinks the European Union's international respect as a democratic power. Mr Vice-President, if Russia has humiliated you, it is because of your own silence at what is happening in Spain. How long will he continue to hide behind a piece of paper? How long will you keep making it look like you can't hear us? Spain is dragging the European Union into diplomatic failure and its face represents this failure. No more irresponsibility, Mr Vice-President.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, every ten minutes in Yemen, a child under the age of five dies of malnutrition. We have been debating for half an hour, so do the count. Indeed, it is the result of a war. A war that Saudi Arabia and its allies are waging against Yemen. But it is also a responsibility of the Member States of the European Union. We are now the second largest arms exporter to that country, and therefore a direct accomplice to the atrocities that are being committed in Yemen today, despite a common position of September 2019 which calls on Member States not to sell arms or other military equipment that could be used for internal repression or contribute to international aggression or regional instability. While the resolution of the conflict will take time, famine does not wait. The European Union must continue and strengthen its humanitarian action on the ground. The decisions taken last Friday by the new US president are first good news. The European Union must seize this opportunity - and I know you will - and encourage an initiative at the United Nations with adoption in the Security Council to establish a global embargo on the sale of arms to the actors of the conflict and impose an end to hostilities in Yemen.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, the humanitarian situation in Yemen is the worst in the world, with widespread hunger, disease, attacks on civilians and violence every week, every day, every hour. This human tragedy, which has been exacerbated by more than five years of war, became increasingly deadly with the increasing of sanctions, a fatal collapse of the country’s economy and the COVID pandemic. The conflict has displaced more than one million people and over 24 million people – two thirds of the population –require food assistance.  Yes, Mr Borrell, you are right. This must stop immediately. The EU High Representative and the EU Member States have to condemn in the strongest terms the gross violation of international humanitarian law and put pressure on both sides to advance the political process and reach a nationwide ceasefire. At the same time, the EU should mobilise additional resources to address the situation in Yemen and to ensure equitable access to vaccines against COVID-19.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President, Yemen has been plunged into a civil war for six years, as my colleagues have been saying. During 2020, the armed conflict has not only continued but also intensified, resulting in blatant human rights violations conducted by all parties involved. All parties need to urgently implement the global ceasefire call contained in UN Security Council Resolution 2532.  Since 2016, this Parliament has repeatedly called for an EU-wide arms ban on the members of the Saudi-led coalition, and while some EU Member States have already done so, others continue to transfer weapons in breach of our common position on arms exports. There can be no military solution to that conflict. After six years, we cannot continue to turn a blind eye to the violence, human suffering and loss ravaging Yemen. It is the moment for the EU, Mr Vice-President, to assert its role as a peace broker and to seize the opportunity of the election of the new US Administration to really have an initiative to build peace in the region.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, what is happening in Yemen is a disgrace to all humanity. This otherwise poorest country of the Arabian Peninsula was hit by war, famine, and then a cholera epidemic.  The situation escalated further with saudi Arabia's intervention first armed by Western imperialist countries and of course politically supported. The situation has gone so far as to accuse Saudi Arabia of war crimes for bombing plumbing, ports, food factories, hospitals.  And while we're giving enormous attention here in Europe to our fellow citizens dying of COVID in their eighth or ninth decades, although that's not certain either because we're not doing autopsies, the hunger virus that swept Yemen is hardly even seen. 100,000 children have died of starvation so far, and a million are severely undernourished and threatened by a similar situation. One child every ten minutes or 150 children by the end of this day only. There's talk of the greatest famine in the world in a hundred years. There's talk of losing an entire generation.  Until when more this hypocrisy and double standards, what media, what political?

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, something dramatic and undervalued is happening in Yemen. The picture is disarming: since 2015, the conflict has led to the deaths of almost 250 000 people, mostly civilians; 14 million people are now starving and the survival of 24 million Yemenis is directly dependent on humanitarian aid.  The danger, in Guterres's words, of the worst famine the world has seen in decades is foreshadowed. In the face of this, we need strong action, starting with the identification of responsibilities, those of the Saudi-led coalition, which has glaring violations of human rights on its conscience, and also our own.  Between 2015 and 2018, European governments granted €42 billion in licenses to the Saudi coalition. A very heavy responsibility from which a decisive change of page must begin. In this sense, the Italian Government has done well to suspend licences for arms exports to Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates and it is even more important that Biden has decided to go in the same direction.  We must insist. The international community, starting with the European Union, must mobilise even more decisively.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, Yemen means the worst ongoing humanitarian crisis in the world. Many terrible figures on human suffering and human failures have been mentioned during this debate. We desperately need more diplomatic efforts to trigger a wide and inclusive political process. After six years of war, all contending parties have to understand that no further  military offensives will end the conflict.  But for the war to stop we also need our Member States to stop fuelling the conflict by selling arms. US President Biden recently announced the suspension of arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the Emirates.  We, in the EU, should ban sales of arms or any military equipment to the Saudi—led coalition. Member States who have only frozen such exports should permanently revoke all export licenses. With their arm sales, which break the EU common position, many EU Member States – with Spain ranking prominently – are complicit in the prolongation of this terrible war. It is time for them now to be complicit in peace.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for High Representative Borell! I want to show you a picture of a child. We have talked a lot about those in question, the children who are starving. I think about myself, how I look at pictures from Yemen, how I see children malnourished on the brink of a famine that risks taking their lives. And then I see my own children playing, chubby, happy, free. And there I think we have to be, we have to stay, we have to be able to look at it.  I think there is something about the speed blindness we have sometimes today that makes us not stop and realize that this is not the way it should look. This is something that would have been consigned to history. I lived for a decade, I would say, with the belief that starvation was consigned to my childhood, to my upbringing. I thought it was over, that the world had done this. We must remember that and we must put much, much more focus on helping these children to freedom, focus on – as has been said in this debate – food, but also peace.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Remark to the Member. Madam President, please do not break the Rules of Procedure. You cannot present posters or photographs during your speech in the plenary chamber.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Madam President, Mr High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, here we are again and again deploring the situation of the Yemenis.  Let us remember, this is the worst crisis in the world according to humanitarian organizations. Europe should not internalise its impotence. As we note bitterly, the French government is not reviewing its arms sales to Saudi Arabia. Our industrialists even continue the after-sales service.  The United States has decided to suspend arms sales contracts. Europe must stop playing impotence. European law governing arms sales needs to be strengthened.  I urge the European Union and the Member States to support the creation of a clear mechanism for collecting evidence of these crimes and to encourage referral to the International Criminal Court. The humanitarian emergency is great. We absolutely need to do it effectively.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I agree with all Members that the only solution is to look for an inclusive political agreement. The end of the conflict in Yemen will come only from an agreement from the parties and the big powers who are behind them. That’s why we should try to continue promoting dialogue and not choose sides, to support the United Nations-led peace-making efforts. We have to continue leading a humanitarian response, including unimpeded humanitarian access. We are trying to use any opportunity that we can in order to increase other donors’ engagement as the multilateral humanitarian response is completely underfunded.  I can assure you that we are doing our utmost. We have limited resources but we are devoting all of them and we are using our influence with Saudi Arabia, with Iran, and now, together with the Biden Administration, I think that we can put more pressure in order to stop this war by proxy, because Yemen is a war by proxy: Saudi Arabia and Iran and the other actors in the region. And yes, it is as awful as you can show through pictures in any kind of material that we already know, the figures are really terrible. I was talking the other day with my friend Miliband, the Head of the NGO Rescue, about this catastrophic war and the humanitarian consequences.  We, as the European Union, have a role to play. It’s a modest one because the only solution is to stop the flow of arms to both parties and to put strong political pressure on the countries who are supporting this war, filling it with arms and resources. The last decision of the Trump Administration, declaring the Houthi rebels a terrorist organisation, for example. I’m sorry, someone will say that I am criticising a decision by the US. Yes, I am criticising this decision taken by the Trump Administration at the last minute, because it was going to create a lot of problems for the supply of resources and food to the people in high need. And happily, this decision has been reconsidered by the new Administration.  So more political engagement and more financial resources and more pressure on the actors. This is, in practical terms, what we can do and what we are trying to do, until the limit of our capacities.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure*. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 11 February 2021 _ _________ *See minutes of the meeting.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Myanmar/Burma (2021/2540(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as you know, on 1 February 2021, the Myanmar military declared a state of emergency for one year in Myanmar. All powers were transferred to the commander—in—chief of the army. The opening of the democratically elected parliament was cancelled, hundreds of people were arrested, including the President and the State Counsellor, Aung San Suu Kyi, and the chief channels have been shut down and Facebook blocked.  This event abruptly turned back the clock of history in Myanmar. The path towards democracy, which had started in 2011, and the will of the people, as expressed in the November elections, has been reversed once again by the military power. The military has already appointed new ministers, trying to establish facts on the ground. It’s crucial to act swiftly and strongly and in coordination with our partners.  Specifically, I already issued a statement already on 1 February. On 2 February, the European Union issued another statement agreed by all Member States and contributed to a G7 statement. So first my statement quickly, engaging only my responsibility but quickly, secondly, a 27 Member State statement engaging the responsibility of the Foreign Affairs Council, and then contributing to a G7 statement.  Yes, we are currently reviewing all our actions and we have three tools to use. First, to consider additional targeted sanctions on individuals and business owned by the military. As you know, in this country the military are a big economic power and own an important part of the economic infrastructure of the country. Second, to review our development assistance and, third, to assess the use of the Everything but Arms trade preferences.  Our policy response should follow some basic principles: first, to try to effect change, second, to maintain channels of dialogue, and, third, to avoid affecting the broader population, which are not guilty and they should not be punished. We are looking carefully at all these actions and, if the Foreign Affairs Council on 22 February gives the political guidance, we will ensure we are doing nothing to legitimise the actions of the military, while trying to maintain support for the people of Myanmar. The review is taking into account how closely we work with the government and its institutions from a legal, financial and technical perspective, as well as the impact on beneficiaries. At the same time, we should avoid rushing into measures that would adversely affect the most vulnerable part of the population. This often happens when you take restrictive measures. In the end it is the poorest among the poor who bear the consequences. Withdrawing preferences would damage the civilian garment sector, while leaving military business unscathed. Five hundred thousand workers would be at risk, mostly women, so we cannot afford to take these kinds of measures.  Third, coordination. We have been in close contact with all partners since the outset of the crisis. We have engaged with ASEAN, India, the US and Australia, and also discussed the situation yesterday with the Chinese Foreign Minister. We all agree on the need for quick responses to avoid allowing a fait accompli that could last quite a long time. We now need to develop a robust response to this unacceptable seizure of power, which reverses ten years of democratic transition.  This is what I had to inform you, honourable Members, about the situation in Myanmar. I am looking forward to your debate.

name: Daniel CASPARY
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which is The numerous reactions to the military coup in Myanmar in recent years have been clear and they are correct. To revise a result of an election, a democratic election, on its own initiative, citing baseless accusations and flimsy justifications– that is simply undemocratic. This is unacceptable. It is good that we are calling out together, supporting the people of Myanmar and also working towards and supporting them and calling for the restoration of the democratic situation in Myanmar. But we have to be careful not to throw the baby out with the bathwater. That is why I am very grateful to you, Mr Vice-President, for what you have said. We must keep a differentiated view. The resolution that we will adopt this week on the situation in Myanmar identifies possible sanctions and restrictions, such as the lifting of trade facilitation such as Everything but Arms. It is a possible means of expressing our firm protest. However, it is also important to me that such measures must not simply be imposed in a knee-jerk manner, but we must weigh up very carefully what the consequences are for the people on the ground. After all, the sanctions that we have often imposed have sometimes failed to reach the target in the past and, instead of the military and the parallel economy, have hit civil society and the civilian economy hard, especially. At the same time, a new sanction will further weaken our position as an economic power in the region. We already have just eight percent of foreign investment in Myanmar. China, on the other hand, is already the second largest investor in the country after Singapore. And if we look at the background to the coup and the current developments, I have the impression that China will be preparing for the new situation very, very quickly. Will try to take advantage there. That is why it is very important to me that we enter into a dialogue, that we also make this clear, but that we really consider when is the right moment to introduce sanctions. In this sense, I say 'yes' to a close observation of the situation. In the end, however, blind actionism must not help Beijing and China, but we really must look at the people of the country. And in that sense. Thank you very much for what you have said today.

name: Marianne VIND
text: for the S&D Group. Madam President! I support the people of Myanmar in their demonstrations against the military coup. That is why I will hold a minute's silence in support of them. (The speaker immediately began his minute's silence. It was interrupted by the President after a short time)

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: Madam President, please speak, otherwise we will give the floor to the next speaker. Madam President, i would like to thank you very much  Madam President, please speak, otherwise I will give the floor to the next speaker.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the situation in Myanmar following the coup d’état on 1 February 2021 is extremely difficult. After the military seized power of the country and detained numerous top government figures, the situation has only escalated. Despite their martial law, the digital blackout created by the military and the limited ability to gain information, we see ongoing protests on the streets which are met with rubber bullets, water cannons and tear gas. It is imperative that this crackdown on the protesters does not turn deadly again, as it did in 2007. Myanmar is home to around 135 major ethnic groups and seven ethnic minority states who are constantly discriminated against. The human rights record in Myanmar is appalling. In addition to Rohingya genocide, other minorities face human rights violations as well.  The Council should impose targeted sanctions to those responsible for the coup, as well as those responsible for what might constitute acts of genocide against Rohingya. Those responsible for human rights violations in Myanmar must be brought to justice.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, six months ago, the European Parliament, imbued with its certainty of embodying human rights alone, with the quiet conscience of the philanthropic bourgeoisie, was splitting a statement with self-satisfied dignity: Aung San Suu Kyi was formally excluded from the Sakharov Prize community. This decision obviously has no influence on the recent events and the imprisonment of Aung San Suu Kyi. To see it as a cause-and-effect link would be to overestimate the diplomatic influence of the European Union, which, by dint of setbacks and ridicule, no longer weighs anything. This is evidenced, Mr. High Representative, in your pitiful getaway to Russia. The European Union, a self-proclaimed champion of freedom and democracy, is subject to the worst fundamentalisms. When it comes to the serious subjects of international relations, it is emotion and well-being that take over. It was this emotion that made you choose Aung San Suu Kyi as the Sakharov Prize, it was this same emotion that made you withdraw it. Always that emotion that sees you stutter today in the face of what you have been unable to predict.  It is this well-being that has made you always choose the same victims around the world by systematically forgetting some others. Your European Union prefers Uighurs to persecuted Catholics in China. She prefers the Rohingya to the Karen people, who have been persecuted for decades. She prefers the Black Lives Matter and their procession of violence to the middle classes, dispossessed of everything. Today, you are forced to slalom between opposing ideological positions because never dictated by the realities and complexity of international relations.  The coup in Myanmar and the brutal restoration of the military junta are of course totally reprehensible. And the European Union would have the means to express it in place of moral injunctions, which autocrats make fun of. Let's use concrete measures. Trade preferences allowing Myanmar to export to the European Union without tariffs under the "Everything but Arms" agreement must be suspended. Not only will the military junta be effectively sanctioned, but this decision would also better protect the interests of some of our Member States. Ladies and gentlemen, these events are a new diplomatic lesson for the European Union, which is clearly struggling to make progress. As a slave to its ideology, the European Union cannot give lessons in freedom, since it represents no people. The European Union is not intended to become a voice in the world, leaving it to the nations to defend their interests in a world where they are regaining an ever more important place. It is said that the politician is thinking about the next election, that the statesman is thinking about the next generation. In diplomatic matters, if it wishes to avoid ridicule, it would be good for the European Union to think beyond its next communication.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, indeed, today’s news tells us that the situation in Myanmar is escalating. Police have fired rubber bullets against peaceful demonstrators as thousands have defied a ban on protesting in the administrative capital of Naypyidaw. But also, European businesses should be aware of the risks of doing business with this military conglomeration, which the High Representative has mentioned. There should be no links in the value chain of European businesses to the Myanmar military’s economic imperium. I would like to highlight that here we have yet another crystal clear example that there should be no complicity with repression, grave human rights violations or environmental destruction. The EU Commission should, with this aim, urgently produce an advisory for businesses on how to do business in Myanmar under these very serious conditions. I could highlight the Japanese brewing company Kirin Holdings. I’m sure you may have tasted its products when having your sushi. Kirin Holdings is among those companies that have already been withdrawing their joint ventures with the military because they find it intolerable to be complicit in anything that has to do with a coup. Furthermore, the EU needs to launch an investigation on the Everything but Arms (EBA) programme. There should be an investigation into the trade preferences. Are they benefiting the Myanmar military’s conglomerates or ordinary people? I have no opinion on the outcome of this investigation as standing rapporteur in the Committee on International Trade, but I think it’s urgent to do that investigation.  Selective action could already be taken now. There could only be preferences benefiting private civil entities, if there are any. So instead of preferences, EU sanctions on the military’s conglomerates are needed.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa As Vice-President of the ASEAN delegation to the European Parliament, I observe with great attention the recent events in Burma, where a military coup took place just before the swearing-in of the new parliament on 1 February. It is clear that the elections that took place in the country on 8 November, in which the National League for Democracy party won a huge majority, were rigged, followed by martial law and a military dictatorship.  If we add that the president of this country, as well as some 200 very important Burmese politicians, have also been arrested as a result of the attack, I think that, as the European Union, we should take what is happening in this country extremely seriously. Above all, as always, military leaders should be condemned and called upon to immediately release political leaders and all those arrested, and to take action to stabilise the situation in the country with the active participation of the European Union.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, Mr High Representative, the coup d'état on 1 February is a clear violation of the Constitution. More than 100,000 people demonstrated peacefully against the coup, more than 160 people have been detained and martial law has been enacted with a curfew and a ban on gatherings with more than five people.  The military involved has not only directly interfered with the country's democratic order, but there are several allegations of its involvement in corruption schemes, concentration of power and control of the economy. The Secretary General of the United Nations, António Guterres, called this coup absolutely unacceptable and several countries have condemned the military coup.  This is why we condemn this military coup and express our support for the people of Myanmar in their peaceful and legitimate struggle for democracy. But we also do not forget that in the country serious human rights violations persist, in particular against the Roinja minority and that Myanmar's own democratic government has failed and failed to recognise this population, and ethnic cleansing has even taken place in 2017 as recognised by international authorities that led to a massive exodus of people from the country.  Despite all international appeals, roinjas continue to be persecuted. Just as we condemn this military coup, we also call attention to roinjas and the defence of human rights as fundamental in Myanmar.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Madam President, dear Commissioner, dear Mr Borrell, dear colleagues, democrats in Myanmar, or Burma, fear for their life and country, and as we are all democrats, we must take a stand against a military coup. It seems that the action of Ms Suu Kyi, who tried to limit the power of the military, led to a coup, in a part of the world where the EU has little or no influence and China is the major factor. It needs no debate that the coup should be condemned by the EU, as Mr Borrell correctly did. I have only one question. Does Mr Borrell agree that considering our limited influence in this part of the world, our best chance to contribute to positive developments lie in coordination of our actions, in close relations to the United States?

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, as the European Parliament we have always followed developments in Myanmar very closely.  In a number of resolutions throughout the last few years we have, for instance, strongly condemned all past and present human rights violations, especially against the Rohingya population.  Since 2015, and previous speakers have underlined this, the European Union has politically and financially supported Myanmar’s process of democratic transition. We have undertaken enormous efforts to promote peace, human rights and development in this country.  Unfortunately, all these positive developments have been abruptly reversed by the recent coup. This coup was a clear violation of Myanmar’s constitution, which we ought to all strongly condemn. I am deeply concerned by the detention of political leaders and civil society activists, including State Counsellor Aung San Suu Kyi and President Win Myint.  I call upon the military to immediately end the state of emergency. I call on the military to restore power to the democratically elected government. I call upon the military to respect human rights and the rule of law, and I call upon the military to release all those unjustly detained.  The November election results, as well as the Constitution, must be respected, and the national parliament should be convened at the earliest opportunity. Power should be returned to democratically elected representatives and to a civilian government as soon as possible.  For the European Union, all instruments should be on the table in order to react. As the European Parliament, we should send a strong message that we stand with the people of Myanmar who want to see a democratic future of their country.  High Representative, thank you for your good words on this issue.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – Madam President, the coup d’état carried out last week in Myanmar by the armed forces is a clear violation of the Myanmar constitution. It means a dramatic break from the country’s democratic transition process. The international community must condemn it. Let us not forget that Myanmar benefits from the European Union’s Everything but Arms scheme, designed to encourage the development of the world’s poorest countries. We need to make sure that this scheme does not profit an unelected military power, but its people. We need to make sure that humanitarian and development aid is not channelled through the Myanmar government’s networks to the military. Last but not least, the EU reaction to situations such as this could be so much more efficient if the Union had more tools in this area. The past has shown us repeatedly that 27 Member States on their own and limited coordination from the EU institutions is not a recipe for a strong Union in the global context.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, it seems like Myanmar has gone back 15 years through a time machine, back to when Václav Havel was calling for the international community to keep the pressure on the military junta to free the democratic opposition leaders and hand over power.  Many fear that the past decade was all for nothing. The people of Myanmar want democracy. We have seen the images of tens of thousands rallying around the country to protest against the coup. We in Europe stand with them.  But this cannot be just with words. We need action. Those responsible for the coup must be sanctioned. Those responsible for the crimes against the Rohingya must be brought to justice, and what must be crystal clear from the debate today is that the European Union will not be silent.

name: Alessandro PANZA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, the situation in Myanmar following last week's coup d'état is a major concern and a number of concerns.  The lack of news of the president-elect in last November's free and democratic elections, Aung San Suu Kyi, and the arrest of hundreds of political leaders are a cause for concern. The introduction of martial law in the country's major cities is a cause for concern, a decision taken with the sole purpose of suppressing the protests that are filling the streets throughout the country, causing numerous injuries hit by rubber bullets and tear gas. This escalation, which threatens to undermine the fragile path to complete democracy, is a cause for concern. Above all, however, the role of China, which on many sides is referred to as the true director who brought General Min Aung Hlaing to power, is a cause for concern, and the veto in the UN Security Council of China itself only increases these suspicions. It is well known that China is implementing a strategy of global hegemony in trade, finance and military terms, and access to the Bay of Bengal and the Indian Ocean via Myanmar fits perfectly into this context. The deliberate lack of transparency on the management of COVID to the detriment of the entire global economy, the violent repression of Hong Kong, the questionable management of human rights and the continuous aggressive attitude on the commercial level require a strong, cohesive and rapid response from the whole West.  Let the European Union make its voice heard. Democracy in Myanmar is not only an indispensable value for the Burmese, it is necessary for the stability of the entire Asian continent and the embankment of Chinese misres.

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, I join in the unanimous condemnation of the coup d'am in Myanmar and ask the European Union not to contribute to its trade policy to support and legitimize the systematic violation of fundamental rights. The Commission should immediately review the implementation of the system of generalised preferences and paralyze the importation into the European Union of rice from Myanmar. It will seem anecdotal to many that I ask for this and it will also seem superficial, but I assure you that it is not at all superficial. Our rice producers are ruined because the European Union, despite the safeguard clause in force, continues to massively import rice from Cambodia and Myanmar, looking the other way when there are problems with human rights or customs control. If the Commission does not react commercially to these situations, do not think of asking our farmers for blind trust in the Green Pact and in so much hollow talk. If one of the objectives is to seek sustainability, I ask: what is more sustainable, rice imported from Myanmar or rice produced in the European Union? And I think the answer is obvious.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Madam President, we want to express our own concern about the last events in Myanmar, with special attention to the situation of ethnic and religious minorities, as well as ethnic armed groups and ethnic political parties in the sub—states of Myanmar, such as Shan, Karen, Chin, Rakhine, Kachin, Mon, and Karenni. We condemn and oppose this coup and call on the international community to act in accordance, and not to allow a return of military rule in Myanmar. We call on the Tatmadaw of the Republic of the Union of Myanmar to show restraint, to release all the arrested individuals and facilitate confidence-building measures, as well as to respect the nationwide ceasefire agreement. Once again, it is time to affirm that the will of the people must be respected and, therefore, we urge the military and the ethnic armed organisations to seek a solution through peaceful and inclusive discussions and negotiations.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Mr High Representative, the humanitarian situation in Myanmar, Burma, as we would say in Portuguese, is an absolutely deplorable situation. The military coup is not only a break with the limited democracy that existed in the country, it is again to return to the nightmare of the systematic human rights violations that the military over decades have committed throughout the territory.  It was no longer enough to worry, even in a limited democratic environment, about the human rights of the Roinja minority, which have never been fully guaranteed either by the military or the democratic government of Ms Aung San Suu Kyi, the truth is that now this danger and this risk extends to all the inhabitants of this country, without exception.  That is why we have to show full solidarity with the people of Myanmar and we must join forces with our global and regional partners, namely Japan, India and, of course, the United Kingdom and the United States, to eventually also put pressure on the military to return to constitutional regularity.  There is, however, an actor on whom the European Union has the tools to act and that so far no one has spoken and it is the elephant in the room that is absent, China. We are now with the investment agreement on China also at our negotiating table, also at our implementation table, perhaps it will be time to push for China to use all its known influence over the Burmese military to cease constitutional rupture and return sovereignty to the Burmese people.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, we spoke in the debate on Russia of Realpolitik and the language of power. We need to be aware that, for the time being, waiting for what the system of sanctions for human rights violations can give, one of the tools we have to manage ourselves in international politics is trade. I believe that to put pressure on the coupists we must resort to all the panoply of instruments that we have in our toolbox.  I would also ask you to examine with the Commission the desirability of using the system of generalised preferences. And I must say that I share your concern that we can use it in an ina sensible or un balanced way. But that clause was introduced into European law precisely for cases like this. So we have to find a system in which the Commission finds a formula for putting pressure on the military that has taken power and which, at the same time, in a parallel or accidental way, also causes an improvement in the system of trade and rice production within the European Union. Because, as has been said, the massive influx of Rice from Myanmar has led to a fall in European rice, the proportion of which was 60% a few years ago and is now 30%. I therefore ask you, in view of your reluctance to do so, that the Commission should not shut it down, as the resolution attached to this debate this afternoon will also tell you.

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A fitness video with military coup in the background. That has meme potential. But this has, above all, brought Myanmar into the public eye.  This has not been good for the democratisation process for some time, and there is also justified criticism of the civilian government. But the people have made their views clear in elections and are now taking to the streets peacefully, demonstrating, striking for democracy. The military responded with coup and violence. The EU must draw conclusions: support for the rohingya refugees and other minorities together with the UN, which needs access to the country, sanctions against responsible military personnel, suspension of preferential access to the EU's internal market. Respect for human rights is a prerequisite for cooperation.  The EU is not yet a diplomatic power. But we are an economic power. And, as Myanmar's third-largest trading partner, we must use the economic lever so that one day Myanmar's delicate plant of democracy can grow and not be overrun by tanks.

name: Rosanna CONTE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Myanmar, the military junta has imposed martial law to stop street protests. This is the latest act of a coup that has rekindle the international spotlight on the dramatic situation in the country. This shows that Myanmar is still a long way from the democratic transition that the European Union has praised in recent years.  The Commission has closed both eyes in order to justify its diplomacy of tariff concessions, which has failed to achieve its objective by fuelling unfair competition to the detriment of our companies. This is demonstrated by the invasion of Burmese rice: only in Italy has the import of the Japonica variety splashed above 80 %, affecting European companies and workers in a sector that is a world excellence.  We in the League have repeatedly called for the European Union to suspend the facilities. We cannot accept that those who abuse human rights and exploit workers even have a privileged channel for doing business in Europe. Just! Burmese rice is dirty with blood. By facilitating its import, Europe is thus becoming an accomplice in this coup.

name: Andreas SCHIEDER
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for his work For decades, Myanmar has been fighting for democracy with Myanmar's military. It has finally been on the road to democracy since 2015, and that is why I am all the more appalled by the military coup that took place last year. Our solidarity is with the democratic forces in Myanmar, and our solidarity calls for the immediate release of Aung San Suu Kyi and all the other democratic forces who are now innocently in prison.  We must also demand again that the democratically elected parliamentarians be reinstated and that the government that was democratically elected be reinstated. The military is breaking burma's constitution. This coup is unconstitutional. What we, as the European Union, can do as a first measure is to stop providing humanitarian aid through the capital, but directly through NGOs.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for High Representative Borell! It has been a dark week for Myanmar, which is now once again governed by the brutal military junta. For the fourth day in a row, brave people gather in several cities to demonstrate. The demonstrators have been met with water cannons with suspected poisoned water. Shots are also said to have been fired with unknown numbers of injured or dead.  The world has rightly condemned the junta's illegal takeover of power. Now the EUROPEAN Union must do everything in our power to ensure that Myanmar returns quickly to democratic rule, while supporting the popular protests that are now taking place, including condemning any attempt to silence or intimidate demonstrators.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, it has been an interesting debate where some points have  been put on the table and some issues may require an answer on my part.  Should the European Union not use or trigger the Everything But Arms (EBA) withdrawal procedure? The grave situation and the grave regression in human rights caused by the military coup – if not now, when? Some of you have asked that. But look, the EBA withdrawal is certainly a powerful instrument, which can foster positive change in partner countries. With Myanmar, it was actually delivering some, although limited, positive results, notably on social and labour rights. But the power of this instrument lies in the threat of the withdrawal – not in the withdrawal itself but in the threat, for example, in the process of monitoring before the actual decision is initiated. But take care because the EBA is a blunt instrument. Inasmuch as it affects the economy or at least the economic sector widely, even if used to cover only some specific tariff lines, it is not the best suited to be applied surgically to target specific individuals, companies or business interests. In the case of Myanmar, the aim is to target military interests as they are responsible for the current situation, not the whole economy.  According to the information available, military interests are focused on sectors that would not be affected by EBA preferences. In fact, most of Myanmar’s exports under the EBA regime are in the clothing sector, which employs more than 500 000 workers, mostly female workers, poor people. If we take this decision, they will suffer, not the military. In sum, withdrawing the EBA preferences would hit Myanmar’s economy hard, putting half a million low skilled workers at risk of poverty and leaving military interests almost untouched. Is that what we want? No. So take care when you ask to use some elements of our toolbox.  Another issue that has been raised by honourable Members is how the European Union should review its policy towards Myanmar if the legitimate government is not restored. It’s a legitimate question but, at present, our policy has two short—term objectives. Let’s concentrate on them: the immediate and unconditional release of those jailed because of the coup and the development of some form of dialogue. That’s what we should be focusing on. The policy options I outlined in my intervention are aimed at driving change in the short term in order to avoid the military government becoming a fait accompli and it becoming impossible to get rid of them.  There have been other military rules in Myanmar and these previous military rules lasted over five decades – five decades, 50 years, half a century – despite strong sanctions from almost the entire world. This shows that sometimes sanctions don’t work. We have to avoid repeating this situation. Our key objective remains to restore dialogue.  Incidentally, the need for dialogue was also the key message given by the respected Cardinal Bo, and it’s clear that the current crisis emerged from the military’s reluctance to cede power to the civilian side, but also from the breakdown of all channels of dialogue between the civilian and the military.  Dialogue has to be restored. There are many people who believe that dialogue is bad and you should not talk with the bad people. Well, sometimes you have to talk with the bad people precisely because they are bad people.  If the situation does not change, we will reassess the situation and re—examine our toolbox, having in mind the same principles I outlined before: be strong to affect change, and be careful to avoid undue impact on the general population and the most vulnerable. On the third issue, Ms Rookmaker asked me if I believe it’s good to coordinate with the US. Yes, for sure. In Myanmar we, the European Union, cannot seriously pretend to create the dynamics of change without coordination with the big powers, and the big powers there are the US, China and ASEAN.  From the outset, we, the European Union and our External Action Service and I, have been striving to coordinate this action and consult with as many relevant parties as possible. Naturally, we were closely involved in working with our G7 partners, but not only the traditional ones: the US, the UK, Canada, Norway and Australia. We also wanted to engage with other relevant stakeholders – India, China, ASEAN – and, in the case of the Rohingya crisis, the military coup in Myanmar is, first and foremost, a regional security issue. In addition to the humanitarian crisis, it’s a regional security issue and regional countries have the right and the duty to be first in line to respond. But this response has not been overwhelming. China, as you could have expected, did not even qualify the event as a coup, but a major government reshuffle. A reshuffle – you know, they change the government and it’s just a reshuffle. ASEAN was not able to reach consensus on any statement and resorted to a statement of the Chair. I know that sometimes it is difficult to get an agreement and it is the Chair who has to take responsibility, but is not the same thing. Brunei, for example, with very toned down language, was in in fact agreeing with Myanmar. In ASEAN the principle of non—interference in the internal affairs of other countries prevails.  There were many other issues. I would be delighted to continue answering them, going deeply into the subject. For example, should we, the European Union and the Member States, recall our ambassadors from Myanmar? Yes, it would send a strong signal, but I do not favour recalling our ambassadors. It would cut our channels of communication at a moment where we should facilitate dialogue. Once again, don’t lose the possibility of keeping dialogue open, even with the evil. It would also reduce our capacity to appraise the situation on the ground and our ability to gather information, but this is something that has to be checked permanently in order to fine-tune our tools to the situation.  There are many issues. Why do we, the European Union, only deploy a small electoral mission instead of a fully-fledged observation mission? You know how important our electoral observation missions are and how much I praise the work that we are doing there. The civil servants of this House and the Members of this House engage in these kinds of activities. However, the COVID—19 pandemic and the strict lockdown in Myanmar prevented the deployment of a fully—fledged exploratory mission, which, as you know, is a prerequisite for the observation mission.  But we were nevertheless able to engage with all relevant stakeholders and they are finalising their report. Our reporter will very much take into account what is happening in Rakhine State. The elections where they are open to the participation of the Rohingya and to the Rakhine people, but the actual result would have most likely further eroded the share of the military—backed party, if they could participate fully. In a nutshell, we have been a strong supporter of Myanmar’s democratic transition in the last 10 years. Yes, we had strong disagreements with the civilian government, notably after the 2017 events against the Rohingya, but we will not stop advocating for the return of the government and for holding the perpetrators of the worst human rights violations accountable. We are calling for national democracy to be upheld by Myanmar. With all its shortcomings, Myanmar remains a positive experiment in the region and we have to help them by acting strongly, quickly and in coordination with all our partners.  Thank you very much for your attention and thank you for holding this debate on something which is far away from us geographically but, once again, close to our minds and principles if we really want to be considered an institution that has human rights as the basis of its behaviour.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: I have received six motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 11 February 2021.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Michael Gahler, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the EU Association Agreement with Ukraine (2019/2202(INI)) (A9-0219/2020). I will just remind you that there will be no catch—the—eye procedure, and no blue cards will be accepted.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which (The speaker speaks in a language which is not an official language) Ukraine has chosen the European path. How do you support this? With the Association Agreement, we have established a comprehensive cooperation that leads to results step by step. If the vast majority of Ukrainian citizens are concerned, this path is irreversible. Only the prospect of a European way of life holds the promise of stable democracy, a fair rule of law and personal economic and social progress. Strong civil society and genuine reformers in politics are making every effort to realise the hopes of their citizens. On the other hand, there are menacing challenges. From the outside, Russia is the constant aggressor with the occupation and annexation of Crimea, which is contrary to international law, and the conquest and occupation of parts of Donetsk and Luhansk Oblasts, which goes hand in hand with a ceasefire that does not deserve the name. Just last Saturday, two Ukrainian soldiers were killed again. We are now mourning more than 13 000 civilian and military deaths, well over a million internally displaced persons and a largely lawless population, which is subject to arbitrariness of Russian-controlled henchmen in the occupied territories. Within Ukraine, Russia is practicing a diverse, open and covert hybrid warfare with allies in politics, business, and the media. That is why I would like to make it clear, for the current occasion, that there is a great deal to be said that the closure of three television stations belonging to a straw man under Mr Medvedchuk's control is not about curtailing the diversity of opinion, but about preventing continued media destabilisation in the interests and mission of Russia. There is plenty of room and reason in Ukraine for criticism of the president, the government and Verkhovna Rada. For this, Ukrainian democracy does not need media platforms that want to hand the country over to the Kremlin's revisionist interests. Ukraine has come an astonishing path since the revolution of dignity. Our support, including our financial support, is well-invested. We also provide comprehensive human resources in advising in a wide range of areas of business and administration. Our aim is simply to establish a democratic state that functions perfectly normally according to the law. There is very broad, fundamental support for this policy here in the European Parliament. Real friends support each other, but also tell each other the truth and the criticism when things get difficult. The real reformers know that we do not give good advice in our interests, but because we want to strengthen it and contribute to its success – also to defend against their enemies. There is an urgent need for action to combat corruption. We support NABU, the national anti-corruption office, and similarly independent institutions. They must not be hindered in their work. We support the Work of the High Anti-Corruption Court, which must set an example with its judgments for a fundamentally reformed judiciary, including prosecutors, sooner rather than later. The High Council of Justice must be reformed, as must the High Qualification Commission of Judges, which selects new judges and judges them in office. Without them, the whole reform process can be blocked. The system of electronic declaration of assets is effective and must not be undermined by a constitutional court working against the reforms. Decentralisation, coupled with municipal reform, is on the way to a great success story. It must not be jeopardised by unclear hierarchies or competing competences. The release of trade in agricultural land opens up great potential for rural development, even if the downstream economy is developed and the value chain is deepened by small and medium-sized enterprises. If the second stage of health reform fails, it is not so much the concept of reform that is the case with particular interests that want to channel certain financial flows into their pockets. Environmental protection must be an instrument for preserving Ukraine's great natural treasure and for using it carefully and sustainably. That is why we need the protection of the primeval forests in the Carpathians, the much more determined fight against illegal deforestation and the prevention of destructive tourism, and the development of ecological, sustainable tourism. Dear President Selensky, Olympic Games as in Russia, which fill the coffers of oligarchs and only a straw fire do not belong to Svydivez and not to Borshawa.  Ladies and gentlemen, our report identifies many other details in which we want to deepen the association. I would therefore like to thank you for good and trusting cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs, colleagues in the Foreign Affairs and Trade Committee, in the Parliamentary Association Committee and other committed Members and officials in the European Parliament and also in the Verkhovna Rada. A big compliment to you, dear Valdis. This praise goes to the Support Group for Ukraine and the External Action Service. We all work together for a good cause, a stable, democratic and European Ukraine. (The speaker speaks in a language which is not an official language)

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, first of all I would like to thank Mr Gahler for his comprehensive report. The EU has stood by Ukraine since Russia began its military aggression and illegally annexed Crimea in 2014. Ukraine remains high on the European agenda. We continue to provide political, financial and technical assistance as support for its reform agenda to build a more resilient economy. We have stepped up support, especially during this crisis, where the EU is showing solidarity with Ukraine during the pandemic. Our support for Ukraine’s independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity within its internationally recognised borders has been steadfast since the aggression began in the country’s southern and eastern regions. The ceasefire that has been largely holding – although with a recent spike in violence, but it has been largely holding since July – is an undeniable breakthrough. It brings tangible improvements on the ground. However, the overall pace of progress towards a peaceful and sustainable resolution of the conflict remains too slow. While Ukraine must be praised for its constructive approach and President Zelensky’s efforts, Russia must reciprocate. The EU expects Russia to use its considerable influence over the armed formations that it backs, as there is no place in 21st century Europe for using force to alter the boundaries of a sovereign country. Enforcement of our sanctions in response to the undermining of Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity by Russia is consistent and unwavering. Sectoral sanctions were rolled over in December 2020 by the European Council. The duration of these sanctions against Russia remains linked to complete implementation of the Minsk Agreements. The individual sanctions regime has only become wider over the years, in response to further Russian undermining of Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity.  The sanctions regime targeting the Crimean Peninsula is also consistently enforced. We have also put a new sanctions regime in place that allows the Council to impose asset freezes and travel bans on persons it deems to have committed serious human rights violations. If Member States call for it we are ready to make use of the EU global human rights sanctions regime against Russia. The EU stands firmly by Ukraine on its reform path, providing unprecedented financial and technical support. We are supporting Ukraine with a new market, a financial assistance programme worth EUR 1.2 billion to help mitigate the economic impact of the pandemic. Its first tranche of EUR 600 million was disbursed in early December.  The EU Ukraine Association Agreement is an unique platform for Ukraine to advance on its reform path, bringing our economies and societies closer together. The agreement is producing results. Our bilateral trade saw many years of uninterrupted growth stimulated by the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area. The pandemic set back this development last year, but we hope to return to positive tendencies soon. The agreement has an immense potential, and the EU is ready to explore all possibilities to continue enhancing our sectoral cooperation and economic integration.  As you rightly indicated in the report, implementing the agreement, including its Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area, must remain a top priority. We will discuss the next steps for developing our bilateral relations in the post—pandemic period at this week’s EU—Ukraine Association Council.  Tomorrow, Prime Minister Shmyhal and I will also launch the process for review of trade liberalisation for goods, which is foreseen under Article 29 of the Association Agreement, five years after its entry into force. The EU also stands by Ukraine in fighting the pandemic. We have reoriented several ongoing and future assistance programmes, with more than EUR 190 million going to Ukraine to help meet its COVID—19—related needs. The EU has also deployed the Civil Protection Mechanism to transfer equipment and supplies to Ukraine.  In addition, we are exploring options to help Ukraine to receive early access to vaccines. As part of the COVAX programme, Ukraine will receive 170 000 doses of the Pfizer vaccine in February and 2.2 million to 3.7 million doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine during the first half of the year.  We are looking forward to see vaccinations start in Ukraine this month. However, we are concerned about the impact of Russian disinformation and about the vaccination process in Ukraine. We are ready to assist in the fight against this disinformation and vaccine scepticism.  Parliament’s report strikes a very fine and accurate balance in praising achievements and acknowledging shortcomings. It rightly highlights that Ukraine has delivered many important reforms over the past years. These have all been hard fought and Ukraine’s leadership should be praised. However, I share your assessment that, despite notable progress, widespread corruption continues to hamper Ukraine’s reform process. Its key institutions must have strong and independent leadership and a chance to do their work free of political, economic or other interference.  As the report says, smuggling only benefits criminals and oligarchs. It must be stopped. For this, it is vital that National Anti—Corruption Bureau be fully independent. Over the years, the Bureau has demonstrated its effectiveness and produced tangible results. The fight against corruption is a core condition for EU macro—financial support.  Recent developments in the rule of law and anti-corruption show that comprehensive judiciary reform is long overdue. The Venice Commission and a G7 roadmap complementing the EU delegation’s constant advice to authorities and politicians give clear guidance on what has to be done. We recognise the complexity of the task.  From the start, Russian interference was designed to destabilise, divide and weaken Ukraine. So the best response is to stay united and keep working towards the prosperity and stability that come from sound economic policies. The EU is ready to support Ukraine in doing this.  We urge all reform—oriented political factions to come together and give a clear signal of Ukraine’s determination to make its reform path irreversible. This will be one of the main messages that I will convey to Prime Minister Shmyhal tomorrow.  The EU is helping Ukraine to create the right conditions for prosperity and peace. Ukraine has our support – political, financial and technical.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Before continuing with the debate I will now move to the results of today’s first voting session.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: We now continue with the debate on the report by Michael Gahler on the EU Association Agreement with Ukraine (A9-0219/2020).

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Thanks to the FREE TRADE AGREEMENT, our trade with Ukraine is expanding promisingly. Unfortunately, our partner has been trying to circumvent the convention with various legal and illegal tricks for some time. Their creativity hasn't diminished since the infamous "batman chickens." Since then, news of the introduction of various safeguards, be it timber, roses or fertilizers, has been coming. Some of the experiments were beaten back in time, but the last one was reached: Ukraine has been subject to a safeguard against imports of polymers since December.  It does so despite the fact that the move is contrary to the FTA and WTO rules. Ukraine calls this policy "smart protectionism." In my opinion, however, this is nothing more than a breach of contract. Ukraine must understand that bilateral relations are based on trust and fair compliance with agreements is essential for this. It must also be said that our eastern partner has repeatedly yielded to reason. That is because the Commission firmly represents the EU's interests on trade issues. This is the strategy that the Union should follow in political matters, so that it cannot tolerate atrocities against national minorities, such as hungarians living there.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. The report on the implementation of the EU-Ukraine Association Agreement underlines that Ukraine is an important geostrategic and political partner of the EU, which is committed to implementing reforms that meet the Copenhagen criteria, the principles of democracy, and expresses Ukraine's respect for fundamental and minority rights. Unfortunately, the developments of the last year show that, in addition to the Covid epidemic and the economic situation, there are serious problems to which the EU should react decisively.  I am thinking here of the spread of extremist views and methods, restrictions on freedom of media and opinion, unprecedented political pressure on the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia and constant intimidation. The excesses of the Ukrainian security services against Hungarian organizations and their leaders, or the death list of the extremist site Mirotorec.  The Hungarian community in Transcarpathia has been subject to language, education and representation restrictions for years and is treated as an enemy, even though the current minority law and the constitution guarantee wide rights for national minorities. The Hungarian community in Ukraine wants nothing more than to preserve their existing rights, to participate as partners in the legislative process affecting minorities and to live peacefully in their homeland. He has been receiving great help from the Hungarian Government for many years, which also proves that the Hungarian community in Transcarpathia plays the role of bridge not only in the relationship between the two countries, but also in the EU. It is important that the report contains amendments to the hungarian minority's point of view and I hope that these important problems will also be on the agenda of the EU-Ukraine Association Council.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, this report underscores that Ukraine remains one of the European Union’s most important partners in the Eastern Partnership region, and also the most important recipient of EU financial assistance.  We are encouraged by the willingness to implement important reforms and by the strong public support for them among the Ukrainian people. We are, however, also extremely worried by the implications of the recent Constitutional Court ruling, which annulled key pieces of the country’s anti-corruption agenda. The fight against corruption must remain the focus of all political activities in Ukraine. If it’s not successful, then all other reforms that aim to improve the standard of living of all Ukrainians are in danger.  This is why the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament will continue to lend our support to all of those in the Verkhovna Rada who want to eliminate corruption from public life.  We call on all parties to work together to reinstate the anti-corruption measures that have been struck down by the Constitutional Court and to adopt and implement additional legislation that would protect Ukraine from actors, both internal and external, who are hostile to these much needed reforms.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the 7th anniversary of the Euromaidan revolution marks a tremendous advancement in EU-Ukraine relations. Bilateral commitments enshrined in the Association Agreements guide our cooperation, which already delivers much needed changes, and provide an ambitious agenda for future relations and deeper partnership. The Euromaidan anniversary also marks a grave period of Russian military aggression against Ukraine, which is continuing to bring suffering and the loss of many more than 13 000 lives.  In our relations with Ukraine, the immediate priority is a common fight against COVID-19. Medium-term priorities should focus on socioeconomic reforms and economic development in Ukraine. The long-term aim is achieving the EU membership perspective for Ukraine.  It is in our interest to further advance a gradual economic integration with Ukraine by creating a common economic space and providing a reliable basis for economic growth and mutually beneficial trade relations. Equally important is for the European Union to do its utmost to support Ukraine’s sovereignty, including its information sovereignty, and to help build resilience to hostile influence from third countries.  On this occasion I thank the rapporteur, Michael Gahler, and all shadows for the excellent work and one step forward in EU-Ukraine’s future relations.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, in Ukraine, the European Union has still not learned anything from its mistakes. In 2013, it was a form of fanaticism that took over the Commission. It went against all the historical, cultural and political evidence and wanted Ukraine to immediately sign an association agreement which had the main objective of keeping Kiev away from Russia. It was to ignore the importance of the links between a part of the Ukrainian population and Russia, especially in Crimea and the Donbass. Since 2013, the European Union has squandered European money for ideological objectives unrelated to the country's reality. As our colleague Mike Wallace demonstrated in committee, behind the generosity of the Commission lies in fact a more sordid reality. Privatization of agricultural land, privatization of forests and the prudent liberalisation of the Ukrainian economy are the counterparts that globalism imposes on the Ukrainian people. The conclusion will be bitter for this people. Ukraine was to be a link between Western Europe and Russia. Instead, this country is under infusion of European public money, which we know is being used without serious control. Hundreds of millions of euros of loans were disbursed, without any consideration, for COVID-19. Since 2013, the European Union has not enriched the country. It has increased the rent of the oligarchs. Having extolled the merits of President Zelensky, we note that he has just suddenly shut down three private television channels to better consolidate his power. Our association with Ukraine is costly, fruitless for Ukrainians and for our peoples, and generating tensions with Russia. This is the assessment of the madness of Brussels since 2013.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, Commissioner Dombrovskis, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has In 2019, we revealed that Ukraine is handling the 50 000 tonne import quota for chicken breasts with a cheap trick. They have imported the chicken breasts with a small piece of bone on them than other chicken parts that do not have import quotas – the so-called "Batman cut". On my visit to Ukraine in 2019, I saw whole areas whose groundwater was so nitrate-contaminated that the water was no longer drinkable, that even the poorest sections of the population did not go to the chicken factories because they noticed that the people who work there are very quickly and very badly ill. I've seen a whole valley full of chicken maniman, where the sauce - the black sauce - just swelled into the creek, into the woods. Since 2014, Ukraine has been pledging veterinary reports on animal hygiene, but also on animal welfare, under the Association Agreement. And to date – I inquired yesterday at the Permanent Representation in Kiev – none of these reports has been received. This is about hygiene and animal welfare. It is already difficult enough for European producers to keep up with dumping wages of EUR 150 or with farms such as MHP, which at that time, in 2019, had 378 000 hectares under the plough. It is difficult enough to maintain European production here.  I say here on behalf of my group: we stand by friendship with Ukraine, we stand by the European path with Ukraine. But one thing must be clear: those who participate in the European market must also abide by the common rules.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, (inaudible passage) we have to make efforts though to reverse the really bad impression made by Mr Borrell’s visit to Moscow. Lavrov was given the platform to deliver all anti-Ukraine clichés publicly.  The best way out is to immediately stop Nord Stream 2, maintain and extend sanctions and, most importantly, for Mr Borrell to undertake quick visits to Kiev and Tbilisi. These are the capitals to consult on EU-Russia policy, before the Council, rather than Moscow.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, the reforms mandated by the EU-backed loan to Ukraine in 2014 included a cultural deregulation intended to benefit foreign agri—business.  More recently, Western solidarity with Ukraine saw COVID-19 weaponised in a new round of disaster capitalism. In June last year, both the IMF and World Bank COVID relief package loans came with conditions on liberalisation of laws around the sale of state-owned land.  We’ve recently seen how a network of private equity firms, like the New York-based NCH Capital, working through offshore tax havens and financed by the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the Dutch pension fund PGGM, and a host of EU and US profiteers have targeted Ukraine, leasing or buying up farms for next to nothing and aggregating them into large—scale US style grain and soybean farms. This is neo—colonialism, theft and exploitation.  Is it any wonder that the pro—Russian party is battering Zelensky’s party in the polls at the moment? If you don’t cop onto yourselves, you’ll have another coup to orchestrate soon enough.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, it’s an important day for our friends in Ukraine, who were fighting and dying for European choice, Euromaidan, seven years ago. Since then Ukraine has managed to achieve a lot, despite the fact that the Kremlin war against Ukraine is still going on. I fully support the report which we are discussing today. Of course there are shortcomings in the Ukraine reforms, which the report is pointing out. But I would urge to see both sides in our relations with Ukraine. There are problems in Ukraine, but also there are problems inside of EU policy towards Ukraine and Eastern Partnership countries. Back in 2014 Ukrainians made a geopolitical choice to go for democracy, for European integration. It changed not only Ukraine, it is making big influence on the changes which started to happen in Belarus and Russia. And those changes demand from us, from the EU, to have much more ambitious policy towards eastern partnership countries, and especially towards Ukraine. The association language of quotas, standards, etc., is important but it is not enough for a geopolitical Commission. We need to come back to the language of ambitions and big dreams.  Seven years ago Ukrainians fought for the dream to join the European family. Let’s have a big dream on our side also: to have Ukraine in our family at some time. And let’s speak our dream loudly and work together  to make it reality. Let’s offer a clear road map to the fulfilment of our common dream. Slava Ukraini!

name: Marek BELKA
text: – Madam President, if we were tasked to define the benefits of the association agreement with Ukraine, the DCFTA alone could be a sufficient answer. Since 2016, our bilateral trade has grown steadily, and the EU is now Ukraine’s largest trading partner and by far the most important partner in the process of reforms. The pandemic has somewhat hampered our mutual success, but we cannot allow it to undermine Ukraine’s achievements in the field of macroeconomic governance, for example. The EU’s MFA loans, COVID—19 response packages and technical assistance programmes should be commended and extended further to allow for the roll—out of vaccination programmes. However, we have to expect full respect for the provisions of the agreement with regard to regulatory approximation, increased efforts to fight corruption, stronger protection of property rights and guarantees of freedom of association and collective bargaining rights for workers. We should also urge our Ukrainian partners to create a predictable regulatory environment with an independent judiciary and limited influence of state—owned enterprises and oligarch—based interest groups, in order to attract much—needed foreign direct investment.
