This is needed to reap the full benefit of our growing economic cooperation.

name: Karin KARLSBRO
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his Colleagues! It is now almost four years since the EU concluded the association agreement with Ukraine. It was a victory for Europe and for the Ukrainian people, who carried out a revolution for the sake of the agreement. The Euromaydan was a revolution for Europe. It was when Yanukovych in 2013 at the last moment reconsidered and chose not to sign that the Ukrainian people had enough and deposed him. It also means that we in the EUROPEAN Union have a great responsibility and expectation to live up to.  It is important that we are clear that Ukraine has some way to go in terms of judicial and political reform. Because the desire to move closer to Europe is precisely that, about recoming once and for all the corrupt structures that have been hanging around since the Soviet era. And we have to set high standards. However, I welcome this report and the clear ambition it has. Ukraine belongs in Europe. Ukrayina tse Yevropa. Ukraine is Europe.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report Ukraine's rapprochement with the EU is to be welcomed in principle, but only if it does not put an additional strain on our relationship with Russia.  Russia is an important partner for us, the demonisation of which, despite all the justified criticism, is not effective. Ukraine's rapprochement with the EU, which, incidentally, has cost us well over EUR 10 billion since 2014, can only take place if Ukraine also shows appropriate reform efforts – which, unfortunately, is not the case.  The lack of implementation of the KÜ, which I have already mentioned on several occasions, proves this just as impressively as the lack of response to our letter to President Selenskyj. Commission President von der Leyen, incidentally, has not yet responded to this matter.  Recently, the Ukrainian president had three TV channels blocked. Allegedly, they spread pro-Russian propaganda. Blocking these channels, as their contributions seem to have not appealed to political decision-makers, is an unacceptable attack on freedom of expression.  Under Selenskyj, Ukraine does not seem to be following the hoped-for path of reform and instead following the US doctrine and working on Russia. Ukraine could serve as an excellent bridge between the EU and Russia. As long as that does not change, the EU should suspend aid and credit.

name: Krzysztof JURGIEL
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Since the entry into force of the Association Agreement, Ukraine has implemented a number of reform measures, adopting m.in. laws on land trading and banking and entering into provisional arbitration of appeals. However, the reform process in Ukraine should be deepened, as the completion rate of the tasks related to the implementation of the Association Agreement has decreased over the last two years.  Firstly, Ukraine should step up its efforts to bring its legislation closer to EU standards on food safety as well as animal welfare. Secondly, it is necessary to address the differences between rural and urban areas as soon as possible by introducing a development policy on social, economic and territorial cohesion.  Poland is also concerned about the news reported by dairy farmers' organisations, which are signalling that the Ukrainian authorities intend to investigate the increasing import of dairy products into Ukraine.  Cooperation with Ukraine is beneficial for the European Union, but its rules should be respected by both sides.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Mr Gahler, I would like to thank mr Gahler for his work on this I agree with you in the bottom line: the association agreement with Ukraine needs a critically constructive, comprehensive review. We must examine why what a majority of the Ukrainian population promised of the agreement did not happen. Their everyday life, their experiences, are the criterion of truth. What do we need to change in order to finally overcome the social crisis among large sections of the population and to safeguard European environmental standards? How can the rule of law be experienced? How can we help curb corruption, put an end to tax evasion and tax avoidance, free the country from the debt devil of macro-financial assistance, finally dismantle the oligarchic structures of all stripes? What needs to be changed in the agreement so that the trade balance does not shift further in favour of the EU – with the lion's share for Germany and Poland? We must treat Ukraine and its people throughout the country as partners. We need much more cooperation, also in the form of twinning projects. And yes, how can we strengthen peace efforts and re-develop economic, even trilateral, relations with traditional partner Russia in accordance with the Minsk Protocols?

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, congratulations to Mr Gahler on the quality of the report on Ukraine. I welcome the progress, whether limited, by Ukraine in the Framework of the Association Agreement with the Union.  Although minorities in Ukraine have put their hopes in President Zelenski's election promises, according to the Minister of Education, I quote: "the schools of national minorities that speak a language of the European Union will move to teaching in Ukrainian from September 2023".  Kiev must understand that minorities on the territory of Ukraine, whether ethnic Romanians, Hungarians or Russians, have the right to retain their language, customs and culture, thereby contributing to the enrichment of Ukraine's cultural heritage. I make it clear that more than half a million Romanian speakers live in Chernivtsi, Odessa and Transcarpathia.  The solution to ending this social dispute between minorities in the territory of Ukraine and the political power in Kiev is the immediate annulment of articles of the Education Law that prohibit or limit teaching in the language of minorities. This action is all the more necessary as the legislative measure has also led to the righteous dissatisfaction of Ukraine's neighbours.

name: Attila ARA-KOVÁCS
text: "Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Dear Colleagues, Officer, I'm sorry. The other day, we heard from the editor-in-chief of RT, a Russian state propaganda channel, that the time had come to annex the territories of eastern Ukraine with Russia. Although the Kremlin denies this, I have no doubt that the idea did not come out of the head of that editor-in-chief. The lead-up is kind of a breathalyzer. They measure internal and external reactions. The occupation of Crimea was overtaken by similar phenomena. After all this, I believe that we need to strengthen and even expand our security policy relationship with Ukraine. Without the security of Ukraine, the security of the European Union is not guaranteed. It is necessary to be prepared that the current state of rest, apparent rest, will not be left. Putin has growing domestic political problems at home, and such provocations can be a precursor to more serious events. Therefore, if Moscow were to move forward, more effective sanctions should be immediately responded to

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. We need reliable and reliable partners, especially across our eastern border. Further deepening economic and political cooperation with Ukraine is undoubtedly a necessary and mutually beneficial process. Its long-term objective should be to integrate our economies more seriously and to create the conditions for Ukraine's future accession to the European Union.  Kiev continues to face Russian aggression, which not only destabilises the region, but also poses a threat to European security. Reforming the structures of the state in these conditions is a very difficult task. This should be taken into account when assessing the pace of anti-corruption and judicial reform. In the difficult circumstances of the pandemic, our solidarity is of great importance, which is why the financial support package for Kiev is an important initiative that will confirm that, in addition to good advice and intentions, cooperation with the European Union simply pays off.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, thank you above all to my colleague Gahler who made an excellent report. Mr. Commissioner, Colleague Gahler, you have said correctly, Ukraine is one of the priority partners of the European Union.  In this parliament, we have on numerous occasions actually expressed our support and commitment to ukraine's full independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity, of course within its internationally recognised borders.  During the visit of The Minister for Temporary Occupied Territories of Ukraine Olexi Reznikov to Croatia last October, the Croatian Government emphasized its support for territorial integrity, also the European path of Ukraine. Croatia also expressed its readiness to share the experiences of the peaceful reintegration of the Croatian Danube into the constitutional order of the Republic of Croatia in January 1998.  Despite the positive progress we have seen after the summit of leaders of the Eastern Partnership countries, Member States and European institutions within the Framework of the Croatian Presidency of the Council, which took place in Zagreb last June, problems remain that remain a strong challenge to the future progress of our relations.  More tools are needed to encourage crucial reforms, and we see this in particular in the example of the Countries of the Western Balkans and here ukraine. We see and warn about the problem of corruption, the difficult consolidation of the rule of law, the implementation of socioeconomic reforms and the strengthening of the role of citizens in a democratic society. With growing geopolitical turmoil in the region, but also across the European Union's neighbourhood, further strengthening our partnership with Ukraine should be one of our foreign policy objectives. Ukraine's progress in implementing the obligations under the agreement is visible as is strong support in moving closer to the European Union and NATO. Therefore, we must respond to the expectations of the Ukrainian people.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Since the entry into force of the 2017 Agreement, Ukraine has undoubtedly made visible progress. However, there is still a lot of work to be done. From the Union's point of view, it is crucial to complete the reforms that have started, particularly in the areas of the rule of law, the electoral system, the fight against corruption and the rights of minorities, including Poland. Resurgent nationalism is also of concern. Outside the free trade area, the free movement of people is also an important factor in Ukraine's approach to the European Union.  Let us remember that one of the conditions for effective integration is to increase people-to-people contacts and build responses from the bottom up. Unfortunately, these possibilities are significantly complicated by the current pandemic. With this in mind, we should aim to transfer some of the vaccines at the disposal of the European Union and the Member States to Ukraine. Surely this gesture of solidarity will help to build friendly relations with the Ukrainian people and to better implement the association agreement with the European Union.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-President, I think it is an extremely important report that we are debating today, and I must make it very clear that Kiev must understand that, after the annexation of Crimea, one of the most important and loyal partners it has had has been and remains the European Union.  Ukraine cannot get through this transitional period without the support of the European Union and, in order to reform itself, to speed up the European path it needs our support, to fight corruption, to reform its institutions, to escape this aggressive influence of the Russian Federation. But Ukraine must do another extremely important thing: after the Russian minority, in this neighbouring country of the European Union, the largest minority is the Romanian minority, which is subject to a process of denationalization almost identical to that practiced by the Soviet Union.  That is why I call on the European Commission to set up a monitoring mechanism on minorities existing in Ukraine, those who speak official languages of the European Union, such as the Romanian minority, the Hungarian, Polish, Bulgarian and other minorities. It is absolutely vital that we have a real picture of what is happening today with regard to the situation of minorities in Ukraine.

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: – Madam President, despite the undeniable progress made by Ukraine, there remain areas on which our eastern partner must continue to insist, such as judicial reform or anti-corruption measures. But I would also like to draw attention to another situation that is discriminatory and violates, including Article 22 of the Constitution of Ukraine. I am talking about limiting the right of ethnic minorities to learn in their mother tongue.  The minority Romanian, for example, which numbers about half a million people, only wants to be able to pass on its language and culture to future generations, but because of the new education law, this will no longer be possible from 2023. Although, on paper, this right will practically exist after the fifth grade, the children of ethnic Romanians and other minorities will be required to courses only in Ukrainian, with the exception of a single subject which can be taught in the mother tongue, but which will be a subject imposed and not chosen by the student.  This situation is neither acceptable nor consistent with our values and principles. Access to education must be guaranteed by any state that wants a rapprochement with the European Union and any measure that has the effect of assimilating a minority must be condemned.

name: Rasa JUKNEVIČIENĖ
text: – Madam President, I will speak about the Kremlin’s hybrid war against Ukraine and whether we should condemn Ukraine if it fights against this information. Ukraine is a state at war. Hostile propaganda against Ukraine is an integral part of the Kremlin war. Kremlin-backed media is not media as we understand, it is a weapon to destroy human brains. It is Kremlin’s weapon just like any other weapon that kills Ukrainian troops in eastern Ukraine. We must have full information about how the Kremlin is operating inside Ukraine. It is a hybrid war that employs all means, buying politicians, even parties, shadow money for disinformation and a network of spies. In the Special Committee on Foreign Interference in all Democratic Processes in the European Union, including Disinformation (INGE Committee), we examine external influences and political processes in the EU. In Ukraine, outside influence is like a landfill in which the Kremlin operates on a daily basis. Before condemning, one must first understand and help.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Dear President, first of all, we welcome Ukraine's achievements by particularly assessing the exceptionally difficult conditions under which they are fulfilled. While ukraine's reform momentum and institutional challenges have not yet exhausted all the reform opportunities, and the country's independence and territorial integrity with internationally recognised borders are still under threat due to Russia's continued illegal annexation of Crimea, the occupation of the Donetsk and Luhansk areas, Ukraine is making good use of its unique expertise and expertise by participating in common security and defence policy missions. We should congratulate Ukraine and its new NATO-enhanced partner status. The ukrainian Government's position to prevent the importation of electricity from power plants which are not built in accordance with international requirements and the highest environmental and safety standards is also welcomed. I believe that Ukraine will continue to take a European orientation and continue its progress in implementing reforms, gradually integrating into the European Union market and respecting democratic principles. Слава Україні!

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, before I conclude, I would like to agree with another part of the report.  It rightly commends Ukrainian civil society, young people and NGOs for their vibrant activities. All who have visited Ukraine during the last years, including myself, have been deeply impressed by their determination to forge a better future.  I know that the conflict and the economic situation have weighed heavily on young Ukrainians. Many have been internally displaced. Many others have emigrated. Some leave for a short time as students, taking advantage of the Erasmus Plus exchange programme to gain experience elsewhere in Europe. In fact, Ukraine is among the most active and successful participants in Erasmus Plus, having access on the same terms as EU Member States. I believe that today we can send them a joint message of support and recognition for their invaluable contribution. Ukraine’s future is in their hands and Europe is standing strong for Ukraine.
